questions.text: A 64-year-old woman presents with dyspnea and orthopnea. She is a lifelong non-smoker. Her pulmonary function testing (PFT) results are as follows:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mixed Obstruction–Restriction

 

Step 1. Identify Obstruction:

 

  • FEV₁/FVC = 61% (<70%) → Obstructive defect
  • FEV₁ = 30% predicted → Severe obstruction

 

Step 2. Identify Restriction:

 

  • TLC = 52% predicted → True restriction
  • Restrictive defect is confirmed when TLC < 80% predicted, not merely a reduced FVC.

 

Step 3. Integration:

 

  • Both obstructive and restrictive features are present → Mixed pattern.

 

Step 4. Rule out Pseudorestriction:

 

  • In pseudorestriction (as in severe air trapping), TLC is normal or high.
  • Here, TLC is reduced, confirming true restriction rather than pseudo.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Severe Obstruction: FEV₁/FVC ↓ supports obstruction, but TLC is also ↓ → not pure obstruction.

 

Option B. Severe Restriction: Restrictive defect present, but FEV₁/FVC ratio is ↓ → not pure restriction.

 

Option D. Pseudorestriction: Seen in air trapping (↓FVC, normal/increased TLC). Here TLC is ↓ (52%) → true, not pseudo, restriction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A mixed obstructive–restrictive pattern on PFT is diagnosed when both:

 

  • FEV₁/FVC < 70% (obstruction) and
  • TLC < 80% predicted (restriction).

choices.text: Immediate antitoxin administration after sensitivity testing
Remove membrane and give local antiseptics
Wait for culture confirmation before starting treatment

questions.text: 6-year-old unimmunized child presents with low-grade fever, sore throat, and difficulty swallowing for 3 days. Examination reveals the findings shown in the image, a characteristic bull neck appearance, and a muffled voice. The child appears toxic and has moderate respiratory distress. What is the most appropriate first step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Immediate antitoxin administration after sensitivity testing

 

  • This child presents with classic signs of diphtheria, including the pathognomonic greyish-white membrane that bleeds on attempted removal, bull neck appearance (due to significant cervical lymphadenopathy), and muffled voice (suggesting laryngeal involvement).
  • Diphtheria toxin causes local tissue destruction and can lead to myocarditis, neuritis, and respiratory failure when systemically absorbed. 
  • Antitoxin neutralizes circulating toxin, preventing further damage, and should be administered immediately after a sensitivity test to check for hypersensitivity to horse serum. 
  • The dose depends on the site and extent of disease, with 80,000-120,000 units indicated for severe pharyngeal/laryngeal disease as in this case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Start IV antibiotics and observe: While antibiotics (penicillin or erythromycin) are essential to eradicate the organism and prevent further toxin production, they will not neutralize already circulating toxin. Antibiotics should be given after antitoxin administration but aren't sufficient alone for a child with signs of severe disease and toxin effects.

 

Option C. Remove membrane and give local antiseptics: Attempting to remove the membrane is contraindicated as it may cause bleeding, increases pain, and can promote toxin absorption. The membrane also provides important diagnostic evidence and should be sampled for culture rather than removed.

 

Option D. Wait for culture confirmation before starting treatment: Delaying treatment until culture confirmation (which may take 48-72 hours) significantly increases mortality. Treatment should be initiated based on clinical diagnosis in an unimmunized child with characteristic features, as the case fatality rate increases with each day of delayed treatment.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Diphtheria is a medical emergency requiring immediate intervention. 
  • The management priority is antitoxin administration after sensitivity testing to neutralize circulating toxin, followed by appropriate antibiotics and supportive care. 
  • The dosage of antitoxin depends on disease severity, with higher doses (80,000-120,000 units) indicated for severe or extensive disease.

choices.text: Immersion in 0.5% sodium hypochlorite for 2 hours

questions.text: A 35-year-old neurosurgeon expresses concern about prion contamination after operating on a patient later diagnosed with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease. The surgical team prepares to sterilize the neurosurgical instruments used during the case. Which of the following decontamination strategies is insufficient for inactivating prion proteins?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gamma radiation at 25 kGy dose

 

  • Prions, unlike typical infectious agents, are extremely resistant to standard physical and chemical sterilization techniques. 
  • Their pathogenic isoform (PrP<sup>Sc</sup>) aggregates and resists breakdown because of its stable beta-sheet conformation.
  • According to CDC and WHO recommendations, effective inactivation of prions includes:
    • Autoclaving at 134°C for 1–1.5 hours under vacuum
    • Immersion in 1N sodium hydroxide for 1 hour
    • Immersion in 0.5% sodium hypochlorite for at least 1–2 hours
  • In contrast, gamma irradiation at 25 kGy, which is effective for sterilizing many bacteria and viruses, does not reliably inactivate prions, even at high doses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autoclaving at 134°C for 60 minutes: Effective method. High-pressure steam at this temperature denatures PrP<sup>Sc</sup> structures when done properly under vacuum.

 

Option B. Soaking in 1N NaOH for 1 hour: Effective method. Strong alkaline conditions degrade the prion protein and denature its pathogenic form.

 

Option C. Immersion in 0.5% Sodium hypochlorite for 2 hours: Effective method. This is a WHO-endorsed chemical sterilant for prion-contaminated tools.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Prion proteins are highly resistant to conventional sterilization. Gamma radiation, UV light, and alcohols are ineffective. 
  • Only extreme protocols like autoclaving at 134°C, NaOH, or sodium hypochlorite for prolonged periods can reliably inactivate prions on medical equipment.

questions.text:
Peripheral IV cannulation in newborn requires: 

 

  1. 24G needle
  2. 16G needle
  3. 5 mL syringe
  4. Adhesive tape
  5. Normal saline
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 3, 4, 5

 

Newborns require small-bore cannula (24G) with 5ml syringe, adhesive tape, and normal saline for patency check.

 

Incorrect Option:


2. 16G needle: 16G needle is used in trauma.

 

Educational Objective:


Use 24–26G needles for neonates to avoid vascular trauma.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements correctly identify key differentiators in larval behaviour among intestinal nematodes? 

 

  1. Hookworm and Strongyloides stercoralis share skin penetration and pulmonary migration, but only Strongyloides can complete its life cycle within the host via autoinfection.
  2. Trichuris trichiura and Enterobius vermicularis lack a larval lung migration phase and reside primarily in the small intestine.
  3. Ascaris lumbricoides uniquely has both fertilized and unfertilized eggs, and its larvae undergo hepatic-tracheal migration.
  4. Strongyloides stercoralis is the only nematode which is diagnosed by finding larvae, not eggs, in stool.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 3 and 4 only

 

Statement 1. Hookworm and Strongyloides stercoralis share skin penetration and pulmonary migration, but only Strongyloides can complete its life cycle within the host via autoinfection: Correct. Hookworm and Strongyloides enter via skin and migrate via lungs. However, Strongyloides is the only helminth in this group capable of internal autoinfection, often leading to hyperinfection in immunocompromised patients.

 

Statement 3. Ascaris lumbricoides uniquely has both fertilized and unfertilized eggs, and its larvae undergo hepatic-tracheal migration: Correct.  Ascaris produces both egg types. After ingestion, larvae migrate to the lungs, causing Löffler’s syndrome, then are coughed up and swallowed, returning to the small intestine.

 

Statement 4. Strongyloides stercoralis is the only nematode which is diagnosed by finding larvae, not eggs, in stool: Correct. Unlike other intestinal nematodes, Strongyloides is diagnosed by rhabditiform larvae in stool. Eggs are rarely seen.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 2. Trichuris trichiura and Enterobius vermicularis lack a larval lung migration phase and reside primarily in the small intestine: Incorrect. Both Trichuris and Enterobius do not undergo lung migration, but they reside in the large intestine, not the small intestine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Strongyloides stercoralis is the only intestinal nematode that can cause autoinfection and is diagnosed by larvae in stool, not eggs. 
  • Trichuris and Enterobius lack a lung phase and reside in the large intestine, not the small intestine.

questions.text:
Which statement(s) is/are accurate concerning local anesthetics?

 

  1. Prilocaine is longer acting than Bupivacaine.
  2. Tetracaine is more potent than Lignocaine.
  3. Dibucaine is the longest acting local anesthetic.
  4. Bupivacaine can produce cardiotoxicity.
  5. Cocaine can produce hypotension.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2, 3, 4

 

Statement 2. Tetracaine is more Potent than Lignocaine: Tetracaine is considered a high-potency local anesthetic and is generally more potent than lignocaine (lidocaine), which is an intermediate-potency local anesthetic.
 

Statement 3. Dibucaine is the Longest-Acting Local Anesthetic: Dibucaine is known for its very long duration of action among local anesthetics, making it one of the longest-acting agents in this class.
 

Statement 4. Bupivacaine can produce Cardiotoxicity: Bupivacaine, particularly when used in high doses or inadvertently administered systemically, can produce cardiotoxicity, including potential for cardiac arrhythmias and toxicity.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 1. Prilocaine is Longer Acting than Bupivacaine: Bupivacaine is known for its long duration of action, while prilocaine has a shorter duration of action compared to bupivacaine. Therefore, this statement is false.

 

Statement 5. Cocaine can produce Hypotension: Cocaine, as a vasoconstrictor, can lead to hypertension rather than hypotension due to its effects on the cardiovascular system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Based on potency & duration local anaesthetics are classified into:

 

 

  • Cocaine causes vasoconstriction leading to hypertension.
  • Bupivacaine is the most cardiotoxic local anesthetic.

questions.text: Match the type of muscle contraction with its defining characteristic choose the correct match:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1–a, 2–b, 3–c, 4–d

 

  • 1–a. Isometric → Constant muscle length, variable tension: Tension ↑ but length constant (e.g., holding a weight steady).
  • 2–b. Isotonic (concentric) → Constant tension, shortening of muscle: Tension constant, muscle shortens.
  • 3–c. Eccentric → Muscle lengthens while contracting: Muscle lengthens while contracting (controlled lowering of weight).
  • 4–d. Isokinetic → Constant velocity of contraction: Muscle contracts at constant velocity (requires specialized equipment).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Different muscle contractions vary by whether length, tension, or velocity remains constant during contraction.

 

  • Isometric: Length constant, tension changes
  • Isotonic (Concentric): Tension constant, muscle shortens
  • Eccentric: Muscle lengthens while contracting
  • Isokinetic: Constant velocity contraction

questions.text: A molecular biologist is developing a diagnostic PCR-based assay to detect mutations in a gene associated with colorectal cancer. During optimization, she uses a modified DNA polymerase that can synthesize DNA and proofread errors but cannot remove nucleotides ahead of the growing DNA strand. Which of the following enzymes is she most likely using in this experiment?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Klenow fragment

 

  • A modified DNA polymerase used in a PCR-based assay that can synthesize DNA and proofread errors (3′→5′ exonuclease activity) but cannot remove nucleotides ahead of the growing strand (no 5′→3′ exonuclease activity).
  • This exactly describes the Klenow fragment, which is a large fragment of E. coli DNA polymerase I produced when the enzyme is cleaved by the protease subtilisin. 
  • This cleavage removes the 5′→3′ exonuclease domain, leaving behind two functional domains:
    1. 5′→3′ polymerase activity – allows DNA synthesis.
    2. 3′→5′ exonuclease activity – enables proofreading and correction of misincorporated bases.
  • Because it lacks the 5′→3′ exonuclease function, the Klenow fragment cannot remove nucleotides ahead of the growing DNA strand (no “nick translation” activity). 
  • This makes it ideal for DNA labeling, sequencing, and site-directed mutagenesis, where controlled synthesis and proofreading are required without strand degradation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DNA Polymerase I (E. coli): Incorrect. Native E. coli DNA polymerase I possesses three enzymatic activities:

 

  • 5′→3′ polymerase activity (DNA synthesis)
  • 3′→5′ exonuclease activity (proofreading)
  • 5′→3′ exonuclease activity (nick translation)
    Since the question specifies that the enzyme cannot remove nucleotides ahead of the strand, this enzyme is excluded because it retains the 5′→3′ exonuclease function.

 

Option C. Restriction Endonuclease: Incorrect. Restriction endonucleases are enzymes that cut DNA at specific palindromic recognition sequences. They do not participate in DNA synthesis or proofreading, so they are unrelated to polymerase function or PCR-based applications.

 

Option D. RNA Polymerase: Incorrect. RNA polymerase synthesizes RNA from a DNA template, not DNA. It does not have proofreading activity comparable to DNA polymerases and lacks both 5′→3′ and 3′→5′ exonuclease activities. Hence, it does not match the enzyme described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Klenow fragment is a modified form of E. coli DNA polymerase I that retains 5′→3′ polymerase and 3′→5′ exonuclease (proofreading) activities but lacks 5′→3′ exonuclease activity, making it suitable for DNA synthesis without strand degradation.

choices.text: If the test is positive, the patient definitely has the disease
If the test is negative, the patient is very unlikely to have the disease
If the disease is common in the population and the test is positive, the patient must have the disease
If the disease is rare in the population and the test is positive, the patient is likely to have the disease

questions.text: A 45-year-old asymptomatic man participates in a community screening program for a condition which is serious but treatable early stage. The screening test used by the program is known to have very high sensitivity. Which of the following inferences is most appropriate when interpreting an individual’s test result?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) If the disease is common in the population and the test is positive, the patient must have the disease

 

  • Sensitivity = probability that the test is positive given disease (true-positive rate). A highly sensitive screening test has few false negatives.
  • Whether a positive result indicates true disease depends on the positive predictive value (PPV), which rises as prevalence increases (Bayes’ theorem).
  • Therefore, when the disease is prevalent and the test is positive, the person is more likely to truly have the disease—but a screening positive must always be followed by a confirmatory diagnostic test (standard screening principle; Ref. Park 27/e p155).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. If the test is positive, the patient definitely has the disease: Overstated. A positive result’s certainty depends mainly on specificity and prevalence; screening tests can yield false positives.

 

Option B. If the test is negative, the patient is very unlikely to have the disease: Too absolute. High sensitivity makes a negative result reassuring (few false negatives), but it is not 100%.

 

Option D. If the disease is rare in the population and the test is positive, the patient is likely to have the disease: Backwards. When prevalence is low, PPV is low; many positives are false positives.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For a highly sensitive screening test, a negative result helps rule out disease (“SnNout”). 
  • For a positive result, the chance it is a true positive (PPV) is higher when prevalence is higher; all positive screens require confirmatory diagnostic testing.

choices.text: Transmission occurs mainly by direct skin penetration of the foot; oral transmission can also occur
Heavy infection is associated with iron-deficiency anemia and hypoalbuminemia
Hookworm infection is known as miners’ anemia and Egyptian chlorosis
Hookworm problem is assessed by Chandler’s Index assesses per gram of stool of individual case

questions.text: Which of the following statements about hookworm disease is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hookworm problem is assessed by Chandler’s Index assesses per gram of stool of individual case

 

  • Chandler’s Index is used to assess the community burden of hookworm infection, not the parasite load of an individual case. It is calculated as:
  • Chandler’s Index = % positivity × average eggs per gram of stool in a community sample
  • This provides a measure of community-level endemicity rather than an individual’s stool count. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transmission occurs mainly by direct skin penetration of the foot; oral transmission can also occur: Correct. Hookworm larvae in contaminated soil penetrate skin (commonly the feet) to cause infection. Oral transmission is rare but possible with Ancylostoma duodenale.

 

Option B. Heavy infection is associated with iron-deficiency anemia and hypoalbuminemia: Correct. Hookworms feed on intestinal blood; chronic heavy infections cause iron-deficiency anemia, hypoalbuminemia, growth retardation, and edema.

 

Option C. Hookworm infection is known as miners’ anemia and Egyptian chlorosis: Correct. Historically, hookworm was prevalent among miners and Egyptians, leading to the colloquial terms “miners’ anemia” and “Egyptian chlorosis.”

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chandler’s Index measures the community-level prevalence and intensity of hookworm infection—not individual stool counts. Hookworm infection primarily spreads via skin penetration and is a major cause of iron-deficiency anemia in endemic regions.

choices.text: The pathology is often seen in middle age
Females are affected five times more
Its rate of growth is very fast
The pathology may compress the jugular vein

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a sudden episode of bleeding from the right ear. An ENT specialist packs the ear and, upon removal of the pack, finds an aural polyp. She reports pulsatile tinnitus in the same ear for the past 2 years and a change in voice for the last 2 months. On laryngeal examination, the right vocal cord is found paralyzed in the abducted position, but there is no cervical lymphadenopathy. Which of the following statements about the underlying pathology is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Its rate of growth is very fast

 

  • The clinical picture is classic for a glomus jugulotympanicum (paraganglioma) — a benign, slow-growing, highly vascular tumor arising from paraganglionic cells associated with the jugular bulb and middle ear.

 

Key Clinical Features:

 

  • Pulsatile tinnitus — due to vascular nature of the tumor (“tumor blush” on otoscopy).
  • Aural polyp / red mass behind tympanic membrane — may bleed on touch.
  • Otorhagia — due to erosion of surrounding bone and vessels.
  • Lower cranial nerve palsies (IX, X, XI) — as tumor expands at the jugular foramen, leading to vocal cord paralysis (recurrent laryngeal nerve involvement).
  • May extend to involve facial nerve or cause jugular bulb compression.

 

Pathophysiology:

 

  • Origin: From chief cells of paraganglia in the adventitia of the jugular bulb (glomus jugulare) or middle ear (glomus tympanicum).
  • Nature: Benign and slow-growing, but locally aggressive; may erode bone and invade nearby structures.
  • Epidemiology: Predominantly in middle-aged women (female:male ratio ≈ 5:1).
  • Growth rate: Very slow; may progress over several years before causing symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The pathology is often seen in middle age: True. Commonly affects adults between 30–60 years.

 

Option B. Females are affected five times more: True. Strong female preponderance (~5:1).

 

Option D. The pathology may compress the jugular vein: True. Jugular bulb is often eroded or compressed (seen radiologically).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Glomus jugulotympanicum is a benign, slow-growing vascular paraganglioma of the middle ear and jugular bulb, typically affecting middle-aged females and presenting with pulsatile tinnitus, aural bleeding, and lower cranial nerve palsies.
  • Its growth is slow, not rapid — distinguishing it from malignant lesions.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman with multiple sclerosis presents with complaints of diplopia. On examination, she cannot adduct her left eye when looking to the right, but the right eye abducts with nystagmus towards end gaze. Her pupils are equal and reactive. Which of the following neural pathways is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Left medial longitudinal fasciculus

 

  • This patient has classic features of internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO) — a hallmark of multiple sclerosis in young adults. 
  • INO results from a lesion in the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF), a fiber tract that connects the abducens nucleus of one side to the contralateral oculomotor nucleus, coordinating horizontal conjugate gaze.

 

In this case:

 

  • When looking right, the right abducens nerve functions normally, causing abduction of the right eye.
  • The left eye, however, fails to adduct because the left MLF is damaged and does not transmit the signal from the right abducens nucleus to the left oculomotor nucleus.
  • Nystagmus in the abducting eye (right) is often seen due to overcorrection as the system tries to maintain conjugate gaze.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left abducens nerve: Would result in impaired abduction of the left eye, not adduction. In this case, adduction is impaired.

 

Option C. Right oculomotor nerve: A lesion here would affect right eye adduction, not the left. Also, there would likely be ptosis and pupil dilation, which are not present.

 

Option D. Left vestibular nucleus: Involved in the vestibulo-ocular reflex, not voluntary conjugate gaze. Lesions here would affect reflexive eye movements but not produce the pattern described in this vignette.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO) is caused by a lesion of the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF), resulting in impaired adduction of the ipsilateral eye and nystagmus of the contralateral abducting eye during conjugate gaze. 
  • It is commonly seen in multiple sclerosis.

questions.text: A leukemia patient on high-dose methotrexate develops nephrotoxicity with dangerously elevated plasma drug levels. Which of the following agents is specifically indicated to rapidly degrade circulating methotrexate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glucarpidase

 

  • Glucarpidase is a recombinant enzyme (carboxypeptidase G2) that rapidly hydrolyzes methotrexate into its inactive metabolites: DAMPA (4-deoxy-4-amino-N10-methylpteroic acid) and glutamate. 
  • It is especially indicated in patients receiving high-dose methotrexate who develop renal dysfunction, leading to impaired methotrexate clearance. Because methotrexate is primarily renally excreted, any reduction in glomerular filtration significantly increases plasma drug levels, worsening toxicity (e.g., mucositis, myelosuppression, neurotoxicity).
  • Glucarpidase acts independently of renal clearance and provides rapid plasma methotrexate reduction, even when standard therapies (leucovorin, hydration, urine alkalinization) fail.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Leucovorin: Leucovorin (folinic acid) is a rescue therapy that supplies reduced folates to normal cells, bypassing the inhibition of dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR) by methotrexate. However, it does not lower methotrexate levels, and its protective effect is time-limited and insufficient in cases of renal failure.

 

Option C. Sodium bicarbonate: Used to alkalinize the urine, sodium bicarbonate helps prevent methotrexate crystallization in renal tubules. It is preventive, not curative. In established renal failure with elevated methotrexate levels, it is insufficient to reverse toxicity.

 

Option D. Allopurinol: This is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor used to prevent tumor lysis syndrome by reducing uric acid formation. It has no effect on methotrexate levels and plays no role in methotrexate-induced nephrotoxicity or its treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In patients with high-dose methotrexate toxicity and renal dysfunction, glucarpidase is the treatment of choice to rapidly degrade methotrexate and reduce plasma levels. 
  • Leucovorin protects normal cells but does not eliminate the drug.
  • Supportive measures (hydration, alkalinization) are useful but inadequate once clearance is compromised.
  • Always consider glucarpidase when methotrexate toxicity persists despite standard rescue measures.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man from a rural area presents with fever, rash, and a necrotic eschar. His initial serology includes a positive Weil-Felix test showing high titers against Proteus OXK. Regarding the diagnostic features of rickettsial diseases, which of the following statements is/are accurate? 

 

  1. Scrub typhus is associated with positive OXK agglutination, while epidemic typhus shows high OX19 titers.
  2. Weil-Felix test is typically positive in Q fever and ehrlichiosis due to shared lipopolysaccharide antigens.
  3. Direct immunofluorescence from skin biopsy offers high sensitivity during early rash phase.
  4. Indirect immunofluorescence assay (IFA) is the gold standard for confirming most rickettsial infections.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1 and 4 only

 

Statement 1. Scrub typhus is associated with positive OXK agglutination, while epidemic typhus shows high OX19 titers: True.

 

  • Scrub typhus = positive OXK titer
  • Epidemic typhus (R. prowazekii) = positive OX19
  • These are hallmark differentiating serologic markers in Weil-Felix test.

 

Statement 4. Indirect immunofluorescence assay (IFA) is the gold standard for confirming most rickettsial infections: True.

 

  • IFA (Indirect immunofluorescence assay) is the most sensitive and specific test.
  • A titer of ≥1:64 is diagnostic. Used to confirm the diagnosis after Weil-Felix screening.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 2. Weil-Felix test is typically positive in Q fever and ehrlichiosis due to shared lipopolysaccharide antigens: False.

 

  • Q fever (Coxiella burnetii) and ehrlichiosis do not show Weil-Felix positivity.
  • These organisms lack cross-reactive Proteus antigens, making Weil-Felix unreliable.

 

Statement 3. Direct immunofluorescence from skin biopsy offers high sensitivity during early rash phase: False.

 

  • Direct immunofluorescence from rash biopsies can be used, but it is not very sensitive, especially in early disease.
  • Its utility is less than PCR or IFA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Weil-Felix Test helps preliminarily differentiate rickettsial infections based on cross-reactivity with OX19, OX2, and OXK antigens, but must be confirmed with IFA, the gold standard for antibody detection. 
  • Q fever and ehrlichiosis are not detected by Weil-Felix.

choices.text: Type II, Type III, and Type I

questions.text: A researcher is developing a drug that blocks complement activation. For which type(s) of hypersensitivity would this agent likely reduce tissue injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Type II and Type III

 

  • Both Type II (antibody-mediated cytotoxic) and Type III (immune complex-mediated) hypersensitivity reactions prominently involve complement activation as part of their effector mechanisms.
  • Type II reactions involve antibodies (mostly IgG/IgM) binding to antigens on host cells, leading to:
    • Complement-mediated lysis
    • Opsonization and phagocytosis
    • Antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC)
  • Type III reactions involve circulating immune complexes (Ag–Ab) that deposit in tissues (e.g., glomeruli, vessels), triggering complement activation → inflammation and recruitment of neutrophils → tissue damage.
  • By inhibiting complement, this drug would blunt both:
    • Cytolytic effects in Type II
    • Inflammatory cascade in Type III

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type I only: Incorrect. Type I hypersensitivity (e.g., anaphylaxis, asthma) is IgE-mediated, involving mast cell degranulation and histamine release. Complement is not involved, so this drug would have no effect.

 

Option C. Type III and Type IV: Incorrect. While Type III is complement-mediated, Type IV hypersensitivity is T-cell mediated, involving delayed-type responses like macrophage activation and cytokine release (e.g., in contact dermatitis, TB). Complement does not play a role.

 

Option D. Type II, Type III, and Type I: Incorrect. Although Type II and III are complement-mediated, Type I is not, so inclusion of Type I here is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Complement activation plays a pivotal role in the pathogenesis of Type II and III hypersensitivity reactions through immune-mediated cytotoxicity and inflammation. 
  • In contrast, Type I (IgE-mast cell) and Type IV (T-cell mediated) hypersensitivities operate via complement-independent pathways.
  • Therapeutic strategies targeting complement would therefore selectively benefit disorders in which complement contributes directly to tissue damage.

questions.text: According to 8th AJCC classification of colorectal cancers, tumor deposits in the visceral peritoneum and serosal breach are staged as?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) T4a

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

According to the 8th AJCC (American Joint Committee on Cancer) TNM Classification for colorectal carcinoma, T4a lesions are those in which the tumor penetrates the visceral peritoneum, leading to serosal breach or direct exposure of the tumor on the peritoneal surface.

questions.text:
Arrange the sequence of events occurring after the P wave in an ECG: 

 

  1. a wave in JVP
  2. First heart sound
  3. Rapid filling of ventricles
  4. T wave in ECG
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-2-4-3

 

  • The P wave on an ECG represents atrial depolarization, which leads to atrial contraction. 
  • After the P wave, the following sequence of events occurs in a specific order:

 

1. a wave in JVP: The a wave in the jugular venous pressure (JVP) is caused by atrial contraction, which immediately follows the P wave on the ECG. This event represents the mechanical contraction of the atria after depolarization.

 

2. First heart sound (S1): The first heart sound (S1) is heard when the atrioventricular valves (tricuspid and mitral valves) close at the beginning of ventricular contraction (systole). This follows the a wave and is a key indicator of the start of the isovolumetric contraction phase.

 

4. T wave in ECG: The T wave represents ventricular repolarization, which leads to ventricular relaxation. This is an electrical event that occurs before the mechanical relaxation of the ventricles. Repolarization precedes the mechanical relaxation process, allowing the ventricles to begin filling.

 

3. Rapid filling of ventricles: After repolarization (T wave), the ventricles undergo rapid filling during the early phase of diastole as the atrioventricular valves reopen. This mechanical event occurs after the electrical repolarization (T wave).

 

 

Sequence breakdown:

 

  • P wave triggers atrial contraction, which is reflected as the a wave in the JVP.
  • The first heart sound (S1) occurs as the AV valves close due to increased ventricular pressure.
  • The T wave marks ventricular repolarization, signaling the beginning of relaxation.
  • Finally, the rapid filling of ventricles happens after relaxation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The correct sequence following the P wave involves:

 

1. Atrial contraction (a wave in JVP),

2. First heart sound (AV valve closure),

4. T wave (ventricular repolarization),

3. Rapid ventricular filling.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with chronic pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea, and deep dyspareunia. Pelvic ultrasound shows a 4 cm cystic lesion in the left ovary with homogeneous "ground-glass" echogenicity, consistent with an ovarian endometrioma. She expresses a strong desire to conceive in the near future. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Laparoscopic cystectomy

 

  • An endometrioma (also called a “chocolate cyst”) is a localized form of endometriosis, commonly found on the ovaries. It contains old, altered blood from ectopic endometrial glands and stroma.
  • In women who desire fertility, the most appropriate management is laparoscopic cystectomy, which involves surgical excision of the endometriotic cyst wall while preserving healthy ovarian tissue.

 

Rationale:

 

  • Medical therapy (OCPs or GnRH analogs) suppresses ovulation and prevents pregnancy, making it inappropriate for women seeking fertility.
  • Laparoscopic cystectomy relieves pain, restores normal ovarian anatomy, and improves fertility outcomes by removing ectopic endometrial tissue that interferes with ovulation and fertilization.
  • Surgical excision also reduces recurrence risk and provides tissue for histopathologic confirmation.

 

Key advantages of laparoscopic cystectomy:

 

  • Alleviates dysmenorrhea and dyspareunia
  • Enhances spontaneous conception rates
  • Decreases recurrence of endometrioma compared to drainage alone

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. GnRH analogs for 6 months: These suppress ovarian estrogen production, inducing a hypoestrogenic (pseudomenopausal) state that temporarily alleviates pain. However, ovulation suppression prevents conception and recurrence occurs once therapy stops. Thus, it is not suitable for women desiring fertility.

 

Option C. Continuous oral contraceptive pills: OCPs reduce menstrual flow and endometrial proliferation, which helps control symptoms and prevent recurrence. However, they inhibit ovulation and therefore are used in women not desiring pregnancy, not in those seeking fertility.

 

Option D. Total hysterectomy with oophorectomy: This is reserved for women with severe disease who have completed childbearing or for those unresponsive to conservative management. It eliminates fertility permanently, making it inappropriate for this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a woman with ovarian endometrioma who desires fertility, the next best step is laparoscopic cystectomy, which removes the cyst wall, relieves pain, and improves fertility outcomes while preserving ovarian function.

choices.text: Granulomatous inflammation with multinucleated giant cells
Follicular hyperplasia with scalloping of colloid
Follicular atrophy with extensive Hurthle cell metaplasia

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with weight loss, heat intolerance, palpitations, and tremors. On examination, she has a diffuse, non-tender goiter and a fine tremor of her hands. Laboratory findings reveal elevated free T₄ and suppressed TSH. Thyroid biopsy of this patient is shown below. Which of the following best describes the underlying pathologic finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Follicular hyperplasia with scalloping of colloid

 

  • The classic features of Graves disease, an autoimmune hyperthyroid state caused by TSH receptor–stimulating IgG antibodies.
  • Histologic hallmarks of Graves disease:
    • Follicular epithelial hyperplasia (tall, crowded epithelial cells forming papillary infoldings).
    • Scalloped colloid, reflecting active reabsorption of thyroglobulin.
    • Absence of lymphoid destruction (unlike Hashimoto thyroiditis).
  • These features explain the diffuse goiter and hypermetabolic symptoms seen in this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Granulomatous inflammation with multinucleated giant cells: Seen in subacute (de Quervain) thyroiditis, often following viral infection, presenting with a painful, tender thyroid.

 

Option C. Follicular atrophy with extensive Hurthle cell metaplasia: Characteristic of Hashimoto thyroiditis, which presents with hypothyroidism and anti-TPO antibodies.

 

Option D. Amyloid deposition in thyroid stroma: Seen in medullary thyroid carcinoma, derived from parafollicular (C) cells, producing calcitonin that deposits as amyloid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Graves disease shows follicular hyperplasia with scalloping of colloid due to TSH receptor–stimulating antibodies, resulting in diffuse thyroid hyperactivity and thyrotoxicosis.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with vomiting, failure to thrive, and a cabbage-like odor to the urine. Laboratory evaluation reveals severe liver dysfunction, renal tubular damage, and elevated succinylacetone levels in the blood. Which of the following enzyme deficiencies is the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase

 

  • Tyrosinemia type I (also called hepatorenal tyrosinemia) is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a deficiency of fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase (FAH), the final enzyme in the tyrosine degradation pathway.
  • Normally, tyrosine is degraded to fumarate and acetoacetate via several steps.
  • When FAH is deficient, its substrate fumarylacetoacetate and its toxic by-product succinylacetone accumulate.
  • These metabolites cause progressive hepatic failure, renal Fanconi-like syndrome, and neurologic crises due to inhibition of heme synthesis enzymes (ALA dehydratase).
  • Clinical features:
    • Failure to thrive, vomiting, jaundice, and hepatomegaly
    • Renal tubular dysfunction → aminoaciduria, rickets
    • Cabbage-like odor of urine (due to sulfur-containing compounds)
    • Elevated tyrosine, methionine, and succinylacetone levels in plasma
  • Early treatment with nitisinone (NTBC), which inhibits an upstream enzyme (4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase), prevents accumulation of toxic intermediates.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Homogentisate oxidase: Deficiency causes alkaptonuria, characterized by dark urine, ochronosis, and degenerative arthritis, not liver failure.

 

Option C. Tyrosine transaminase: Deficiency leads to Tyrosinemia type II (Richner–Hanhart syndrome) with keratitis, skin lesions, and intellectual disability, but no hepatic or renal involvement.

 

Option D. Maleyl-acetate isomerase: Deficiency is not associated with classic tyrosinemia type I; this enzyme acts upstream of FAH, and its block does not lead to succinylacetone accumulation or hepatic necrosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tyrosinemia type I results from fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase deficiency, causing accumulation of fumarylacetoacetate and succinylacetone, leading to severe hepatic and renal dysfunction.

questions.text: At which gestational age is this feeding method typically initiated in stable preterm infants?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 32-34 weeks

 

  • The progression of feeding methods in preterm infants follows a developmental sequence based on the maturation of feeding skills. 
  • At 32-34 weeks gestational age, infants typically develop adequate coordination to handle paladai spoon feeding. 
  • This specialized feeding method serves as an important transitional step between nasogastric tube feeding and direct breastfeeding. 
  • The paladai is particularly valuable because it allows controlled delivery of milk while requiring less energy expenditure from the infant compared to full breastfeeding.

 

Table Decision tool: initiation and advancement of preterm infant feeding 

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The progression of feeding methods in preterm infants follows a developmental sequence: IV fluids (<28 weeks), nasogastric/orogastric feeding (28-32 weeks), paladai feeding (32-34 weeks), and direct breastfeeding (>34 weeks). 
  • The paladai spoon offers several advantages, including controlled flow, reduced energy expenditure, safer feeding compared to bottles, and a helpful transition to breastfeeding

choices.text: Total ₹4000: ₹3,000 to the acceptor, ₹400 to ASHA/health worker, ₹600 to “others” (facility/provider)
Total ₹4500: ₹2,000 to the acceptor, ₹300 to ASHA/health worker, ₹2200 to “others”
Total ₹5000: ₹3000 to the acceptor, ₹400 to ASHA/health worker, ₹1600 to “others”
Total ₹4000: ₹1400 to the acceptor, ₹400 to ASHA/health worker, ₹2200 to “others”

questions.text: A 28-year-old multiparous woman delivers vaginally in a Mission Parivar Vikas (MPV) district and opts for post-partum tubectomy (PPS) before discharge. The facility wants to process incentives under the RCH Sterilization Incentive Package. Which of the following correctly states the total incentive and its breakup for PPS in MPV districts?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Total ₹4000: ₹3,000 to the acceptor, ₹400 to ASHA/health worker, ₹600 to “others” (facility/provider)

 

  • Under the Sterilization Incentive Package (RCH Program), Mission Parivar Vikas (MPV) districts receive enhanced incentives to accelerate fertility regulation. 
  • For post-partum sterilization (PPS), the table shows:
    • Acceptor: ₹3,000
    • ASHA/health worker: ₹400
    • Others (facility/provider/operating team as per program norms): ₹600
    • Total: ₹4,000
  • This higher payout reflects programmatic prioritization of immediate postpartum contraception in high-focus MPV districts.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her family because of severe palpitations, sweating, and shortness of breath for the past few hours. She has a 3-month history of heat intolerance, irritability, tremulousness, and weight loss despite an increased appetite. Physical examination is shown in below mentioned image. She appears agitated and restless. On examination, her pulse is 160/min, regular, and BP is 150/60 mmHg. ECG shows sinus tachycardia. Which among the following is the most immediate life-saving drug for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Propranolol

 

  • The patient is presenting with clinical features of thyroid storm, a life-threatening exacerbation of hyperthyroidism. 
  • The signs of exophthalmos and a diffuse goiter suggest Graves' disease as the underlying cause. 
  • In a thyroid storm, propranolol is the drug of choice for immediate symptomatic control as it reduces tachycardia, palpitations, and tremors by blocking β-adrenergic receptors. 
  • Additionally, propranolol partially inhibits peripheral conversion of T4 to T3, further decreasing circulating levels of the more active thyroid hormone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carbimazole: This antithyroid drug inhibits thyroid hormone synthesis. However, it takes days to weeks to show its effect and is not useful for immediate symptomatic relief during a thyroid storm.

 

Option B. Radioactive iodine: This therapy is used for definitive treatment of hyperthyroidism but is contraindicated in thyroid storm as it can worsen symptoms in the acute phase.

 

Option D. Liothyronine: This is a synthetic T3 hormone and is used in the treatment of hypothyroidism. It would exacerbate hyperthyroid symptoms and is inappropriate in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Propranolol is the most immediate life-saving drug in thyroid storm as it rapidly controls adrenergic symptoms and inhibits peripheral conversion of T4 to T3. 
  • Other therapies, including carbimazole or propylthiouracil, and supportive measures are initiated alongside propranolol to stabilize the patient.

choices.text: Reapply the same patch and continue the current cycle
Apply a new patch and continue the same cycle without backup contraception
Stop the current cycle, apply a new patch immediately, and use backup contraception for 7 days
Wait until the next menstrual period to start a new patch

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman using a transdermal contraceptive patch reports that her patch became partially detached, and she realized it had been off for more than 24 hours. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Stop the current cycle, apply a new patch immediately, and use backup contraception for 7 days

 

  • If a contraceptive patch (such as ethinyl estradiol/norelgestromin) becomes partially or completely detached for more than 24 hours, contraceptive hormone levels may fall below effective levels, increasing the risk of ovulation and unintended pregnancy.
  • Management steps:
    1. Stop the current cycle.
    2. Apply a new patch immediately — this starts a new 4-week cycle.
    3. Use backup contraception (e.g., condoms) for the first 7 days of the new cycle to ensure contraceptive protection while hormone levels stabilize.
  • If the patch had been detached for less than 24 hours, it could be reapplied (or replaced with a new one) and the cycle continued without backup contraception.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reapply the same patch and continue the current cycle: Incorrect if detachment >24 hours — hormone levels may have dropped too low for reliable contraception.

 

Option B. Apply a new patch and continue the same cycle without backup contraception: Unsafe, as ovulation may occur if the patch was off >24 hours; backup contraception is required.

 

Option D. Wait until the next menstrual period to start a new patch: Unnecessary delay — ovulation could occur during this time, increasing pregnancy risk. Immediate reapplication and new cycle initiation are recommended.

 

Educational Objective:

 

If a contraceptive patch is detached for more than 24 hours, start a new cycle immediately with a new patch and use backup contraception for 7 days to maintain pregnancy prevention.

choices.text: Using palm on the lower third of sternum
Using two fingers on the middle third of sternum
Using the two thumbs on the lower third of sternum
Using three fingers on the lower third of sternum

questions.text: A term newborn suddenly develops apnea and bradycardia in the delivery room. The team initiates resuscitation, and chest compressions are required. Which technique is considered the most effective for delivering compressions in neonates?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Using the two thumbs on the lower third of sternum

 

  • The two-thumb encircling technique is the preferred method for chest compressions in neonates. 
  • Both thumbs are placed on the lower third of the sternum while the fingers encircle and support the infant’s back. 
  • This method generates higher coronary perfusion pressure and is less tiring for the rescuer, making it the most effective approach.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Using palm on the lower third of sternum: This is incorrect because the palm technique is used in adult CPR, not in neonates. Applying a palm on a newborn’s sternum would exert excessive force and risk rib or sternal injury.

 

Option B. Using two fingers on the middle third of sternum: The two-finger technique can be used when a single rescuer is providing compressions, but it is less effective than the two-thumb technique. Also, compressions must be placed on the lower third, not the middle third, to avoid injury to the upper sternum.

 

Option D. Using three fingers on the lower third of sternum: Using three fingers is not a standard technique in neonatal resuscitation. It increases the chance of excessive pressure and instability compared to the recommended two-finger or two-thumb method.

 

Educational Objective:


In neonatal resuscitation, chest compressions should be performed on the lower third of the sternum, with the two-thumb encircling technique being the most effective and recommended method.

choices.text: Twin A has a Silverman Anderson score of 2 and requires observation, while Twin B has a score of 9 and requires intubation
Twin A has a Silverman Anderson score of 3 and requires observation, while Twin B has a score of 5 and requires CPAP
Twin A has a Silverman Anderson score of 1 and requires oxygen by nasal cannula, while Twin B has a score of 8 and requires intubation
Twin A has a Silverman Anderson score of 2 and requires observation, while Twin B has a score of 6 and requires CPAP

questions.text: You are called to evaluate two preterm twins, both born at 28 weeks gestation. Twin A shows the following: synchronous chest and abdominal movement during respiration, barely visible lower chest retractions, no xiphoid retraction, slight nasal flaring, and no expiratory grunt. Twin B exhibits see-saw breathing, marked lower chest retractions, just visible xiphoid retraction, marked nasal flaring, and expiratory grunt audible without a stethoscope. Which of the following statements is correct regarding these twins?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Twin A has a Silverman Anderson score of 2 and requires observation, while Twin B has a score of 9 and requires intubation

 

Step-by-Step Calculation of Silverman-Anderson Scores:

 

Twin A:

 

  • Chest-Abdomen Synchrony: Synchronous → 0
  • Lower Chest Retraction: Barely visible → 1
  • Xiphoid Retraction: None → 0
  • Nasal Flaring: Slight → 1
  • Expiratory Grunt: None → 0

 

Total Score for Twin A = 0 + 1 + 0 + 1 + 0 = 2

 

Management: Score ≤ 2 indicates mild respiratory distress → Observation 

 

Twin B:

 

  • Chest-Abdomen Synchrony: See-saw breathing → 2
  • Lower Chest Retraction: Marked → 2
  • Xiphoid Retraction: Just visible → 1
  • Nasal Flaring: Marked → 2
  • Expiratory Grunt: Audible without a stethoscope → 2

 

Total Score for Twin B = 2 + 2 + 1 + 2 + 2 = 9

 

Management: Score ≥ 7 indicates severe respiratory distress → Requires Intubation. 

 

This answer accurately reflects the calculated scores and appropriate interventions based on neonatal respiratory distress severity.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A man is brought to the emergency after a fall-stride injury. He feels the urge to micturate but is unable to pass urine and there is blood at the tip of the meatus with extensive swelling of the perineal region and penis and scrotum. What is the location of the injury and the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bulbar urethra, ascending urethrogram

 

  • The bulbar urethra is the most commonly injured part of the urethra in cases of fall astride injury (perineal trauma). 
  • Rupture of the bulbar urethra results in extravasation of urine and blood into the superficial perineal space, leading to swelling of the perineum, scrotum, and penis. 
  • The presence of blood at the meatus and the inability to void are key diagnostic clues.
  • The next step is ascending urethrography to confirm the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bulbar urethra, micturating cystogram: A micturating cystourethrogram (MCU) is performed only after ensuring urethral continuity, typically during follow-up after catheterization or repair. It is not used here, because of urethral injury, contrast injection through the bladder may worsen extravasation or obscure the site of injury.

 

Options C and D. Prostatic urethra, suprapubic cystostomy and Prostatic urethra, ascending cysto-urethrogram: Injuries to the prostatic urethra are typically associated with pelvic fractures. They may cause high-riding prostate and per rectal findings, which are not observed in this patient.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Blunt trauma to the perineum with blood at the urethral meatus, inability to void, and swelling of the perineum, scrotum, and penis is highly suggestive of a bulbar urethral injury. 
  • Prompt diagnosis and management, including urethrography for confirmation, are essential to prevent complications.

choices.text: The enzyme deficient is phenylalanine hydroxylase
Tyrosine becomes an essential amino acid
The condition can lead to mental retardation if untreated

questions.text: An infant presented to the OPD with a history of vomiting and poor feeding. A musty (mousy) odor is noted in the baby’s sweat and urine. Guthrie test was found to be positive. All of the following statements regarding this disease are true except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dietary phenylalanine should be stopped

 

  • The infant’s presentation — vomiting, poor feeding, musty odor of sweat/urine, and a positive Guthrie test — is classic for Phenylketonuria (PKU).
  • Dietary phenylalanine should be stopped – FALSE
    Phenylalanine is an essential amino acid — it cannot be completely eliminated, only restricted to safe levels.
  • A low-phenylalanine diet with adequate protein and tyrosine supplementation is required.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The enzyme deficient is phenylalanine hydroxylase: True. PKU is caused by deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase, which normally converts phenylalanine → tyrosine.

 

Option B. Tyrosine becomes an essential amino acid: True. Because tyrosine synthesis is impaired, it must be supplied through diet.

 

Option C. The condition can lead to mental retardation if untreated: True. Accumulated phenylalanine is neurotoxic, causing intellectual disability, seizures, and developmental delay.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Phenylketonuria (PKU), phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency leads to phenylalanine accumulation; dietary phenylalanine should be restricted, not stopped, and tyrosine becomes essential.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman with a history of infertility undergoes diagnostic laparoscopy. Intraoperatively, the ovary is found and shown below. The surrounding peritoneum shows areas of fibrosis and adhesions. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Endometriotic cyst 

 

  • The image shown is consistent with Endometrioma. 
  • An endometriotic cyst or ovarian endometrioma is a type of ovarian cyst associated with endometriosis, characterized by the accumulation of old, altered blood within the cyst cavity, giving it a “chocolate-colored” appearance on rupture.

 

Pathogenesis:

 

  • Endometriosis occurs due to ectopic implantation of endometrial tissue on the ovary and other pelvic structures.
  • With each menstrual cycle, the ectopic tissue bleeds, leading to the collection of degraded hemoglobin and hemosiderin-laden macrophages—forming the “chocolate cyst.”

 

Typical features:

 

  • Symptoms: Dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, chronic pelvic pain, infertility
  • Laparoscopic findings:
    • “Powder-burn” lesions (bluish-black deposits on peritoneum)
    • Dense adhesions between pelvic organs
    • Ovarian cysts with dark, thick, tar-like fluid
  • Relevance in this case: The described cyst that ruptured releasing thick, chocolate-like material is classic for endometriosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serous cystadenoma: A benign epithelial ovarian tumor filled with clear, straw-colored fluid. It does not contain old blood or cause adhesions typical of endometriosis.

 

Option B. Corpus luteum cyst: Formed from a persisting corpus luteum, often containing yellow or blood-tinged fluid. These cysts usually resolve spontaneously and are not associated with infertility or chronic pelvic adhesions.

 

Option D. Theca lutein cyst: Typically, bilateral and associated with high β-hCG states (e.g., molar pregnancy, multiple gestation). They contain clear or straw-colored fluid, not chocolate-colored material.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A “chocolate cyst” seen during laparoscopy—containing thick, tarry, altered blood—is characteristic of an ovarian endometrioma, a manifestation of endometriosis, which is a leading cause of infertility and chronic pelvic pain in women of reproductive age.

questions.text:
Regarding the pathological features of Keloid formation, which of the following statements are correct? 

 

  1. Keloids are characterized by excessive deposition of collagen that extends beyond the boundaries of the original wound.
  2. They commonly regress spontaneously over time.
  3. Keloids are more frequent among individuals of African descent and may have a genetic predisposition.
  4. The collagen arrangement within keloids is haphazardly organized.
  5. Keloids are most frequently found in skin overlying the sternum and upper back.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 3, 4 and 5 are correct

 

  • Keloids are an abnormal wound healing response characterized by excessive collagen deposition (mainly type III collagen) that extends beyond the boundaries of the original wound. 
  • Unlike hypertrophic scars, keloids do not regress and often recur after excision.

 

Key pathological features:

 

 

Statement 1. Keloids are characterized by excessive deposition of collagen that extends beyond the boundaries of the original wound: Extension beyond wound boundaries — distinguishes keloids from hypertrophic scars.

 

Statement 3. Keloids are more frequent among individuals of African descent and may have a genetic predisposition:  Genetic predisposition — higher incidence in individuals of African, Hispanic, and Asian descent.

 

Statement 4. The collagen arrangement within keloids is haphazardly organized: Haphazard collagen arrangement — collagen bundles are thick, irregular, and disorganized.

 

Statement 5. Keloids are most frequently found in skin overlying the sternum and upper back: Common sites— presternal region, shoulders, upper back, and earlobes.

 

No spontaneous regression — often persist and may enlarge over time.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 2. They commonly regress spontaneously over time: Incorrect. Keloids do not regress spontaneously; they may continue to enlarge even after healing, unlike hypertrophic scars, which may regress.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Keloids are characterized by overgrowth of disorganized collagen that extends beyond the wound margin, show no spontaneous regression, and have a predilection for Africans and areas like the sternum and shoulders.

choices.text: Elevated eosinophils in the CSF with cloudy appearance
Motile trophozoites on wet mount preparation of fresh CSF
Growth on Sabouraud agar with fuzzy colonies
PCR detection of cyst wall gene markers in serum

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with high-grade fever, severe headache, nausea, and altered mental status. His symptoms began two days after swimming in a local freshwater lake. Which of the following findings would most reliably support a diagnosis of primary amoebic meningoencephalitis (PAM) caused by Naegleria fowleri?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Motile trophozoites on wet mount preparation of fresh CSF

 

  • Motile trophozoites seen on immediate wet mount microscopy of freshly collected CSF is the most reliable early diagnostic clue for Naegleria fowleri infection.
  • These trophozoites exhibit lobopodial, directional movement and can be visualized under phase-contrast microscopy.
  • Delayed examination reduces the chance of detecting motility, making rapid processing crucial.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Elevated eosinophils in the CSF with cloudy appearance: Eosinophilic pleocytosis is more typical of helminthic CNS infections (e.g., Angiostrongylus), not amoebic meningoencephalitis.

 

Option C. Growth on Sabouraud agar with fuzzy colonies: Sabouraud dextrose agar is selective for fungal organisms, not Naegleria. N. fowleri requires non-nutrient agar with E. coli overlay for culture.

 

Option D. PCR detection of cyst wall gene markers in serum: N. fowleri cysts are not present in human tissue or CSF. PCR targeting trophozoite genes in CSF is useful, but not in serum and not the most immediate or practical test for early diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In suspected Naegleria fowleri infections, especially after recent freshwater exposure and fulminant meningoencephalitis, the most rapid and reliable test is wet mount of fresh CSF showing motile trophozoites. 
  • Early detection is critical, as the disease progresses rapidly and has a high mortality rate without timely treatment.

questions.text: During which of the following procedures is this instrument most commonly used?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tubal ligation

 

  • The instrument shown in the image is Babcock’s forceps. It is a non-toothed, fenestrated, atraumatic grasping instrument used to hold and manipulate delicate tubular structures such as the fallopian tubes, ureters, intestines, and appendix without causing injury.
  • In tubal ligation, it is specifically used to:
    • Gently grasp and elevate the fallopian tube from the mesosalpinx.
    • Allow for ligation or cauterization of the tube for sterilization.
      The smooth, rounded edges and fenestrated jaws ensure minimal tissue trauma during handling.
  • Design features:
    • Fenestrated tip to prevent crushing
    • Curved jaws for gentle grip
    • Used primarily in procedures involving soft tissues or hollow tubes
  • Thus, in gynecologic practice, Babcock’s forceps is most frequently used during tubal ligation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ovarian cystectomy: Involves dissection and excision of an ovarian cyst; Allis forceps or toothed tissue forceps are used instead for firm grip, as the ovary is a solid organ.

 

Option B. Vaginal hysterectomy: Requires instruments such as Heaney clamps, Kocher’s clamps, and Allis forceps for firm tissue handling, not Babcock’s forceps.

 

Option D. Abdominal hysterectomy: Also utilizes Kocher’s, Allis, and Heaney clamps for gripping ligaments and uterine vessels — not suitable for delicate tubular structures like Babcock’s.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Babcock’s forceps is an atraumatic grasping instrument primarily used to hold soft, tubular structures such as the fallopian tubes during tubal ligation, ensuring tissue handling without crushing or injury.

choices.text: Latex agglutination for cryptococcal capsular antigen

questions.text: A 45-year-old renal transplant recipient presents with headache, low-grade fever, and photophobia. Physical exam reveals neck stiffness. A lumbar puncture is performed. CSF analysis shows elevated opening pressure, lymphocytic pleocytosis, and the presence of round budding yeast cells. India ink staining is negative. Which of the following is the most sensitive test to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Latex agglutination for cryptococcal capsular antigen

 

  • Latex agglutination test detects capsular polysaccharide antigen of Cryptococcus neoformans (and C. gattii) in CSF or serum and has a >95% sensitivity, making it the most sensitive and rapid test, especially when India ink is negative (which occurs in ~30–40% of cases with low fungal burden).
  • This test can even be used before culture results are available.
  • It works even when fungal cells are sparse or immune suppression reduces inflammatory response.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Culture on Sabouraud’s Dextrose Agar:

 

  • While definitive, it takes several days and is less sensitive than antigen detection in early disease.
  • Colony appearance is creamy, mucoid; but not useful for rapid diagnosis in critical cases.

 

Option C. Gram stain of CSF: Shows Gram-positive budding yeast cells, but is low sensitivity and less reliable than antigen detection or India ink.

 

Option D. Nigrosin negative stain: Like India ink, detects capsular halo, but has similar limitations in low fungal burden, hence lower sensitivity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In suspected cryptococcal meningitis, especially in immunocompromised patients (e.g., HIV, transplant), the most sensitive diagnostic test is latex agglutination for capsular antigen detection in CSF or serum.
  • India ink has limited sensitivity, and culture takes time.

questions.text: The ultrasound image shown demonstrates a specialized liver imaging technique that assesses tissue stiffness by measuring shear wave velocity. Which of the following techniques is being depicted?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Elastography

 

  • The provided image shows a liver ultrasound with a colored ROI (region of interest) where quantitative values of tissue stiffness are displayed in kilopascals (kPa). 
  • This corresponds to shear wave elastography, a non-invasive imaging technique that measures tissue elasticity (fibrosis) by calculating the propagation speed of shear waves through the liver parenchyma.
  • Normal liver tissue is more elastic (low stiffness), whereas fibrosis and cirrhosis cause increased stiffness (higher kPa values).
  • Elastography is increasingly used in hepatology as a non-invasive alternative to liver biopsy for staging fibrosis in chronic hepatitis B, hepatitis C, NAFLD, and alcoholic liver disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Doppler ultrasound:

 

  • Doppler evaluates blood flow and velocity within vessels or organs using frequency shifts.
  • It does not measure stiffness or provide kPa values.

 

Option C. Contrast-enhanced ultrasound:

 

  • Uses microbubble contrast agents to evaluate vascular perfusion in real time.
  • Helpful for detecting tumors and differentiating benign vs malignant lesions, but not for fibrosis staging.

 

Option D. CT scan with contrast:

 

  • Provides cross-sectional anatomical imaging with iodine contrast.
  • Useful for tumor detection and vascular anatomy, but it does not quantify liver stiffness or elasticity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ultrasound elastography is a non-invasive tool that measures liver stiffness using shear wave velocity, reported in kilopascals (kPa). 
  • It is widely used in assessing and staging hepatic fibrosis, reducing the need for invasive liver biopsy.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man is being evaluated for liver transplantation due to decompensated cirrhosis. He is found to be C282Y homozygous, and liver biopsy confirms hereditary hemochromatosis. He has several complications: cardiac dysfunction, arthropathy, diabetes, and hypogonadism related to iron overload. Which of the following disease manifestations would not be expected to improve with phlebotomy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Arthropathy and hypogonadism

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In hereditary hemochromatosis, iron removal by phlebotomy can reverse hepatic, cardiac, and endocrine dysfunction if instituted early.
  • However, arthropathy and hypogonadism are typically irreversible complications that do not improve with iron depletion.

questions.text: A severely decomposed body is recovered from a dense forest two weeks after being reported missing. Most of the soft tissues have degraded, and the body is in an advanced state of decomposition. The forensic team is tasked with establishing the identity of the individual using DNA analysis. Which of the following samples is the most appropriate for obtaining DNA in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pulp from molar tooth

 

  • In cases of advanced decomposition, soft tissues like blood, lung epithelium, and even muscle degrade rapidly due to enzymatic autolysis and bacterial putrefaction. 
  • Hard tissues—such as teeth and bones—are resistant to enzymatic breakdown, making them the most reliable source for DNA extraction in such cases.
  • Among teeth, the pulp cavity of molars is particularly well-preserved and protected, offering a concentrated and high-quality source of nuclear DNA even in bodies that are weeks to months old.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clotted blood from femoral vein: Clotted blood is a poor source of DNA in postmortem cases, especially after decomposition sets in. Also, EDTA blood is preferred over clotted blood for preserving DNA.

 

Option B. Muscle tissue from thigh: Muscle tissue may retain some DNA in early decomposition, but in advanced decay, it is significantly degraded and no longer reliable.

 

Option C. Pulmonary epithelial scrapings: Lung tissue and mucosal scrapings are extremely susceptible to autolysis and microbial invasion, making them unreliable in severely decomposed bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In forensic identification of decomposed bodies, teeth (especially molars) and dense bones (like femur) are the preferred sources of DNA, due to their resistance to degradation and ability to preserve nuclear material.

questions.text: In the hand, which lumbrical muscles are unipennate and which are bipennate in their fiber arrangement?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1st & 2nd lumbricals – unipennate; 3rd & 4th lumbricals – bipennate

 

  • The lumbrical muscles of the hand arise from the tendons of the flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) and insert into the extensor expansion on the dorsal aspect of the corresponding fingers.
  • Arrangement:
    • 1st & 2nd lumbricals: Unipennate (arise from the lateral two FDP tendons of index and middle fingers).
    • 3rd & 4th lumbricals: Bipennate (arise from adjacent FDP tendons).
  • Function: They flex the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and extend the interphalangeal (IP) joints, producing the characteristic “writing” or “pen-holding” movement.
  • Innervation:
    • 1st and 2nd → Median nerve
    • 3rd and 4th → Deep branch of ulnar nerve
  • Hence, weakness in the first two lumbricals (as in median nerve palsy) leads to difficulty performing fine finger flexion—matching the scenario described.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lumbrical muscles exhibit distinct fiber patterns:

 

  • 1st & 2nd – Unipennate
  • 3rd & 4th – Bipennate

 

They flex MCP joints and extend IP joints, with dual innervation from the median and ulnar nerves.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with episodes of dark-colored urine and symptoms of fatigue and pallor. Laboratory tests reveal hemolytic anemia and pancytopenia. Flow cytometry of the patient is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH)

 

  • Flow cytometry is the diagnostic test of choice for Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH). 
  • It identifies loss of glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI)-anchored surface proteins, such as:
    • CD55 (decay-accelerating factor)
    • CD59 (membrane inhibitor of reactive lysis)
  • These proteins normally protect red blood cells from complement-mediated lysis.
  • A PIGA gene mutation in hematopoietic stem cells leads to a deficiency of these GPI-linked proteins, resulting in complement activation and intravascular hemolysis, especially at night (due to mild respiratory acidosis during sleep).

 

Key findings:

 

  • Morning hemoglobinuria (dark urine)
  • Pancytopenia (bone marrow involvement)
  • Thrombosis (hepatic, portal, or cerebral veins) — major cause of mortality

 

Flow cytometry interpretation (image):

 

  • Panel A (Normal individual): All cells express CD55 and CD59 (black cluster).
  • Panel B (PNH patient): A subset of cells (red cluster) is deficient in CD55/CD59, confirming PNH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute glomerulonephritis: Characterized by hematuria (intact RBCs in urine), RBC casts, and proteinuria, not free hemoglobin from intravascular lysis.

 

Option C. Alkaptonuria: A metabolic disorder due to homogentisic acid oxidase deficiency leading to homogentisic aciduria, causing black urine on standing, but not related to complement-mediated hemolysis.

 

Option D. Porphyria cutanea tarda: A hepatic porphyria due to uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase deficiency, leading to uroporphyrin accumulation and red-brown urine that fluoresces under UV light, not due to RBC destruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH) is caused by a PIGA gene mutation resulting in loss of GPI-anchored complement regulatory proteins (CD55 and CD59), leading to complement-mediated intravascular hemolysis.
  • Flow cytometry showing absence of CD55/CD59 is diagnostic.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man with a history of massive blood loss due to trauma is receiving multiple transfusions. After several units of packed red blood cells, his coagulation profile shows prolonged PT and aPTT, and fibrinogen levels are markedly decreased. Fresh frozen plasma is unavailable. Which of the following is the best blood product to correct his coagulation abnormalities?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cryoprecipitate

 

  • Cryoprecipitate is a plasma-derived blood product obtained by thawing fresh frozen plasma (FFP) at low temperatures (1–6°C) and collecting the cold-insoluble fraction.
  • It is rich in high–molecular-weight coagulation proteins, specifically:
    • Fibrinogen
      • Factor VIII
      • Factor XIII
      • von Willebrand factor (vWF)

 

Clinical uses of cryoprecipitate:

 

  • Hypofibrinogenemia (e.g., DIC, massive transfusion)
  • Congenital fibrinogen deficiency
  • Factor XIII deficiency
  • von Willebrand disease or Hemophilia A (if specific factor concentrates are unavailable)
  • Mechanism: Cryoprecipitate replaces fibrinogen and clot-stabilizing factors, restoring coagulation cascade integrity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Platelet concentrate: Used in thrombocytopenia or platelet dysfunction, not in coagulation factor deficiency.

 

Option C. Packed red blood cells (PRBCs): Used to correct anemia and improve oxygen delivery, not coagulopathy.

 

Option D. Albumin: Used for volume expansion and hypoalbuminemia, but lacks clotting factors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cryoprecipitate is the blood product of choice for patients with low fibrinogen levels or deficiencies of Factor VIII, XIII, or von Willebrand factor during massive transfusion, DIC, or inherited disorders.

questions.text: A newborn at 1 minute has HR 110 bpm, irregular breathing, some flexion, grimace, and pink body with blue extremities. What is the APGAR score?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 6

 

HR (2) + Respiration (1) + Tone (1) + Reflex (1) + Color (1) = 6, indicating moderate birth asphyxia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • APGAR helps assess transition and need for resuscitation, not long-term outcome.
  • >7 normal, 4–7 moderate, 0–3 severe birth asphyxia.

questions.text: Identify the site of mesh repair done in the image.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Onlay

 

  • Onlay mesh is placed above the muscle layer on the anterior surface of the fascia. 
  • This technique is commonly used in open inguinal hernia repair as shown in the image.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inlay: The mesh is positioned between tissue planes, often within the hernia defect itself. This approach does not provide strong reinforcement and is rarely used in open inguinal hernia repair.

 

Option C. Sublay: The mesh is placed under the muscle layer and above the peritoneum or posterior fascia. This technique, often termed "posterior mesh placement", is commonly used in laparoscopic inguinal hernia repair, providing robust support and tension-free reinforcement.

 

Option D. Intraperitoneal (IPOM): The mesh is placed inside the peritoneal cavity in direct contact with the intestines. This is primarily utilized in laparoscopic ventral hernia repairs rather than open inguinal hernia repair due to risks of adhesions and complications.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Onlay mesh repair is done in open while sublay mesh placement is the preferred technique in lap inguinal hernia repair, ensuring strong reinforcement and minimal recurrence.

choices.text: Ask to speak a sentence → GCS → IV line → Endotracheal intubation
IV line → Endotracheal intubation → GCS → Ask to speak a sentence
Ask to speak a sentence → IV line → Endotracheal intubation → GCS
Ask to speak a sentence → Endotracheal intubation → IV line → GCS

questions.text: Which of the following represents the correct sequence of ATLS primary survey steps?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ask to speak a sentence → Endotracheal intubation → IV line → GCS

 

The ATLS primary survey follows ABCDE:

 

  • Airway with cervical spine protection → Ask to speak a sentence to assess airway patency.
  • Breathing → Endotracheal intubation if needed.
  • Circulation → IV line for fluid resuscitation.
  • Disability → GCS for neurological status.
  • Exposure → Full body check.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ATLS primary survey follows the sequence: Airway, Breathing, Circulation, and Disability (ABCD), ensuring rapid identification and correction of life-threatening conditions in trauma patients.

choices.text: In case of relapse, re-treatment with the same agent is recommended

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with progressive weakness of both lower limbs for 4 days, followed by difficulty in lifting his arms. He had a brief episode of diarrhea 2 weeks ago. On examination, he has areflexia, symmetric flaccid weakness, and bilateral facial weakness, but no sensory level or bladder involvement. Nerve conduction study shows demyelination, and CSF analysis shows mildly elevated protein with few cells. Which of the following statements regarding the disease is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Normal CSF excludes the diagnosis

 

  • Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS) is an acute immune-mediated polyneuropathy often triggered by infections such as Campylobacter jejuni, CMV, or EBV.
  • It is characterized by rapidly progressive, symmetrical limb weakness, areflexia, and variable cranial nerve involvement.
  • Key Diagnostic Features:

 

 

Treatment Principles:

 

  • IVIG (0.4 g/kg/day × 5 days) or plasmapheresis — equally effective.
  • Corticosteroids are not beneficial.
  • If relapse occurs, the same modality (IVIG or PLEX) may be repeated.

 

Prognosis:

 

  • Axonal variants (AMAN, AMSAN) → slower or incomplete recovery, hence poorer outcome compared to demyelinating (AIDP) type.
  • CSF may remain normal in the first week of illness; protein elevation appears later. Thus, a normal CSF does not rule out GBS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Antiganglioside antibodies are not diagnostic: True — these support diagnosis but are not required for confirmation.

 

Option C. In case of relapse, re-treatment with same agent is recommended: True — relapse can be treated again with IVIG or PLEX, whichever was effective initially.

 

Option D. Axonal variants have poorer outcomes: True — due to axonal loss and slower regeneration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A normal CSF early in the disease does not exclude GBS. Diagnosis is clinical, supported by electrodiagnostic studies.
  • IVIG or plasmapheresis are mainstays of therapy; both can be repeated if relapse occurs. Axonal forms carry a worse prognosis than demyelinating types.

choices.text: After a transient ischaemic attack (TIA), surgery can proceed without delay if otherwise indicated.
After an ischaemic stroke, surgery should not be delayed if there is heart failure, uncontrolled infection, or persistent high embolic risk, and no intracranial bleed on imaging.
After an intracranial haemorrhage, surgery should ideally be delayed for more than 1 month.
In a patient with intracranial haemorrhage and unstable haemodynamics, surgery must be absolutely contraindicated regardless of the cardiac condition.
