questions.text: A 56-year-old man with infective endocarditis develops neurological symptoms suggestive of a stroke. Brain MRI confirms an ischaemic infarct. According to current recommendations, which of the following statements regarding timing of cardiac surgery is not correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) In a patient with intracranial haemorrhage and unstable haemodynamics, surgery must be absolutely contraindicated regardless of the cardiac condition.

 

  • The timing of cardiac surgery after neurological complications of infective endocarditis must balance neurological recovery against life-threatening cardiac deterioration or uncontrolled sepsis.
  • After TIA:
    Surgery can proceed without delay if indicated (Class I, Level B).
  • After ischaemic stroke:
    Surgery should not be delayed in cases with heart failure, uncontrolled infection, abscess, or persistent high embolic risk, as long as the patient is not comatose and intracranial haemorrhage is excluded on imaging (Class I, Level B).
  • After intracranial haemorrhage (ICH):
    Surgery is preferably delayed >1 month with repeat imaging to ensure stability before proceeding (Class IIa, Level C).
  • ICH with unstable condition (heart failure, abscess, uncontrolled infection): Urgent or emergency surgery may still be considered, balancing the chance of meaningful neurological recovery against cardiac risk (Class IIa, Level C). Hence, it is not absolutely contraindicated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. After a transient ischaemic attack (TIA), surgery can proceed without delay if otherwise indicated: Correct. Immediate surgery can be performed if otherwise indicated.

 

Option B. After an ischaemic stroke, surgery should not be delayed if there is heart failure, uncontrolled infection, or persistent high embolic risk, and no intracranial bleed on imaging: Correct. Can proceed after confirming absence of haemorrhage.

 

Option C. After an intracranial haemorrhage, surgery should ideally be delayed for more than 1 month with repeat imaging before proceeding: Correct. Advisable in stable patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cardiac surgery timing after neurological events in infective endocarditis:

 

 

  • Surgery after neurological complications in infective endocarditis is not absolutely contraindicated, even in the setting of ICH, if the cardiac condition is unstable or life-threatening. 
  • Decisions should be multidisciplinary and individualized.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true about cardiac muscle contraction? 

 

  1. Extracellular Ca²⁺ is important for contraction
  2. Ca²⁺ is released from mitochondria
  3. Ca²⁺ is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum
  4. Ligand-gated Ca²⁺ channels on sarcolemma have no role in EC coupling
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 and 3

 

Statement 1. Extracellular Ca²⁺ is important for contraction: This is true. In cardiac muscle, extracellular calcium is essential for the contraction process. About 20% of the calcium required for contraction comes from the extracellular fluid. This extracellular Ca²⁺ triggers the release of additional calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum through calcium-induced calcium release (CICR).

 

Statement 3. Ca²⁺ is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum: This is true. The sarcoplasmic reticulum is the primary source of calcium release inside the cardiac muscle cell, which is essential for contraction.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 2. Ca²⁺ is released from mitochondria: This is false. In cardiac muscle, calcium is not released from the mitochondria during contraction. Instead, calcium is stored and released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum.

 

Statement 4. Ligand-gated Ca²⁺ channels on sarcolemma have no role in EC coupling: This is false. Voltage-gated (not ligand-gated) Ca²⁺ channels on the sarcolemma (also known as L-type calcium channels) play an essential role in excitation-contraction (EC) coupling. They allow the entry of extracellular calcium, which triggers the release of more calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cardiac muscle contraction, both extracellular calcium and calcium released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum are crucial for the process, and voltage-gated calcium channels on the sarcolemma play an important role in excitation-contraction coupling.

choices.text: His glaucoma may worsen with cholinomimetic use
Cholinergic stimulation may exacerbate conduction abnormalities
His bladder symptoms suggest obstructive uropathy, not detrusor weakness
Cholinomimetics are ineffective in post-surgical urinary retention

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man is recovering postoperatively from a hernia repair. On the second postoperative day, he has not passed urine and complains of suprapubic discomfort. Physical examination reveals a distended bladder. The intern suggests initiating a parasympathomimetic agent to stimulate detrusor contraction. His chart reveals the following:

  • History of myasthenia gravis (well controlled on pyridostigmine)
  • History of open-angle glaucoma
  • Baseline ECG showing intermittent PR prolongation with occasional dropped beats, attributed to age-related conduction system disease
  • No history of infection or nephrolithiasis

Which of the following best explains why this patient may not be a suitable candidate for the proposed pharmacologic intervention?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cholinergic stimulation may exacerbate conduction abnormalities

 

  • Cholinomimetic agents (e.g., bethanechol) are commonly used for atonic bladder due to their ability to stimulate M3 receptors, enhancing detrusor muscle contraction.
  • However, these drugs also stimulate M2 receptors in the heart, which slow AV nodal conduction.
  • In a patient with pre-existing conduction abnormalities (e.g., intermittent PR prolongation and dropped beats), parasympathomimetics can worsen bradyarrhythmias or lead to complete heart block.
  • This makes their use contraindicated in partial heart block, even if the patient has other indications like urinary retention or glaucoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. His glaucoma may worsen with cholinomimetic use: Incorrect. On the contrary, cholinomimetics like pilocarpine or carbachol are used to treat glaucoma by improving aqueous outflow.

 

Option C. His bladder symptoms suggest obstructive uropathy, not detrusor weakness: Incorrect. While obstructive uropathy is a consideration, the patient’s bladder is distended and he is post-op, making detrusor underactivity a more likely etiology. Cholinomimetics are appropriate unless contraindicated by another condition (e.g., heart block).

 

Option D. Cholinomimetics are ineffective in post-surgical urinary retention: Incorrect. They are actually commonly used in this setting, especially bethanechol. Their ineffectiveness is not the issue here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cholinomimetic drugs are contraindicated in patients with AV conduction defects, such as partial heart block, due to their bradycardic and AV node-slowing effects via M2 receptor stimulation. 
  • Always review the cardiac conduction status before initiating these agents.

choices.text: Sentinel surveillance overestimates incidence because it samples only pregnant women
Sentinel surveillance primarily tracks trends and can reveal under-reporting; passive notifications may miss cases
Passive surveillance is superior for trend detection because it covers the whole population
The sentinel rise must be spurious because the passive system is comprehensive

questions.text: A state’s sentinel ANC network reports a rise in HIV positivity over 3 years, but routine case notifications from facilities show a flat trend. Which best reconciles the discrepancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sentinel surveillance primarily tracks trends and can reveal under-reporting; passive notifications may miss cases

 

  • Sentinel surveillance deliberately samples selected, stable sites (e.g., ANC/STI clinics) at regular intervals using a consistent protocol, making it well-suited to detect directional change (trends) in the wider population.
  • Because the methodology is standardized (same clinics, fixed sample size, same assays), changes in sentinel HIV positivity often reflect real shifts and/or gaps in routine case ascertainment.
  • By contrast, passive surveillance depends on facilities to report all diagnosed cases. 
  • It is highly vulnerable to incomplete reporting, variable testing intensity, stock-outs, staffing changes, stigma-driven non-attendance, and delays. 
  • A flat passive curve alongside a rising sentinel trend therefore commonly indicates under-reporting or reduced testing in the passive system rather than the absence of a true increase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sentinel overestimates incidence because it samples pregnant only women: Incorrect. Sentinel ANC data are not used to estimate incidence; they are used to monitor trends. Although pregnant women are a specific subpopulation, the consistent sampling frame makes sentinel data sensitive to temporal changes. It does not inherently “overestimate.”

 

Option C. Passive surveillance is superior for trend detection because it covers the whole population: Incorrect. Passive data may cover more facilities but are less stable for trend analysis because completeness and testing practices fluctuate. Trend sensitivity is exactly where sentinel excels.

 

Option D. The sentinel rise must be spurious because the passive system is comprehensive: Incorrect. Dismissing standardized sentinel signals because passive data are flat ignores the known limitations of passive systems and the design purpose of sentinel networks (to detect trends and identify “missing cases”).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sentinel surveillance (e.g., ANC clinics) uses consistent, selected sites to provide stable trend data and can unmask under-reporting in passive systems.
  • A rising sentinel trend with flat passive notifications should prompt investigation of gaps in testing/reporting rather than dismissal of the sentinel signal.

questions.text: An environmental surveillance team isolated the colony shown in the image from improperly stored cereal grains. Upon further analysis, fungal DNA sequencing confirmed the genus Penicillium. Which mycotoxin, known for its nephrotoxic potential and foodborne association, is most likely to be produced by this fungal isolate under conducive conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ochratoxin A

 

  • Ochratoxin A is a nephrotoxic mycotoxin produced by Penicillium verrucosum (as well as Aspergillus ochraceus). 
  • It contaminates stored food products such as cereals, bread, and coffee under humid conditions. 
  • It has been implicated in Balkan endemic nephropathy, and chronic exposure may also pose a carcinogenic risk. 
  • Since the image shows characteristic Penicillium colony morphology, Ochratoxin A is the most relevant associated toxin.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Aflatoxin: Aflatoxins are produced by Aspergillus flavus and A. parasiticus, not Penicillium. They are hepatotoxic and associated with hepatocellular carcinoma, especially through contaminated nuts and grains.

 

Option B. Ergot alkaloids: These are produced by Claviceps purpurea, not Penicillium. They contaminate rye and cause vasospastic symptoms (ergotism or “St. Anthony’s fire”).

 

Option D. Muscarine: Muscarine is found in toxic mushrooms (like Inocybe and Clitocybe species), not molds like Penicillium. It causes cholinergic toxicity, not food spoilage-related mycotoxicosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Penicillium species, although common environmental molds, are significant due to their production of ochratoxin A, a nephrotoxin found in improperly stored grains and bread. 
  • Accurate identification and mycotoxin correlation are essential for diagnosing toxin-related endemic diseases and implementing food safety controls.

choices.text: Median is the least affected by extreme values

questions.text: A statistician is analyzing a dataset that shows a characteristic distribution pattern, as illustrated in the histogram below. Which of the following statements is true regarding measures of central tendency in this type of distribution?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mode = 3 × Median – 2 × Mean

 

  • In bimodal or moderately skewed distributions, direct determination of the mode is often challenging.
  • To address this, the empirical relation is used:
    Mode = 3 × Median – 2 × Mean
  • This allows statisticians to estimate the mode when raw data are unavailable but mean and median are known.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Median = Mean = Mode: This occurs only in a perfectly normal (Gaussian) distribution, not in bimodal or skewed data.

 

Option B. Mode = 4 × Median – 2 × Mean: Incorrect; this formula does not exist in measures of central tendency.

 

Option D. Median is the least affected by extreme values: While true in skewed distributions with outliers, the histogram here is bimodal, not skewed, so the question specifically targets the empirical mode formula.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Central Tendency in Various Distributions:

 

 

  • In a bimodal series, Mode = 3 Median – 2 Mean
  • In distribution with extreme values (Outliers):
    • Most affected measure of central tendency: Mean
    • Least affected measure of central tendency: Mode
    • Most preferable measure of central tendency: Median

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with progressive loss of vision in his right eye. Fundus fluorescein angiography is performed, and the image is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Choroidal melanoma

 

  • The double circulation pattern seen on fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) is a hallmark feature of choroidal melanoma.
  • This refers to:
    • Retinal vessels traversing over the tumor.
    • Intrinsic tumor vasculature, both seen as two distinct vascular networks.
  • This finding represents vascular supply from both the retinal and choroidal circulation, which is characteristic of malignant choroidal tumors.
  • Indocyanine green (ICG) angiography provides even better visualization due to its deeper choroidal penetration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retinoblastoma: Usually presents in children and shows calcification with chalky-white appearance; not associated with double circulation.

 

Option B. Choroidal hemangioma: May show early hyperfluorescence on FFA but does not show double circulation pattern.

 

Option D. Central serous chorioretinopathy (CSCR): Typically shows ink blot or smoke stack leak, not an elevated vascular tumor with double circulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Double circulation on FFA (retinal + intrinsic tumor vessels) is a classic angiographic sign of choroidal melanoma. 
  • This finding helps differentiate it from other intraocular tumors and lesions.

questions.text: A patient with chronic stable angina is prescribed multiple agents for symptom control. Which of the following combinations poses the highest risk of life-threatening bradyarrhythmia due to additive effects on sinoatrial (SA) nodal activity?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Verapamil + Ivabradine

 

  • Verapamil is a non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker that slows AV nodal conduction and SA node firing, reducing heart rate and contractility.
  • Ivabradine selectively inhibits the funny current (If) in the SA node, reducing the pacemaker activity without affecting contractility or BP.
  • Combined use leads to excessive suppression of nodal activity, risking severe bradycardia, sinus arrest, or high-grade AV block.
  • This combination is contraindicated or used with extreme caution under close ECG monitoring.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ranolazine + Nicorandil: 

 

  • Ranolazine inhibits late Na⁺ current, improving myocardial relaxation and reducing oxygen demand.
  • Nicorandil is a nitrate and K⁺ channel opener; it primarily affects vascular tone.
  • Both do not directly affect SA or AV node conduction, so the risk of bradyarrhythmia is minimal.

 

Option C. Metoprolol + Trimetazidine: 

 

  • Metoprolol can slow the heart rate via β₁-blockade.
  • Trimetazidine modulates myocardial metabolism and does not affect nodal conduction or HR.
  • This combination is generally safe from a rhythm perspective.

 

Option D. Atenolol + Ranolazine: 

 

  • Both drugs may reduce myocardial workload, but Ranolazine's effect on HR is minimal, and atenolol, though a β₁-blocker, when used alone rarely causes life-threatening bradycardia.
  • Not a synergistic nodal suppressant combination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Avoid combining two drugs that both slow the SA node — especially ivabradine + verapamil/diltiazem or β-blockers — due to cumulative bradycardic risk.

choices.text: HBsAg, anti-HBc IgG, HDV RNA, anti-HDV IgG

questions.text: A 42-year-old male with a history of chronic hepatitis B presents with signs of worsening liver function. The clinician suspects a secondary viral infection contributing to hepatic deterioration. Which of the following lab findings would most accurately support a diagnosis of chronic hepatitis D superinfection?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) HBsAg, anti-HBc IgG, HDV RNA, anti-HDV IgG

 

  • Hepatitis D virus (HDV) is a defective RNA virus that requires the presence of Hepatitis B virus (HBV), specifically the HBsAg envelope, for replication and transmission.
  • There are two patterns of HDV infection:
    1. Co-infection: HBV and HDV acquired simultaneously (in an otherwise healthy person).
    2. Superinfection: HDV infection in a patient who is already chronically infected with HBV.
  • The patient is already a chronic HBV carrier and now shows signs of hepatic worsening, suggesting HDV superinfection.
  • In chronic superinfection, lab results would include:
    • HBsAg: Persistently positive due to chronic HBV
    • Anti-HBc IgG: Indicates prior/chronic infection (not IgM, which reflects acute infection)
    • HDV RNA: Indicates ongoing active replication of HDV
    • Anti-HDV IgG: Present in chronic phase (IgM more common in acute)
  • Thus, Option B reflects the correct serological pattern for chronic HDV superinfection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HBsAg, anti-HBc IgM, anti-HDV IgM:

 

  • Indicates acute co-infection, not superinfection.
  • Anti-HBc IgM points to recent HBV infection, which contradicts the “chronic HBV carrier” status in the stem.
  • Anti-HDV IgM is associated with acute HDV.
  • Incorrect: Pattern matches co-infection, not superinfection.

 

Option C. HBsAg, anti-HBs, HDV RNA:

 

  • Anti-HBs indicates resolution or immunity; it should not co-exist with HBsAg.
  • If a person has anti-HBs, they have cleared HBV or been vaccinated and thus cannot harbor HDV, as HDV needs HBsAg.
  • Incorrect: Serologically contradictory – anti-HBs and HBsAg are mutually exclusive.

 

Option D. Anti-HBc IgM, anti-HDV IgM, anti-HBs:

 

  • Anti-HBc IgM = acute HBV
  • Anti-HBs = resolved HBV or post-vaccination
  • Again, anti-HBs should not be present with ongoing infection.
  • Anti-HDV IgM = acute HDV, not chronic.
  • Incorrect: Inconsistent with chronic HBV + chronic HDV picture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chronic HDV superinfection occurs in HBV carriers and leads to a more severe disease course with higher risks of fulminant hepatitis, cirrhosis, and hepatocellular carcinoma. 
  • Serologic markers of chronic HDV superinfection include:
    • HBsAg
    • Anti-HBc IgG (not IgM)
    • HDV RNA (evidence of viral replication)
    • Anti-HDV IgG

questions.text: A 65-year-old man is admitted with dyspnea and hyponatremia. Laboratory findings are shown as follows. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s hyponatremia?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Heart failure

 

  • This patient’s hyponatremia is most consistent with hypervolemic hyponatremia due to heart failure.
  • In heart failure, there is increased total body water and sodium, but decreased effective circulating volume leads to nonosmotic release of ADH.
  • As a result:
    • Serum sodium is low (dilutional hyponatremia).
    • Urine osmolality is elevated (ADH-mediated water reabsorption).
    • Urine sodium is low (<20 mEq/L) due to activation of the renin–angiotensin–aldosterone system (RAAS) causing sodium retention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Beer potomania: Characterized by very low urine osmolality (<100 mOsm/kg) due to reduced solute intake; not seen here.

 

Option C. Low solute diet: Causes hyponatremia with low urine osmolality from decreased solute load; inconsistent with this case.

 

Option D. SIAD: Shows euvolemic hyponatremia with urine sodium >40 mEq/L and urine osmolality >100 mOsm/kg; inconsistent with this patient’s low urine sodium and clinical presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In heart failure, hyponatremia results from water retention secondary to nonosmotic ADH release and renal sodium conservation due to low effective arterial volume. 
  • This leads to low serum sodium, high urine osmolality, and low urine sodium.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a 20-year history of poorly controlled Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and established peripheral neuropathy presents with a hot, swollen, and red right foot that he noticed after twisting his ankle a week ago. He has discomfort, no pain. On examination, the foot is warm to the touch and grossly swollen. He has significantly diminished sensation in a stocking distribution. An X-ray of the foot is performed. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Charcot Neuroarthropathy

 

  • This diagnosis is defined by the combination of severe sensory neuropathy (poorly controlled diabetes, absent protective sensation) and progressive, destructive joint changes.
  • The patient is a long-standing diabetic with established neuropathy who presents with a hot, swollen, and red foot but little to no pain. 
  • The lack of pain despite severe visible inflammation is a key sign of a neuropathic joint.
  • The description of fragmentation, debris, dislocation, and new bone formation (Eichenholtz Stages) involving the midfoot (tarsal/tarsometatarsal joints) is the definitive radiographic evidence of joint disintegration secondary to unchecked mechanical stress in an insensate foot.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteomyelitis:

 

  • Osteomyelitis (bone infection) is common in diabetic feet.
  • But is typically associated with a chronic ulcer and, on X-ray, shows focal bone erosion and lysis or periosteal reaction, not the widespread disorganization and fragmentation across multiple joint lines seen in this case. 
  • Clinically, it often presents with fever or deep, throbbing pain, which is inconsistent with the patient's low pain report.

 

Option B. Acute Gouty Arthritis:

 

  • Gout causes an exquisitely painful, sudden flare (often in the MTP1​ joint) and is diagnosed by aspirating monosodium urate crystals. 
  • While the joint would be hot and red, it would be excruciatingly painful (a significant contrast to this patient's "discomfort"), and the X-ray would not show the massive, destructive fragmentation and dislocation of the midfoot joints.

 

Option C. Cellulitis:

 

  • Cellulitis is a soft-tissue bacterial infection causing redness, warmth, and swelling. 
  • It does not cause the underlying bone and joint destruction seen on the X-ray. 
  • While Charcot foot often presents with associated cellulitis, the deep bone changes mandate the primary diagnosis of Charcot neuroarthropathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The classic presentation of acute Charcot foot—specifically the combination of a high-risk patient (diabetic neuropathy) with an acutely swollen, warm, but painless or mildly painful joint, and the hallmark radiographic findings of severe joint destruction and disorganization.

choices.text: Elevated blood ketones with normal glucose levels

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus presents for a follow-up visit 3 weeks after being started on dapagliflozin for better glycemic control. She reports increased frequency of urination and a recent urinary tract infection. On evaluation, her serum bicarbonate level is mildly reduced (18 mEq/L). She denies nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, or breathlessness. Her blood glucose level is 130 mg/dL, and she appears well hydrated. The physician suspects a rare but serious adverse effect associated with her new medication. Which of the following laboratory findings would most likely confirm this adverse effect?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Elevated blood ketones with normal glucose levels

 

  • This patient was recently started on dapagliflozin, a sodium-glucose cotransporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibitor used in type 2 diabetes to promote glucosuria and lower plasma glucose levels. 
  • A rare but serious complication of SGLT2 inhibitors is euglycemic diabetic ketoacidosis (euDKA).
  • In euDKA:
    • Urinary glucose loss leads to relatively normal or mildly elevated blood glucose.
    • Insulin levels fall due to lower plasma glucose.
    • Simultaneously, glucagon rises, promoting lipolysis and ketone body formation.
    • This leads to high anion gap metabolic acidosis (evidenced by low bicarbonate).
    • Classic symptoms of DKA (nausea, vomiting, fruity breath, Kussmaul breathing) may be mild or absent, especially early in the disease course.
  • The key lab finding that confirms this condition is the presence of elevated blood ketones with normal or only mildly elevated glucose — consistent with euDKA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Elevated liver transaminases: These are associated with hepatotoxic drugs such as pioglitazone or statins, not dapagliflozin. This would not explain the metabolic acidosis or urinary symptoms.

 

Option C. Decreased serum insulin levels: While a physiologic consequence of SGLT2 inhibitor use, low insulin is not diagnostic by itself and is not a specific marker for euDKA. The diagnosis depends on evidence of ketosis and acidosis.

 

Option D. Elevated serum amylase and lipase: These findings suggest pancreatitis, which is more commonly associated with GLP-1 receptor agonists like exenatide or liraglutide, not SGLT2 inhibitors. Pancreatitis does not typically cause euglycemic ketoacidosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SGLT2 inhibitors (e.g., dapagliflozin) can cause euglycemic diabetic ketoacidosis, characterized by elevated ketones and metabolic acidosis despite normal or mildly elevated glucose levels.

questions.text:
Consider the following statements:

 

  1. Specific phobia is characterized by marked fear or anxiety about a specific object or situation, which is actively avoided or endured with intense distress.
  2. Behavioural therapy is the treatment of choice.
  3. To diagnose specific phobia, symptoms must persist for at least 1 month.
  4. Blood-injection-injury type of specific phobia may be associated with vasovagal syncope and a biphasic heart rate response.

 

Which of the following is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Statements 1, 2, and 4 are correct

 

Statement 1. Specific phobia is characterized by marked fear or anxiety about a specific object or situation, which is actively avoided or endured with intense distress: Correct. Specific phobia involves marked fear/anxiety about a specific object or situation (e.g., flying, animals, injections), which is avoided or endured with distress.

 

Statement 2. Behavioural therapy is the treatment of choice: Correct. Behavioural therapy is the treatment of choice for patients with specific phobia.

 

Statement 4. Blood-injection-injury type of specific phobia may be associated with vasovagal syncope and a biphasic heart rate response: Correct. In blood-injection-injury type phobia, there's often a unique vasovagal (biphasic) response: an initial increase in heart rate and BP followed by a sudden drop, sometimes leading to syncope.

 

Incorrect Statement: 

 

Statement 3. To diagnose specific phobia, symptoms must persist for at least 1 month: Incorrect. The required duration for diagnosis is ≥6 months, not 1 month (as per DSM-5 criteria).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Specific phobia is a persistent (>6 months), excessive fear of a clearly defined object or situation. 
  • Insight is usually preserved, and blood-injection-injury phobia is unique in its physiological response (vasovagal syncope).

choices.text: Most commonly seen in the lower leg, particularly in the gaiter area
An active venous ulcer is classified as CEAP C6

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of chronic varicose veins presents with a non-healing ulcer over the medial aspect of his lower leg. On examination, the ulcer is shallow, irregular, and has a granulating floor. Which of the following statements about venous ulcers is not true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Has punched-out edges

 

  • Venous ulcers characteristically have gently sloping edges, not punched-out edges. They often contain granulation tissue and exudate, and they heal poorly due to persistent venous hypertension. 
  • Punched-out edges are instead a feature of arterial ulcers or trophic ulcers (e.g., neuropathic ulcers).

 

Other Options:  

 

Option A. Most commonly seen in the lower leg, particularly in the gaiter area: True. Venous ulcers occur most often in the gaiter area (medial lower leg between the calf and ankle), where venous pressure is greatest.

 

Option B. Caused by ambulatory venous hypertension: True. The underlying pathophysiology is ambulatory venous hypertension, resulting from incompetent venous valves and impaired calf muscle pump.

 

Option D. An active venous ulcer is classified as CEAP C6: True. According to the CEAP classification (Clinical-Etiological-Anatomical-Pathophysiological), active venous ulcers are C6, while healed venous ulcers are C5.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Venous ulcers are typically found in the gaiter region, caused by ambulatory venous hypertension, with sloping edges and CEAP classification C6 when active — punched-out edges suggest arterial ulcers, not venous.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman with grossly deforming arthritis has been on methotrexate for the past 2 years. She is reluctant to start anti–TNF-α therapy due to concerns about immunosuppression. Recently, she developed scaly rashes behind her pinna as shown below. Which drug should be particularly avoided?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hydroxychloroquine

 

  • This patient likely has psoriatic arthritis (PsA) - indicated by deforming arthritis and new psoriatic plaques behind the ear.
  • In such cases, hydroxychloroquine should be avoided as it can precipitate, worsen, or reactivate psoriasis.
  • Mechanism:
    • The dermatologic adverse effect of hydroxychloroquine is not fully understood.
    • It may alter keratinocyte proliferation or immune signaling, leading to new or aggravated psoriatic lesions.
    • Both chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine are known triggers, even when used for non-dermatologic indications such as SLE or RA.
  • Hence, in psoriatic arthritis or known psoriasis, hydroxychloroquine should be avoided, particularly when cutaneous disease is active.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methotrexate: Beneficial in psoriatic arthritis, improving both joint and skin manifestations

 

Option C. Leflunomide: Can be safely used in PsA; may even help cutaneous psoriasis.

 

Option D. Sulfasalazine: Useful for mild peripheral joint involvement, though less effective for axial or skin disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hydroxychloroquine should be avoided in patients with psoriasis or psoriatic arthritis, as it can induce or exacerbate psoriatic skin lesions.
  • Preferred agents for PsA:
    • TNF-α inhibitors (e.g., etanercept, adalimumab)
    • IL-17 inhibitors (e.g., secukinumab)
    • IL-12/23 inhibitors (e.g., ustekinumab)
    • DMARDs such as methotrexate or leflunomide for peripheral arthritis.
  • Avoid hydroxychloroquine in psoriasis — it may trigger or worsen psoriatic flares even in previously stable disease.

choices.text: Collect 50 ml urine only; blood is not needed
Collect 10 ml blood in heparin tube and freeze immediately
Collect 100 ml urine and 5 ml blood. Add NaF to both blood and urine, and potassium oxalate to only blood
Delay collection to 96 hours for peak metabolite concentration

questions.text: A rape survivor presents 3 days after the incident. She suspects she was drugged with GHB (gamma-hydroxybutyrate) at a party. Which of the following specimen collection protocols would maximize the chance of detecting the drug?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Collect 100 ml urine and 5 ml blood. Add NaF to both blood and urine, and potassium oxalate to only blood

 

  • Detection of GHB in forensic settings is difficult because the drug is rapidly metabolized and eliminated from the body.
  • To maximize detection:
    • Urine samples are preferred as they allow longer detection times (up to 12–24 hours, sometimes longer). Collecting at least 100 mL urine improves sensitivity.
    • Blood samples (5 mL) are also collected because they may detect the drug earlier, though the detection window is shorter.
    • Preservatives such as sodium fluoride (NaF) are added to both blood and urine to inhibit bacterial growth and enzymatic degradation of GHB.
    • Potassium oxalate is added to blood specifically to prevent clotting.
  • Prompt collection is essential, as delaying sample acquisition significantly reduces the chance of detecting the drug due to its short half-life.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Collect 50 ml urine only; blood is not needed: Incomplete. While urine is useful but 100 ml, blood sample is essential within 24 hours for forensic validity and correlation.

 

Option B. Collect 10 ml blood in heparin tube and freeze immediately: Heparin interferes with PCR and should not be used for GHB analysis. Also, freezing isn't optimal unless processing is significantly delayed.

 

Option D. Delay collection to 96 hours for peak metabolite concentration: Incorrect. Delaying reduces detection chances as GHB has a very short half-life. Early collection is crucial.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • GHB detection requires timely sample collection using appropriate preservatives:
    • Blood (5 ml) within 24 hours (in NaF and potassium oxalate tubes)
    • Urine (100 ml) within 96 hours to optimize forensic toxicology testing.

questions.text: During evaluation of a patient with dysphonia and loss of gag reflex, injury to the cranial nerve X (vagus nerve) is suspected. Which of the following functional components is not represented in this cranial nerve?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) General Somatic Efferent (GSE)

 

  • The vagus nerve (cranial nerve X) carries multiple functional components responsible for motor, sensory, and parasympathetic functions:
    • GSA (General Somatic Afferent): Provides sensory innervation to the external auditory canal, external ear, and part of the dura mater.
    • GVA (General Visceral Afferent): Carries sensory fibers from the thoracic and abdominal viscera, including aortic baroreceptors and chemoreceptors.
    • GVE (General Visceral Efferent): Provides parasympathetic fibers to the heart, lungs, and gastrointestinal tract up to the midgut.
    • SVE (Special Visceral Efferent): Supplies muscles derived from the 4th and 6th pharyngeal arches, including pharyngeal and laryngeal muscles.
  • The GSE (General Somatic Efferent) component is absent in the vagus nerve. 
  • GSE fibers supply somite-derived skeletal muscles such as those controlled by cranial nerves III, IV, VI, and XII — not branchial arch-derived muscles.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. General Visceral Efferent (GVE): Incorrect. These fibers mediate parasympathetic control of thoracic and abdominal organs via the dorsal motor nucleus of the vagus.

 

Option B. General Somatic Afferent (GSA): Incorrect. Present in the vagus nerve, providing somatic sensation from the external ear and dura mater.

 

Option D. General Visceral Afferent (GVA): Incorrect. These fibers carry visceral sensory input from the thoracic and abdominal viscera to the nucleus tractus solitarius.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The vagus nerve (cranial nerve X) contains GSA, GVA, GVE, and SVE fibers but lacks GSE fibers, which are confined to cranial nerves III, IV, VI, and XII that innervate somite-derived skeletal muscles.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements correctly distinguishes fast-acting erythrocytic schizonticides from primary tissue schizonticides?

 

  1. Fast-acting erythrocytic schizonticides are effective for acute attacks but not for causal prophylaxis.
  2. Primary tissue schizonticides act on pre-erythrocytic stages and prevent infection after sporozoite entry.
  3. Both classes eradicate dormant hypnozoites of P. vivax.
  4. Only primary tissue schizonticides are safe in pregnancy.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 and 2 only

 

Statement 1. Fast-acting erythrocytic schizonticides are effective for acute attacks but not for causal prophylaxis: Fast‑acting erythrocytic schizonticides (chloroquine, quinine, artemisinins, mefloquine) kill blood-stage schizonts, quickly controlling symptoms during acute attacks. However, they do not act on hepatic pre-erythrocytic stages, so they cannot provide causal prophylaxis or eradicate dormant hypnozoites.

 

Statement 2. Primary tissue schizonticides act on pre-erythrocytic stages and prevent infection after sporozoite entry: Primary tissue schizonticides (proguanil, pyrimethamine) act on the pre-erythrocytic (hepatic) stage, preventing the development of blood-stage infection after sporozoite entry — hence used for causal prophylaxis.
This is why only statements 1 and 2 are correct.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 3. Both classes eradicate dormant hypnozoites of P. vivax: Incorrect. Only primaquine eradicates dormant hypnozoites of P. vivax/P. ovale (radical cure). Neither fast-acting erythrocytic schizonticides nor primary tissue schizonticides do this.

 

Statement 4. Only primary tissue schizonticides are safe in pregnancy: Incorrect. Chloroquine (a fast-acting erythrocytic schizonticide) is actually safe in pregnancy. Primaquine (a hepatic agent) is contraindicated in pregnancy due to hemolysis risk in G6PD-deficient fetuses.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Fast-acting erythrocytic schizonticides: Treat acute attacks, no effect on hepatic stages (cannot prevent relapse).
  • Primary tissue schizonticides: Act on pre-erythrocytic hepatic stages (causal prophylaxis), but do not eradicate hypnozoites.
  • Only primaquine eradicates dormant hypnozoites (radical cure).
  • Chloroquine is safe in pregnancy; primaquine is not.

choices.text: To create an end-to-end anastomosis in the bowel
To measure the internal pressure of the rectum

questions.text: A 64-year-old man undergoes an anorectal surgery. During the reconstruction phase of the surgery, the surgical team uses the device shown in the image. Which of the following best describes the function of this device?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) To create an end-to-end anastomosis in the bowel

 

  • The instrument in the image is a circular stapler, commonly used in colorectal and gastrointestinal surgeries, especially during low anterior resection or esophagogastric anastomosis. 
  • It is introduced into the lumen of one bowel end, and the opposite end is attached to the stapler’s anvil.
  • Function: It fires a circular double row of staples, then cuts between them, thus creating a secure end-to-end anastomosis.
  • This technique ensures hemostasis and reduces the risk of leakage at the anastomotic site.
  • Frequently used in colorectal resections, particularly low pelvic anastomoses where manual suturing is technically difficult.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. To dilate strictures:  Dilation is typically performed using balloon dilators or bougies, not a stapler.

 

Option B. To excise sentinel pile: Sentinel pile is seen in chronic fissures, which are excised with knife/scissors.

 

Option D. To measure the internal pressure of the rectum: This is done via anorectal manometry, not with a surgical stapler.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

A circular stapler is a surgical instrument used to create an end-to-end anastomosis between hollow organs, especially in gastrointestinal surgeries such as low anterior resection.

questions.text: A state implements a clean water and sanitation program to reduce diarrheal disease. After five years, diarrhea incidence declines by 40%, but simultaneously, economic development, better nutrition, and new rotavirus vaccine rollouts also occurred. In your evaluation, attributing the 40% drop solely to the water program would primarily violate which evaluation criterion?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Impact 

 

  • Impact evaluation measures the overall health and developmental effects of a program. 
  • Crucially, it must determine the net effect attributable to the program, separating it from other contextual influences (e.g., socioeconomic changes, additional health interventions).
  • In this case, diarrhea incidence likely fell due to multiple factors, not sanitation alone. 
  • Concluding that the water program was the sole cause overstates its impact and ignores confounding influences, which invalidates the attribution of impact.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Accessibility: Refers to whether the target population could use the service. The program may have been accessible, but that’s not the problem here.

 

Option B. Relevance: Indicates whether the service addressed a real need (diarrhea reduction). Clearly relevant.

 

Option C. Adequacy: Concerns whether implementation matched planned targets. The issue is not about reaching planned coverage but about causal attribution of health outcomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Impact evaluation must attribute only the portion of outcome change truly caused by the program, accounting for other concurrent interventions and contextual factors. 
  • Over-attributing outcome improvements to a single intervention violates the principle of valid impact assessment.

 

Note - Evaluation of Health Services:

 

  • Relevance: Appropriateness (need) of a health service
  • Adequacy: Sufficient attention to pre-determined course of action
  • Accessibility: Proportion of population expected to use the service
  • Acceptability: Socially and culturally acceptable
  • Effectiveness: Extent of prevention/alleviation of underlying problem
  • Efficiency: How well resources are utilized
  • Impact: Overall effect of programme/service on health and development

questions.text: A public health officer is planning a school eye screening program in a rural block. The total number of students from grades V to VIII is estimated to be 30,000. According to the national SES guidelines, how many trained teachers should be recruited to complete the initial screening?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 200

 

According to the School Eye Screening (SES) program under the National Programme for Control of Blindness (NPCB):

 

  • Target group: Middle school children (Grades V to VIII = 10–14 years)
  • Teacher-to-student screening ratio: 1 teacher per 150 students
  • So for 30,000 students:

 

 

  • Hence, 200 trained teachers should be recruited to perform the initial screening.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • To implement large-scale screening in schools, task-shifting is done by training schoolteachers to screen for visual impairment. 
  • This increases efficiency and ensures early detection of refractive errors in children.
  • Cut-off for referral in SES: <6/9 vision in either eye
  • Each teacher can screen 150 students after a 1-day training at PHC
  • Teacher kit includes: Vision charts, rope/tape for 20-ft distance, referral cards
  • Referral system: Students with visual impairment are sent to the nearest PHC with ophthalmic assistant

choices.text: 6 weeks abstinence and delay conception by 6 months
6 months abstinence and delay conception by 6 years
3 weeks abstinence and delay conception by 2 years
3 months abstinence and delay conception by 1 year

questions.text: A patient has recently undergone surgical repair of a vesicovaginal fistula (VVF) and is being discharged. For optimal healing and prevention of recurrence, how long should she be advised to abstain from sexual intercourse and delay conception?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 3 months abstinence and delay conception by 1 year

 

  • Vesicovaginal fistula (VVF) is an abnormal communication between the urinary bladder and the vagina, leading to continuous leakage of urine per vaginam.
  • Surgical repair (via abdominal or vaginal route) aims to close the defect and restore urinary continence.
  • Postoperative management and counseling are crucial to ensure proper healing and prevent recurrence:
    • Sexual intercourse: The patient should abstain from sexual activity for at least 3 months post-surgery to allow complete epithelial healing and prevent mechanical disruption of the repair.
    • Conception: Pregnancy and vaginal delivery place stress on the repaired site; hence, conception should be deferred for at least 1 year to allow full tissue recovery.
      When pregnancy does occur, delivery should be by cesarean section to prevent recurrence of the fistula.

 

Summary of recommendations:

 

  • Abstinence: 3 months
  • Delay conception: 1 year
  • Future delivery: Cesarean section preferred

 

Educational Objective:

 

After vesicovaginal fistula repair, patients should abstain from sexual intercourse for 3 months and delay conception for 1 year to ensure complete healing of the fistula site and prevent recurrence.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding non-pharmacologic therapy is/are true? 

 

  1. DASH typically lowers SBP 8–14 mmHg, often exceeding the effect of sodium restriction alone.
  2. Regular aerobic activity (≥30 min most days) lowers SBP 4–9 mmHg.
  3. Alcohol moderation to <2 drinks/day has negligible BP effect (≈0–1 mmHg).
  4. Weight loss of 10 kg lowers SBP 5–20 mmHg.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2 and 4 only

 

Statement 1. DASH typically lowers SBP 8–14 mmHg, often exceeding the effect of sodium restriction alone: The DASH eating pattern (fruits/vegetables, low-fat dairy, reduced saturated/total fat) reduces SBP by ~8–14 mmHg, typically more than sodium restriction alone.

 

Statement 2. Regular aerobic activity (≥30 min most days) lowers SBP 4–9 mmHg: Regular aerobic exercise (≥30 min on most days) lowers SBP by ~4–9 mmHg.

 

Statement 4. Weight loss of 10 kg lowers SBP 5–20 mmHg: About 5–20 mmHg SBP reduction per 10-kg loss (dose-responsive).

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 3. Alcohol moderation to <2 drinks/day has negligible BP effect (≈0–1 mmHg): False. Limiting alcohol to <2 drinks/day reduces SBP by ~2–4 mmHg, not “negligible (0–1 mmHg).”

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lifestyle Modifications to Manage Hypertension

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man with long-standing hypertension is started on an ACE inhibitor. Regarding the juxtaglomerular apparatus (JGA) and its physiological control, consider the following statements:

 

  1. Decreased sodium chloride delivery to the macula densa stimulates renin release.
  2. β₁-adrenergic receptor activation on juxtaglomerular cells enhances renin secretion.
  3. Afferent arteriole constriction directly inhibits renin secretion.
  4. Angiotensin II exerts positive feedback on renin release from JG cells.

 

Which of the following combination is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1 and 2 only

 

Statement 1. Decreased sodium chloride delivery to the macula densa stimulates renin release: Correct. The macula densa senses NaCl concentration in the distal tubule. ↓ NaCl (as in low GFR or hypovolemia) → macula densa releases prostaglandins (PGE₂) → stimulates renin release from JG cells.

 

Statement 2. β₁-adrenergic receptor activation on juxtaglomerular cells enhances renin secretion: Correct. β₁-adrenergic stimulation (via sympathetic activity) increases cAMP in JG cells → promotes renin secretion. This is why β-blockers (like propranolol) reduce renin release.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 3. Afferent arteriole constriction directly inhibits renin secretion: Incorrect. Afferent arteriole constriction actually stimulates renin release indirectly by lowering renal perfusion pressure sensed by baroreceptors in JG cells.

 

Statement 4. Angiotensin II exerts positive feedback on renin release from JG cells: Incorrect. Angiotensin II exerts negative feedback on JG cells, inhibiting renin release. Therefore, ACE inhibitors or ARBs remove this inhibition → cause increased plasma renin activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Renin secretion by juxtaglomerular cells is stimulated by:
  1. ↓ renal perfusion pressure (intrarenal baroreceptor mechanism),
  2. ↓ NaCl at macula densa, and
  3. ↑ sympathetic β₁ activity.
  • Angiotensin II provides negative feedback to maintain renin homeostasis.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe pain and discoloration in his lower extremities, as shown in the image. His medical history reveals that he was recently prescribed medication for an acute migraine attack. Physical examination reveals cold, dusky toes and diminished pulses in his lower extremities. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ergotamine

 

  • Ergotamine is an ergot alkaloid used for the acute treatment of migraine attacks.
  • It acts as a partial agonist at serotonin (5-HT₁B/₁D) receptors, leading to cranial vasoconstriction and relief of migraine pain. 
  • However, it also has potent α-adrenergic and 5-HT₂ agonist activity, which can cause vasoconstriction in peripheral and coronary vessels.
  • In susceptible individuals or when taken in high doses, ergotamine can cause severe peripheral vasospasm, leading to limb ischemia, gangrene, and a condition known as ergotism (also referred to as St. Anthony’s fire).
  • The patient’s symptoms of cold, dusky toes with diminished pulses following use of an acute migraine medication are classic for this adverse effect.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Propranolol: Propranolol is a non-selective beta-blocker used in the prophylactic treatment of migraines, not for acute attacks. It does not cause vasospastic ischemia. Common side effects include bradycardia, fatigue, and hypotension, but not gangrene or peripheral ischemia.

 

Option C. Topiramate: An anticonvulsant used for migraine prophylaxis, topiramate works by modulating GABA and glutamate neurotransmission. It does not cause vasoconstriction and is not associated with peripheral ischemia. Side effects include cognitive slowing, weight loss, and paresthesias.

 

Option D. Olcegepant:  A CGRP receptor antagonist, olcegepant is a newer class of anti-migraine drug used for acute migraine therapy. It promotes vasodilation, the opposite of vasospasm, and is not associated with ischemic complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ergotamine, used for acute migraine attacks, can cause severe peripheral vasoconstriction due to its α-adrenergic and serotonergic activity, leading to ischemia and gangrene (ergotism).

questions.text: A 35-year-old male is admitted with a severe skin and soft tissue infection unresponsive to first-line β-lactam antibiotics. Culture from the wound grows gram-positive cocci in clusters. The attending physician suspects MRSA and requests further testing for rapid confirmation. Which of the following laboratory methods offers the fastest and most specific identification of MRSA in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) PCR detection of mecA gene

 

  • PCR detection of the mecA gene is the most rapid and specific diagnostic method for confirming MRSA (Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus).
  • The mecA gene encodes PBP-2a, a penicillin-binding protein that confers resistance to β-lactam antibiotics by reducing their binding affinity. 
  • PCR not only detects this gene directly from the sample but also provides rapid results, which is crucial for early intervention and antibiotic stewardship.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oxacillin disk diffusion test: Although commonly used, this phenotypic test takes longer (24–48 hours) and requires specific incubation conditions (2–4% NaCl, 30°C). It also lacks the molecular specificity of PCR.

 

Option B. Gram stain and colony morphology: This method confirms Staphylococcus aureus but cannot distinguish MRSA from methicillin-sensitive S. aureus (MSSA). It's useful for preliminary identification, not resistance detection.

 

Option D. Latex agglutination test for PBP-2a: This test is fairly specific and detects the protein product of mecA, but it's less rapid and can be affected by variable expression levels of PBP-2a. PCR is still more sensitive and direct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • PCR detection of the mecA gene is the gold standard for rapid and specific confirmation of MRSA. 
  • It detects the genetic basis of resistance and allows prompt initiation of appropriate antibiotics like vancomycin or linezolid.

choices.text: Corneal ulcer prevalence > 0.05% indicates a public health problem
Serum retinol <10 mcg/dl in >5% children is diagnostic of community-level deficiency
Keratomalacia prevalence >0.01% does not warrant intervention
Bitot’s spot prevalence >0.5% is considered significant

questions.text:
A public health team conducts a nutritional survey among preschool children (ages 6 months to 6 years) in a rural community to assess for vitamin A deficiency. The following indicators are evaluated:

 

  • Bitot's spots prevalence: 0.7%
  • Corneal ulcer prevalence: 0.06%
  • Serum retinol <10 mcg/dl in 4.5%
  • Corneal xerosis/keratomalacia prevalence: 0.02%

 

Based on WHO-recommended thresholds for xerophthalmia surveillance, which of the following statements is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Keratomalacia prevalence >0.01% does not warrant intervention

 

  • Keratomalacia (as well as corneal xerosis or ulceration) prevalence >0.01% does warrant urgent public health intervention. 
  • It indicates a clinical emergency and is never ignored.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Corneal ulcer prevalence > 0.05% indicates a public health problem: Corneal ulcer prevalence > 0.05% exceeds the WHO threshold, indicating a public health problem.

 

Option B. Serum retinol <10 mcg/dl in >5% children is diagnostic of community-level deficiency: Serum retinol <10 mcg/dl in >5% of children signifies a biochemical indicator of vitamin A deficiency.

 

Option D. Bitot’s spot prevalence >0.5% is considered significant: Bitot’s spot prevalence > 0.5% is considered epidemiologically significant.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Prevalence criteria for determining the Xerophthalmia problem in a community:

 

 

  • Prevalence is measured in population at risk, i.e., pre-school children 6 months – 6 years.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man with Parkinson’s disease presents with a recurrent itchy, erythematous rash affecting his neck, retroauricular areas, and nasolabial folds. The rash also occurred last winter and improved during the warmer months. On examination, there is erythema with greasy, yellowish scales in the affected areas. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Seborrhoeic dermatitis

 

  • Seborrhoeic dermatitis is a chronic, relapsing inflammatory skin condition affecting sebaceous gland-rich areas such as the scalp, face (especially nasolabial folds), retroauricular areas, and upper trunk. 
  • It is characterized by erythema with greasy, yellowish scales and can be itchy.
  • It is more common in individuals with Parkinson’s disease due to altered sebum production and immune changes.
  • Symptoms often worsen in cold, dry winter months.
  • Caused in part by an inflammatory reaction to Malassezia yeast.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acne rosacea: Incorrect. Rosacea presents with central facial erythema, telangiectasia, papules, and pustules. It does not typically involve greasy scales and is not specifically linked to Parkinson’s disease.

 

Option B. Flexural psoriasis: Incorrect. Flexural psoriasis involves smooth, red plaques in skin folds (axilla, groin, inframammary), without the greasy scaling typical of seborrhoeic dermatitis, and usually spares the nasolabial folds.

 

Option C. Levodopa-associated dermatitis: Incorrect. Levodopa may cause drug rashes, but these are not recurrent in the same sebaceous-rich locations and do not have the characteristic scaling of seborrhoeic dermatitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Seborrhoeic dermatitis is a chronic inflammatory condition affecting sebaceous gland-rich areas, often associated with Parkinson’s disease, and presents with erythema and greasy scales in the nasolabial folds, scalp, and retroauricular areas, with flares in winter months.

choices.text: It is effective against MRSA, VRE, and anaerobes.
It acts by inhibiting the 30S ribosomal subunit like other tetracyclines.
It requires dose adjustment in renal failure due to primary renal excretion.

questions.text: Considering the pharmacology and clinical use of tigecycline, all of the following statements are true, except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It requires dose adjustment in renal failure due to primary renal excretion

 

  • Tigecycline is primarily excreted via the biliary/fecal route and does not require dose adjustment in renal impairment. 
  • This makes it a favorable option in patients with reduced kidney function.
  • The statement claiming it requires adjustment due to renal excretion is incorrect, making it the right answer in an "EXCEPT" style question.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is effective against MRSA, VRE, and anaerobes: True. Tigecycline has a broad antimicrobial spectrum and is effective against multidrug-resistant organisms like MRSA (Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus), VRE (Vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus), and anaerobes.

 

Option B. It is ineffective against Pseudomonas: True. Despite its broad coverage, tigecycline is notably ineffective against Pseudomonas species. This is an important clinical limitation and often tested.

 

Option C. It acts by inhibiting the 30S ribosomal subunit like other tetracyclines: True. Like tetracyclines, tigecycline binds to the 30S ribosomal subunit, inhibiting protein synthesis. However, it is structurally modified to evade resistance via efflux pumps and ribosomal protection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tigecycline is a glycylcycline antibiotic with enhanced resistance to efflux-mediated resistance. 
  • It is biliary-excreted, making it safe in renal impairment, and is useful against resistant Gram-positive and anaerobic organisms. 
  • However, its ineffectiveness against Proteus and Pseudomonas and lack of renal dose adjustment are high-yield distinctions in clinical decision-making.

questions.text: The ICF concentration of K⁺ is 140 mEq/L and ECF concentration is 14 mEq/L, and the cell is permeable only to K⁺. What would be the expected change if the extracellular K⁺ concentration is reduced from 14 to 1.4 millimolar?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 61 millivolts hyperpolarization

 

  • This question involves the calculation of the resting membrane potential (RMP) using the Nernst equation, which describes the equilibrium potential for an ion. 
  • For potassium (K⁺), the Nernst equation can be simplified as:

 

 

Given:

 

  • Initial extracellular concentration [K⁺ outside] = 14 mEq/L
  • Intracellular concentration [K⁺ inside] = 140 mEq/L
  • After the change, [K⁺ outside] = 1.4 mEq/L

 

Step 1: Calculate initial RMP:

 

Before the change:

 

 

This is the initial resting membrane potential.

 

Step 2: Calculate the new RMP after reducing [K⁺ outside]:

 

After reducing extracellular potassium to 1.4 mEq/L:

 

 

This is the new resting membrane potential.

 

Step 3: Determine the change in RMP:

 

The initial RMP was −61 mV, and the new RMP is −122 mV. The change is:

 

−122 mV−(−61 mV) = −61 mV

 

Thus, the membrane potential has hyperpolarized by 61 millivolts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When extracellular K⁺ concentration is reduced, the cell undergoes 61 millivolts hyperpolarization, as the loss of K⁺ leads to the inside of the cell becoming more negative.

questions.text: A preterm neonate (born at 30 weeks gestation) presents on day 10 of life with abdominal distension, feeding intolerance, and bloody stools. On examination, the infant appears lethargic, has a tense abdomen, and shows visible bowel loops. A plain abdominal X-ray is performed and showed pneumatosis intestinalis. In which stage of Necrotising enterocolitis, this condition is seen?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Stage 2a

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Modified Bell's staging is the standard classification system for Necrotizing Enterocolitis, helping guide management based on clinical, radiological, and laboratory findings.

questions.text: A lymph node biopsy from a young adult presenting with massive, painless cervical lymphadenopathy shows the histopathological image provided. Immunohistochemistry reveals CD207 negative, S-100 positive, and CD1a negative staining. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rosai–Dorfman disease 

 

  • Rosai–Dorfman disease (RDD), also known as Sinus histiocytosis with massive lymphadenopathy, is a benign histiocytic proliferative disorder characterized by the accumulation of large S100-positive histiocytes within lymph node sinuses.

 

Key Histologic Feature:

 

  • The image shows emperipolesis — the hallmark of RDD — where intact lymphocytes, plasma cells, or RBCs are present within the cytoplasm of large histiocytes.
  • Unlike phagocytosis, the engulfed cells remain viable and intact.
  • Histiocytes are large with abundant pale cytoplasm and vesicular nuclei.

 

Clinical Features:

 

  • Massive, painless bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy (most common).
  • May have fever, leukocytosis, and elevated ESR.
  • Can involve extranodal sites (skin, respiratory tract, CNS, bone).
  • Self-limiting in most cases, though corticosteroids or surgery may be required for severe organ involvement.

 

Immunohistochemistry:  S100 positive, CD68 positive, CD1a negative (helps distinguish from Langerhans cell histiocytosis).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Langerhans cell histiocytosis:

 

  • Cells have Birbeck granules (tennis-racket-shaped) on EM.
  • CD1a positive, S100 positive, but emperipolesis absent.
  • Presents with lytic bone lesions, skin rash, or diabetes insipidus.

 

Option C. Hodgkin lymphoma:

 

  • Characterized by Reed–Sternberg cells (“owl-eye” nuclei).
  • Shows background inflammatory infiltrate, not emperipolesis.

 

Option D. Kikuchi disease (Necrotizing histiocytic lymphadenitis):

 

  • Occurs in young women; features necrosis and karyorrhectic debris.
  • No emperipolesis, and histiocytes lack S100 expression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rosai–Dorfman disease is characterized by massive, painless cervical lymphadenopathy and the presence of emperipolesis — intact lymphocytes within the cytoplasm of S100-positive histiocytes.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with foul-smelling, blood-stained vaginal discharge mixed with mucus. On pelvic examination, there is a necrotic growth on the cervix with extension into the lateral parametrium. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chemoradiation

 

  • The patient’s presentation—postmenopausal age, foul-smelling bloody discharge, and necrotic cervical growth with parametrium involvement—is classic for locally advanced carcinoma cervix (Stage IIB).
  • According to the FIGO (International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics) staging system:
    • Stage IIB: Tumor extends beyond the cervix with parametrial involvement but not up to the pelvic wall.
    • Stages IIB to IVA are considered locally advanced cervical cancers.

 

Management of Stage IIB cervical cancer:

 

  • The treatment of choice is concurrent chemoradiation, which includes:
    • External beam radiotherapy (EBRT) to the pelvis
    • Intracavitary brachytherapy, and
    • Weekly cisplatin-based chemotherapy as a radiosensitizer
  • This combined approach improves local control, survival, and reduces recurrence compared to radiation alone.

 

Rationale:

 

  • Surgery (radical hysterectomy) is indicated only for early stages (IA to IB1), where parametrial invasion is absent.
  • Once the parametrium is involved, complete surgical resection is not feasible, and chemoradiation becomes the definitive treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chemotherapy: Systemic chemotherapy alone has a limited role in locally advanced cervical cancer. It may be used palliatively for recurrent or metastatic disease, not as initial therapy for Stage IIB disease.

 

Option B. Brachytherapy: Used as part of radiation therapy but not alone in cases with parametrial involvement. It is performed after EBRT to deliver a high dose to the tumor while sparing surrounding tissues.

 

Option D. External beam radiotherapy: Used in conjunction with chemotherapy and brachytherapy, but alone it provides inferior outcomes. Combining with chemotherapy (chemoradiation) increases radiosensitivity and survival rates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Stage IIB carcinoma of the cervix (tumor involving the parametrium but not the pelvic wall), the treatment of choice is concurrent chemoradiation, which includes external beam radiotherapy with weekly cisplatin chemotherapy followed by intracavitary brachytherapy.

questions.text: All of the following antimicrobial susceptibility methods provide quantitative MIC values, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Kirby-Bauer disk diffusion

 

  • The Kirby-Bauer disk diffusion method is a qualitative test, not a quantitative one. 
  • It involves placing antibiotic-impregnated disks on Mueller-Hinton agar where a lawn culture of the test organism has been inoculated. 
  • After incubation, the diameter of the zone of inhibition is measured and interpreted using CLSI guidelines to classify the organism as susceptible, intermediate, or resistant — but no MIC value is provided.
  • In contrast, the broth and agar dilution methods use serial dilutions of antibiotics to determine the lowest concentration that inhibits visible growth, thereby directly measuring the MIC. 
  • Similarly, the E-test combines both diffusion and dilution principles and produces a visible MIC value along the strip.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. E-test (Epsilometer test): This method yields a quantitative MIC by reading the point where the elliptical zone of inhibition intersects the calibrated strip.

 

Option B. Broth dilution method: Serial dilutions of the antibiotic in broth are inoculated with the test organism; the MIC is the lowest concentration without visible growth.

 

Option C. Agar dilution method: Similar to broth dilution, but the antibiotic is incorporated into agar; the lowest concentration preventing growth is recorded as the MIC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Only dilution-based methods (broth, agar, and E-test) provide direct quantitative MIC values. 
  • The Kirby-Bauer disk diffusion test provides qualitative results and does not yield an exact MIC.

choices.text: Small sized tumor but N1 axillary metastasis
History of previous breast or chest wall radiation

questions.text: Which of the options below is an acceptable condition for breast conservative surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Small sized tumor but N1 axillary metastasis

 

  • Small sized tumor with limited axillary nodal metastasis (N1) is acceptable for BCS. The presence of nodal disease is not a contraindication to breast-conserving surgery, as axillary dissection (or sentinel node biopsy) plus adjuvant therapy can adequately manage nodal involvement. 
  • The key requirement for BCS is that the primary tumor should be small enough relative to breast size to allow clear surgical margins with a good cosmetic outcome, and postoperative radiotherapy must be feasible.

 

Other Option:  

 

Option B. History of previous breast or chest wall radiation: This is a contraindication to BCS because radiation is mandatory after BCS, and re-irradiation is unsafe.

 

Option C. Severe orthopnea: This makes postoperative radiotherapy difficult to tolerate (lying flat for radiation sessions is essential), making it a contraindication to BCS.

 

Option D. Diffuse microcalcifications on a mammogram: This indicates widespread ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) or multifocal disease, which is a contraindication to BCS as adequate margins cannot be achieved.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Breast conservative surgery (BCS) is acceptable in small localized tumors (even with N1 nodal disease), provided clear margins can be achieved and radiotherapy is feasible. 
  • Contraindications include prior chest irradiation, diffuse microcalcifications, multicentric disease, pregnancy (relative), and inability to undergo radiotherapy.

questions.text: In a volunteer, 10 grams of mannitol was injected into the venous blood. At equilibrium, the urinary excretion of mannitol was found to be 10% and the plasma concentration of mannitol was measured at 60 mg/dl. Calculate the extracellular fluid (ECF) volume based on this information.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 15 L

 

  • We are using the formula to calculate the volume of distribution of mannitol, which is:

 

 

Where:

 

  • a = amount of mannitol injected (in grams)
  • e = amount of mannitol excreted (10% of injected amount)
  • c = concentration of mannitol in plasma (converted to grams per ml)

 

Step-by-step calculation:

 

  1. Amount injected (a):
    The total amount of mannitol injected is given as 10 grams.
  2. Amount excreted (e):
    10% of the injected mannitol is excreted:
    e=10% of 10 grams=1 gram
  3. Plasma concentration (c):
    The plasma concentration of mannitol is given as 60 mg/dl. To convert to grams per ml:
    60 mg/dl=0.6 grams/L=0.006 grams/ml
  4. Substitute into the formula:

 


 

Thus, the extracellular fluid volume is 15 liters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The formula for calculating the extracellular fluid (ECF) volume is based on the amount of substance injected, excreted, and the concentration remaining in the plasma. Here, the ECF volume is 15 liters.

choices.text: Presence of bronchiectasis on CT chest
Positive skin test to Aspergillus fumigatus

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with a history of asthma since childhood presents with worsening cough, wheeze, and expectoration of brownish mucus plugs. CT chest shows central bronchiectasis with mucus impaction. Her total serum IgE is 2200 IU/mL and peripheral eosinophil count is 1300/µL. Skin prick test to Aspergillus fumigatus is positive. Which of the following is essential for the diagnosis of the suspected condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Positive skin test to Aspergillus fumigatus

 

  • Allergic Bronchopulmonary Aspergillosis (ABPA) is an immunologic pulmonary disorder caused by hypersensitivity to Aspergillus fumigatus in patients with asthma or cystic fibrosis.
  • According to the 2021 ISHAM revised diagnostic criteria, the essential (mandatory) components for diagnosing ABPA are:

 

 

  • Hence, sensitization to A. fumigatus (by skin test or specific IgE) is the essential hallmark for diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Presence of bronchiectasis on CT chest: Supports diagnosis but is not essential — radiologic finding may be absent in early ABPA (called serologic ABPA).

 

Option B. Presence of asthma: It is a predisposing condition and not a mandatory criterion. 

 

Option C. Peripheral eosinophilia > 500/µL: Helpful supportive feature but not essential; can be absent if the patient is on corticosteroids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The essential diagnostic feature of ABPA is Aspergillus sensitization -  demonstrated by a positive skin test or specific IgE to A. fumigatus, along with elevated total IgE (≥500 IU/mL) and compatible clinical-radiologic findings.

choices.text: Fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) to rule out malignancy

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with a painful swelling near her previous cesarean section scar. She reports that the lump increases in size and becomes more painful during menstruation. On examination, there is a firm, tender nodule at the edge of the surgical scar. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Wide local excision

 

  • This patient presents with cyclic pain and swelling at a cesarean section scar, which is characteristic of scar endometriosis (abdominal wall endometriosis).
  • It occurs when endometrial tissue is implanted into the surgical wound during procedures like cesarean section, laparotomy, or episiotomy.

 

Pathophysiology:

 

  • During uterine surgery, endometrial cells may become inoculated in the wound.
  • Under hormonal influence, these cells undergo cyclical bleeding and inflammation, leading to painful swelling and fibrosis near the scar.

 

Diagnosis:

 

  • Clinical presentation is often diagnostic due to the triad:
    1. Previous uterine surgery
    2. Painful nodule near the scar
    3. Cyclic pain associated with menses
  • Imaging (ultrasound or MRI) may help delineate the lesion, but definitive diagnosis is by histopathology after surgical excision.

 

Management:

 

  • Wide local excision of the lesion with adequate margins is the treatment of choice.
  • Medical therapy (e.g., OCPs, progestins, GnRH analogs) may reduce symptoms but does not eliminate the lesion, and recurrence is common after discontinuation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) to rule out malignancy: Although FNAC can show endometrial cells, it is not recommended as the first step, since the lesion is clinically characteristic and FNAC may lead to seeding or inadequate diagnosis. Histopathological confirmation is obtained after excision.

 

Option C. Incision and drainage: Incorrect because the lesion is not an abscess. Incision and drainage would not relieve symptoms and could worsen scarring or spread endometrial tissue.

 

Option D. Trial of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs): NSAIDs may provide temporary pain relief, but they do not treat the underlying pathology. The definitive management is surgical excision.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a woman with painful, cyclic swelling near a surgical scar following cesarean delivery, the most likely diagnosis is scar endometriosis, and the definitive treatment is wide local excision with histopathological confirmation.

questions.text: Match the following clinical signs with their descriptions:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-B, 2-A, 3-C, 4-D

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Bruising patterns such as Cullen, Grey Turner, Fox, and Bryant signs are classic external markers of intra-abdominal or retroperitoneal hemorrhage, often seen in acute pancreatitis or ruptured abdominal/gynecological catastrophes.

questions.text:
Which of the following muscles are supplied by superficial peroneal nerve?

 

  1. Peroneus brevis
  2. Peroneus longus
  3. Peroneus tertius
  4. Extensor hallucis longus
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2 

 

  • The leg is divided into three compartments, each with its specific nerve supply. 
  • The lateral compartment of the leg contains only two muscles: peroneus longus and peroneus brevis. 
  • Both of these muscles are innervated by the superficial peroneal nerve.
  • The superficial peroneal nerve is the nerve of the lateral compartment and supplies:
    • Peroneus longus
    • Peroneus brevis
  • These muscles are responsible for eversion of the foot and play important roles in maintaining balance during walking and standing.

 

 

Incorrect Options:

 

3. Peroneus tertius: This muscle belongs to the anterior compartment of the leg, not the lateral compartment. According to Grey's Anatomy 42nd edition (page 1418), peroneus tertius is supplied by the deep peroneal nerve, which is the nerve of the anterior compartment. This is a common source of confusion as the name suggests it belongs with the other peroneus muscles, but anatomically it functions with the anterior compartment muscles.

 

4. Extensor hallucis longus: This muscle is located in the anterior compartment of the leg and is supplied by the deep peroneal nerve. It functions to extend the great toe and assist in dorsiflexion of the foot. The anterior compartment muscles include tibialis anterior, extensor digitorum longus, extensor hallucis longus, and peroneus tertius - all supplied by the deep peroneal nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The superficial peroneal nerve supplies only the two muscles of the lateral compartment of the leg: peroneus longus and peroneus brevis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman with myasthenia gravis presents with 2 weeks of progressive weakness - difficulty swallowing, speaking, and walking. She recently had an upper respiratory infection and stopped her medications (prednisolone, pyridostigmine) 2 months ago. She is tachypneic (RR 34/min), using accessory muscles, unable to lift her head, with bilateral ptosis, diplopia, and fatigable weakness of limbs. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Intubate

 

  • This presentation represents a myasthenic crisis - life-threatening respiratory muscle weakness due to exacerbation of myasthenia gravis, often precipitated by infection, medication withdrawal, or stress.

 

Key points:

 

  • Myasthenic crisis occurs in ~15–20% of MG patients.
  • Indications for intubation:
    • Vital capacity <15 mL/kg or
    • Negative inspiratory pressure less than 25 to 30 cm H₂O
  • Immediate management:
    1. Airway protection and mechanical ventilation.
    2. Rapid immunomodulation with plasmapheresis or IV immunoglobulin (IVIG).
    3. High-dose corticosteroids (e.g., IV methylprednisolone) to sustain long-term benefit.
    4. Hold pyridostigmine temporarily to prevent excess secretions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start Azathioprine: Used for long-term immunosuppression, not for acute crisis.

 

Option B. Resume pyridostigmine: Contraindicated during crisis — may increase airway secretions and worsen ventilation.

 

Option C. Start plasmapheresis: Non-invasive ventilation is insufficient in severe crisis; intubation is the standard for respiratory failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Myasthenic crisis = acute respiratory failure due to exacerbation of MG.
  • Immediate priorities: airway protection, mechanical ventilation, and rapid immunotherapy (plasmapheresis or IVIG).
  • Avoid cholinesterase inhibitors during crisis.
  • Reintroduce maintenance therapy (e.g., pyridostigmine, azathioprine) once the crisis resolves.

questions.text:
Regarding thyroid hormone synthesis and regulation, consider the following statements:

 

  1. Thyroid peroxidase catalyzes both iodination and coupling reactions.
  2. Peripheral conversion of T₄ to T₃ is inhibited by propranolol and glucocorticoids.
  3. TRH acts via a cAMP-mediated pathway in thyrotrophs.
  4. Iodide deficiency increases thyroidal T₃:T₄ ratio.

 

Which of the following is true?
