questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2 and 4 only

 

Statement 1. Thyroid peroxidase catalyzes both iodination and coupling reactions: Correct. Thyroid peroxidase (TPO) catalyzes both iodination (organification) and coupling of iodotyrosines (MIT, DIT).

 

Statement 2. Peripheral conversion of T₄ to T₃ is inhibited by propranolol and glucocorticoids: Correct. Propranolol, PTU, and glucocorticoids inhibit peripheral conversion of T₄ → T₃.

 

Statement 4. Iodide deficiency increases thyroidal T₃:T₄ ratio: Correct. In iodine deficiency, gland adapts by increasing T₃ over T₄ synthesis (T₃ more potent, less iodine needed).

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 3. TRH acts via a cAMP-mediated pathway in thyrotrophs: Incorrect. TRH acts through IP₃/DAG, not cAMP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

TPO is central to thyroid hormone synthesis, and T₃ production increases in iodine deficiency as an adaptive mechanism.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with cirrhosis (MELD 18) reports dyspnea that worsens when upright and improves when supine. An echocardiogram shows bubbles in the right heart followed by appearance in the left heart after 5 heartbeats. Arterial blood gas on room air: PaO₂ 55 mm Hg. ABG shows a PaO₂ of 55 mm Hg; CT chest is normal. Which condition would increase her liver transplant priority score?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) PaO₂ < 60 mmHg on room air

 

  • This patient has Hepatopulmonary Syndrome (HPS) — a complication of cirrhosis that causes intrapulmonary vascular dilatation and arterial hypoxemia.
  • Because her PaO₂ < 60 mmHg despite only moderate liver dysfunction, she qualifies for a MELD exception to receive higher transplant priority.

 

Criteria for HPS MELD Exception

 

 

  • If criteria are met → patient is granted MELD exception = Median MELD at Transplant (MMaT) (≈ MELD 22).

 

Common MELD Exceptions

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Age of 65: Age is not a prioritization factor.

 

Option B. MELD 18: This is the calculated score, not an exception.

 

Option D. Presence of severe portal hypertension: Confirms disease severity but does not affect MELD allocation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with Hepatopulmonary Syndrome (PaO₂ < 60 mmHg) who meet defined criteria are eligible for MELD exception points (MMaT ≈ 22), ensuring fair transplant prioritization for conditions where the lab-based MELD score underestimates true mortality risk.

choices.text: I – e, II – f, III – a, IV – g
I – f, II – h, III – b, IV – g
I – e, II – h, III – d, IV – g
I – d, II – f, III – b, IV – c

questions.text:
Match the following conditions with their associated pupillary findings: 

 

 

Which of the following is the correct match?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) I – f, II – h, III – b, IV – g

 

  • I – f. Pontine lesions → Pinpoint pupil: Pontine hemorrhage or infarct affects descending sympathetic fibers. Leads to bilateral pinpoint pupils due to unopposed parasympathetic activity.
  • II – h. Topical atropine → Pharmacologic mydriasis: Atropine is an anticholinergic and causes fixed dilated pupils.
  • III – b. Central retinal artery occlusion → Marcus Gunn pupil: Relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), aka Marcus Gunn pupil, is seen in severe retinal/optic nerve disease.
  • IV – g. Tabes dorsalis → Argyll Robertson pupil: Classically seen in neurosyphilis — small, irregular pupils that accommodate but don’t react to light.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Different neurological and pharmacological disorders produce specific pupillary abnormalities, such as:

 

  • Marcus Gunn pupil in CRAO,
  • Argyll Robertson pupil in neurosyphilis,
  • Pharmacological mydriasis with topical atropine,
  • Pinpoint pupils in pontine hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents with progressive proximal muscle weakness and joint pain for the past several months. She also reports shortness of breath and a dry cough. Physical examination reveals muscle tenderness in the shoulders and thighs and crackles at the lung bases. Laboratory testing shows elevated creatine kinase (CK) and a positive antinuclear antibody (ANA). Further serologic testing reveals the presence of anti–Jo-1 antibodies. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Polymyositis with interstitial lung disease

 

  • Anti–Jo-1 antibody is directed against histidyl-tRNA synthetase and is highly specific for Polymyositis and Dermatomyositis.
  • It is part of a group of antisynthetase antibodies, which are associated with the Antisynthetase Syndrome — a condition that combines inflammatory myopathy, arthritis, and interstitial lung disease (ILD).

 

Key Features of Polymyositis:

 

  • Autoimmune inflammatory myopathy characterized by T-cell–mediated muscle fiber injury.
  • Symmetrical proximal muscle weakness (difficulty climbing stairs, combing hair).
  • No skin involvement (distinguishing it from dermatomyositis).
  • Elevated muscle enzymes: Creatine kinase (CK), aldolase.
  • Muscle biopsy: Endomysial inflammation with CD8⁺ T cells.
  • Antibodies:
    • Anti–Jo-1 (Histidyl-tRNA synthetase) — most common.
    • Associated with interstitial lung disease and non-erosive arthritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mixed connective tissue disease (MCTD): Characterized by overlapping features of SLE, systemic sclerosis, and polymyositis. Associated with anti–U1 RNP antibodies, not anti–Jo-1.

 

Option C. Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE): Characterized by malar rash, nephritis, and hematologic abnormalities. Associated with anti–dsDNA and anti–Sm antibodies, not anti–Jo-1.

 

Option D. Rheumatoid arthritis (RA): Presents with chronic symmetric small joint inflammation. Associated with anti–CCP (cyclic citrullinated peptide) and rheumatoid factor (IgM against Fc portion of IgG), not anti–Jo-1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti–Jo-1 antibodies target histidyl-tRNA synthetase and are specific for Polymyositis (and sometimes Dermatomyositis). Their presence suggests Antisynthetase Syndrome, characterized by myositis, interstitial lung disease, arthritis, and Raynaud phenomenon.

questions.text: The image shows a type of hernia. Which of the following muscles or structures does not form a boundary of the anatomical space related to this hernia?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trapezius

 

  • The inferior lumbar triangle (Petit's triangle) is a weak anatomical area in the lower posterior abdominal wall through which lumbar hernias may occur.
  • Its boundaries are:
    • Anteriorly: External oblique muscle
    • Posteriorly: Latissimus dorsi muscle
    • Inferiorly: Iliac crest
    • Floor: Internal oblique muscle
  • The trapezius muscle lies superomedially and is not part of this triangle.
    When intra-abdominal pressure rises (e.g., due to coughing, straining, or lifting), the hernia may protrude through this weak area.
  • Thus, in this clinical scenario, the hernia occurs through the Petit's triangle, and trapezius does not form its boundary.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iliac crest: Incorrect. The iliac crest forms the inferior boundary of Petit's triangle and provides attachment for the external and internal oblique muscles, playing a structural role in the lower abdominal wall.

 

Option C. Latissimus dorsi: Incorrect. The latissimus dorsi forms the posterior boundary of the triangle and is a large, flat muscle involved in extension and adduction of the arm.

 

Option D. External oblique: Incorrect. The external oblique forms the anterior boundary of the triangle and is an important abdominal wall muscle contributing to trunk rotation and compression of abdominal contents.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Petit’s triangle (inferior lumbar triangle) is a potential site for lumbar hernias. 
  • It is bounded by the latissimus dorsi posteriorly, external oblique anteriorly, and iliac crest inferiorly, with the internal oblique forming its floor. 
  • The trapezius muscle is not part of this boundary.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy falls from a tree and sustains a rib fracture at the midaxillary line on the right side. He develops difficulty breathing, and investigations reveal a hemothorax with lung collapse. Which of the following is the most likely source of bleeding responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intercostal vessels

 

  • The intercostal vessels (posterior and anterior intercostal arteries and veins) lie within the costal groove along the inferior border of each rib, arranged from superior to inferior as: Vein → Artery → Nerve (VAN).
  • A rib fracture at the midaxillary line often injures these intercostal vessels, leading to bleeding into the pleural cavity (hemothorax). 
  • The blood accumulation compresses the lung, causing atelectasis and respiratory distress, as described in this case.
  • In a 3-year-old child, the ribs are relatively flexible but can still fracture under significant trauma, making the intercostal vessels vulnerable.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Internal thoracic artery: Incorrect. It runs parallel to the sternum, along the anterior chest wall, and would be injured only in parasternal fractures, not in lateral (midaxillary) rib injuries.

 

Option B. Pulmonary arteries:  Incorrect. These vessels are located deep within the lung tissue and are not directly affected by rib fractures. Injury here would cause a massive intrapulmonary hemorrhage, not a localized hemothorax.

 

Option D. Left common carotid artery: Incorrect. This vessel is located in the neck, supplying the head and upper extremities, and is unrelated to trauma in the thoracic wall.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A rib fracture at the midaxillary line commonly injures intercostal vessels, which run along the inferior margin of the ribs within the costal groove. Damage to these vessels causes bleeding into the pleural cavity, resulting in a hemothorax and potential lung collapse (atelectasis).

choices.text: Continue the NST for up to 40 minutes

questions.text: An NST is performed for a pregnant woman who presents with decreased fetal movements. The tracing shows 1 acceleration in 20 minutes and no decelerations. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Continue the NST for up to 40 minutes

 

  • The nonstress test (NST) evaluates fetal heart rate (FHR) accelerations in response to fetal movements to assess fetal oxygenation and neurologic integrity.
  • A healthy fetus exhibits periodic FHR accelerations due to an intact autonomic nervous system and adequate oxygenation.

 

NST Interpretation:

 

  • Reactive NST (normal):
    • At least 2 accelerations of ≥15 bpm above baseline lasting ≥15 seconds within 20 minutes (for gestation ≥32 weeks).
    • Indicates adequate fetal well-being.
  • Nonreactive NST:
    • Fewer than 2 accelerations in 20 minutes.
    • This can result from fetal sleep cycle, maternal medications, or fetal hypoxia.
  • Since fetal sleep cycles can last up to 40 minutes, the next best step after a nonreactive 20-minute NST is to continue monitoring for up to 40 minutes.
  • If the NST remains nonreactive after 40 minutes, further evaluation should be done with a biophysical profile (BPP) or contraction stress test (CST).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Induction of labor: Premature intervention — indicated only if further testing (BPP or CST) confirms fetal compromise.

 

Option C. Wait and watch: Inappropriate because immediate further evaluation (extending NST) is required, not passive observation.

 

Option D. Emergency lower segment cesarean section (LSCS): Not indicated after a single 20-minute nonreactive NST. Cesarean delivery is performed only for confirmed fetal distress or abnormal subsequent testing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

If a nonstress test shows only one acceleration in 20 minutes, it is nonreactive. The next step is to continue the NST for up to 40 minutes to allow for fetal sleep cycles before labeling it abnormal or proceeding with further fetal assessment.

questions.text: A 25-year-old farmer presents to the emergency department 2 hours after being stung by a scorpion on his right hand. He complains of severe pain at the sting site, profuse sweating, palpitations, and difficulty breathing. On examination, his BP is 180/110 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, and he has muscle fasciculations. What is the drug of choice for managing this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Prazosin

 

  • Prazosin is the drug of choice (DOC) for scorpion sting. Scorpion venom causes massive release of catecholamines leading to severe hypertension, tachycardia, and sympathetic overstimulation. 
  • Prazosin, being a selective α₁ blocker, effectively counteracts the α-adrenergic effects of the venom without causing severe tachycardia (unlike non-selective α blockers). 
  • The patient's presentation of hypertension, tachycardia, sweating, and muscle fasciculations is classic for scorpion envenomation requiring immediate α₁ blockade.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phenoxybenzamine: This is a non-selective, irreversible α blocker primarily used for pheochromocytoma. It would cause severe tachycardia and prolonged effects, making it unsuitable for scorpion sting management.

 

Option B. Propranolol: A non-selective β blocker would be contraindicated as it could worsen hypertension by blocking β₂-mediated vasodilation, leaving α₁-mediated vasoconstriction unopposed.

 

Option D. Phentolamine: Though a reversible α blocker, it's non-selective (α₁ + α₂) and would cause severe tachycardia due to α₂ blockade, making prazosin the preferred choice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prazosin is the drug of choice for scorpion sting due to its selective α₁ blocking property that effectively counters catecholamine-induced hypertension without causing severe reflex tachycardia.

choices.text: Case–control study comparing prior vaccination among GBS cases vs matched controls
RCT randomizing populations to vaccine vs placebo
Small case series of GBS patients describing recent vaccine exposure
Ecological study correlating monthly vaccine doses with GBS rates by state

questions.text: A new vaccine is suspected to cause Guillain–Barré syndrome (GBS), a rare outcome. You must choose a design that is most efficient and appropriate to quickly test the association.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Case–control study comparing prior vaccination among GBS cases vs matched controls

 

  • For rare outcomes, the case–control design is the most efficient analytic approach. 
  • Investigators ascertain all incident GBS cases within a defined catchment and select an appropriate set of controls from the same source population (matched on key factors such as age, calendar time, and geography). 
  • Prior exposure status (recent vaccination) is then ascertained from medical records/registries and compared between cases and controls.

 

Why this works well here:

 

  • Rarity of outcome: When the disease is uncommon, assembling a cohort large enough to accrue sufficient events is slow and expensive; case–control sampling focuses resources on all cases and a manageable number of controls.
  • Timeliness: Data can be pulled quickly from immunization registries and hospital records, enabling a prompt risk estimate—often as an odds ratio that approximates the relative risk when the outcome is rare.
  • Exposure windowing: Case–control studies can define biologically plausible risk windows (e.g., exposure within 6 weeks before symptom onset) to test temporality.
  • Advanced note: a self-controlled case series is another efficient vaccine-safety design, but it is not among the answer choices.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. RCT randomizing populations to vaccine vs placebo: Impractical and unethical for suspected harm: randomizing to withhold a recommended vaccine or to expose large numbers solely to detect rare adverse events would require very large sample sizes and long follow-up; moreover, RCTs are not typically the first-line tool for post-marketing safety signals.

 

Option C. Small case series of GBS patients describing recent vaccine exposure: Descriptive only (no control group). A list of GBS cases with recent vaccination cannot estimate risk or quantify association; it is useful for hypothesis generation but cannot test causality.

 

Option D. Ecological study correlating monthly vaccine doses with GBS rates by state: Compares group-level vaccine uptake and population GBS rates and is prone to ecological fallacy and confounding (e.g., changes in diagnostics or reporting). It does not provide valid individual-level risk estimates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When investigating a suspected association between vaccination and a rare adverse event (e.g., GBS), a case–control study is the most efficient and appropriate design—allowing rapid estimation of the association by comparing prior exposure among cases and suitable controls.

questions.text: Match the following staging systems with the tumors they are commonly used for:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-B, 2-C, 3-A

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Different cancers use specific staging systems:

 

  • Masaoka → thymoma
  • BCLC → hepatocellular carcinoma
  • Ann-Arbor → lymphomas

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with complaints of easy fatigability and muscle cramps after mild exercise. On examination, there is mild hepatomegaly. Laboratory studies show low blood glucose levels during fasting. A muscle biopsy reveals accumulation of glycogen with normal structure but decreased glycogen phosphorylase activity. Which of the following vitamins, when deficient, could most directly impair the function of this enzyme?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pyridoxal Phosphate (Vitamin B6)

 

  • The child presents with easy fatigability, muscle cramps after mild exercise, mild hepatomegaly, and hypoglycemia during fasting, which are characteristic findings of a glycogen storage disorder. 
  • The muscle biopsy showing normal-structured glycogen with decreased glycogen phosphorylase activity identifies this as a defect in glycogen breakdown — specifically McArdle disease (Type V) in muscle or Hers disease (Type VI) in the liver, depending on the isoenzyme affected.
  • Glycogen phosphorylase is the key enzyme responsible for cleaving α-1,4-glycosidic bonds in glycogen to release glucose-1-phosphate. 
  • This enzyme requires pyridoxal phosphate (Vitamin B6) as a coenzyme for its catalytic activity. 
  • A deficiency of Vitamin B6 would directly impair the function of glycogen phosphorylase, leading to decreased glycogen breakdown and resulting in exercise intolerance, fatigue, and fasting hypoglycemia due to reduced glucose availability.
  • Thus, Pyridoxal phosphate (Vitamin B6) is the vitamin whose deficiency would most directly impair glycogen phosphorylase function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiamine (Vitamin B1): Incorrect. Thiamine acts as a cofactor for enzymes such as pyruvate dehydrogenase, α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, and transketolase, which are involved in energy metabolism and the pentose phosphate pathway. While important for carbohydrate metabolism, it does not directly participate in the function of glycogen phosphorylase.

 

Option B. Niacin (Vitamin B3): Incorrect. Niacin is a precursor for NAD⁺ and NADP⁺, which are electron carriers in oxidation-reduction reactions such as glycolysis and the TCA cycle. Although niacin deficiency can affect energy production, it does not serve as a cofactor for glycogen phosphorylase, and hence does not directly impair glycogen breakdown.

 

Option D. Biotin (Vitamin B7): Incorrect. Biotin acts as a cofactor for carboxylase enzymes (e.g., pyruvate carboxylase, acetyl-CoA carboxylase, propionyl-CoA carboxylase), which are involved in gluconeogenesis and fatty acid synthesis, not glycogen breakdown. Hence, its deficiency would not impair glycogen phosphorylase activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pyridoxal phosphate (Vitamin B6) is a required coenzyme for glycogen phosphorylase, the enzyme responsible for glycogen breakdown. 
  • Deficiency of Vitamin B6 directly impairs glycogenolysis, leading to glycogen accumulation, muscle cramps, and hypoglycemia.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought by parents with complaints of inability to smile, difficulty in closing eyes, and convergent squint since birth. On examination, the child has facial diplegia, impaired abduction of both eyes, and poor sucking reflex in infancy. From most common to least common, which cranial nerves are affected in Möbius syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) VII, VI, XII

 

  • Möbius syndrome is a congenital non-progressive cranial nerve palsy, primarily involving the pons, due to hypoplasia or agenesis of the abducens (VI) and facial (VII) nuclei.
  • The most frequently affected nerve is the facial nerve (VII), followed by abducens (VI) and occasionally the hypoglossal (XII).
  • This combination explains facial paralysis, bilateral medial strabismus (due to loss of abduction), and tongue weakness.

 

Typical Clinical Features:

 

  • Bilateral facial paralysis (mask-like face, absent blinking, drooling)
  • Medial squint due to abducens palsy
  • Feeding and speech difficulty due to tongue weakness (XII)
  • Sometimes associated limb deformities (e.g., clubfoot, syndactyly)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. VI, XII, V: Trigeminal (V) is rarely involved.

 

Option B. VII, XII, VI: Order incorrect (VII most common, then VI, XII).

 

Option C. VI, VII, VIII: Vestibulocochlear nerve is not typically affected.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Möbius syndrome primarily affects facial (VII) and abducens (VI) nerves (pons level), sometimes hypoglossal (XII)—leading to bilateral facial paralysis and impaired eye abduction.

questions.text:
Regarding reflex arcs in human physiology, consider the following statements:

 

  1. The stretch reflex is the only monosynaptic reflex in humans.
  2. Reciprocal inhibition associated with the reflex is polysynaptic.
  3. The flexor withdrawal reflex is confined to a single spinal segment.
  4. The crossed-extensor reflex involves commissural interneurons.

 

Which of the following combinations is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 4 only

 

Statement 1. The stretch reflex is the only monosynaptic reflex in humans: Correct. The stretch (myotatic) reflex (e.g., patellar reflex) is monosynaptic, involving Ia afferent → α-motor neuron.

 

Statement 2. Reciprocal inhibition associated with the reflex is polysynaptic: Correct. Reciprocal inhibition uses interneurons to inhibit antagonistic muscle activity → polysynaptic.

 

Statement 4. The crossed-extensor reflex involves commissural interneurons: Correct. Crossed-extensor reflex involves commissural interneurons that project to the opposite side of the spinal cord.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 3. The flexor withdrawal reflex is confined to a single spinal segment: Incorrect. Flexor withdrawal reflex spreads to multiple segments through propriospinal pathways.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reflex integration in the spinal cord involves both monosynaptic and polysynaptic mechanisms, often spreading across multiple spinal levels.

choices.text: External rotation of hip/ Abduction of hip

questions.text: What is the primary action of the muscle attached to the area indicated by the arrow in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) External rotation of hip/ Abduction of hip

 

  • The arrow in the image points to the attachment site of the gluteus maximus muscle on the sacrum. 
  • The gluteus maximus is the largest and most superficial muscle of the gluteal region.
  • Anatomical details of gluteus maximus:
    • Origin: Posterior gluteal line, area behind posterior gluteal line, outer lip of iliac crest (posterior 1/3rd), adjacent surfaces of sacrum and coccyx, and sacrotuberous ligament
    • Insertion: Gluteal tuberosity of femur (1/4th) and iliotibial tract (3/4th)
    • Nerve supply: Inferior gluteal nerve (L5, S1, S2)
  • Actions of gluteus maximus:
  1. Primary action: Extension at hip joint (chief extensor) - helps in moving from sitting to standing position
  2. Secondary actions: 
    • External rotation of hip - due to its posterior placement and fiber direction
    • Abduction at hip - especially the upper fibers
    • Adduction at hip - especially the lower fibers
  • While extension at the hip would be the most accurate primary action, it is not listed among the options. 
  • Among the given choices, external rotation and abduction are both valid secondary actions of the gluteus maximus muscle.
  • The upper fibers of gluteus maximus, which attach more superiorly on the sacrum and iliac crest, particularly contribute to abduction of the hip. 
  • The muscle's position posterior to the hip joint axis makes it an effective external rotator of the femur.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medial rotation of hip: This is incorrect. The gluteus maximus causes external rotation of the hip, not medial rotation. Its fiber direction and position posterior to the hip joint make it an external rotator.

 

Option C. Flexion at knee: This is incorrect. The gluteus maximus primarily acts on the hip joint. While some fibers insert into the iliotibial tract which crosses the knee, the primary action is not knee flexion. The muscle does not significantly contribute to knee flexion.

 

Option D. Extension at knee: This is incorrect. Although some fibers of gluteus maximus insert into the iliotibial tract which crosses the lateral aspect of the knee, the muscle does not significantly contribute to knee extension. The primary knee extensors are the quadriceps muscles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The gluteus maximus muscle, attached to the sacrum and other posterior pelvic structures, primarily extends the hip and secondarily performs external rotation and abduction of the hip joint.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is most likely to prolong the action potential duration (APD) and delay repolarization in cardiac myocytes, thereby predisposing to prolonged QT interval?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Quinidine

 

  • The drug that prolongs action potential duration (APD) and delays repolarization, leading to a prolonged QT interval is a feature typical of Class IA antiarrhythmic drug like Quinidine.

 

Mechanism of Action by Class (Vaughan–Williams classification):

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Encainide (Class IC): Potently blocks Na⁺ channels but does not affect K⁺ channels. It has minimal or no effect on AP duration or QT interval.

 

Option C. Verapamil (Class IV): A calcium channel blocker that primarily affects AV nodal conduction, slowing the heart rate. It has little to no effect on ventricular AP duration or QT interval.

 

Option D. Lidocaine (Class IB): A weak Na⁺ channel blocker that shortens AP duration and decreases QT interval. Used mainly in ischemic ventricular arrhythmias, not supraventricular arrhythmias.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Quinidine’s QT prolongation can predispose to Torsades de Pointes — a potentially fatal ventricular arrhythmia. 
  • Always monitor ECG when using such drugs.

questions.text:
Which of the following patients is least suitable for implantation of a multifocal intraocular lens?

 

1. A 55-year-old teacher with mild myopic astigmatism
2. A 60-year-old with stable diabetic retinopathy
3. A 52-year-old software engineer with corneal scars
4. A 58-year-old without any systemic comorbidities
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 and 3 only

 

  • Multifocal intraocular lenses (IOLs) split light into multiple focal points, allowing patients to see at both near and far distances without glasses.
  • However, they also reduce contrast sensitivity and can cause glare and halos, making them unsuitable for patients with preexisting ocular pathology that already compromises visual quality.
  • Statement 2. A 60-year-old with stable diabetic retinopathy: Even when retinopathy is stable, diabetic retinal disease reduces contrast sensitivity and may worsen post-surgery with multifocal lenses. These patients are not ideal candidates due to the potential for suboptimal visual outcomes.
  • Statement 3. A 52-year-old software engineer with corneal scars: Corneal opacities scatter light, and the addition of a multifocal lens can exacerbate visual distortion. Patients with irregular corneal surfaces or scarring typically do poorly with multifocal IOLs.
  • Thus, patients 2 and 3 are least suitable for multifocal lens implantation.

 

Correct Statements:

 

Statements 1 and 4. A 55-year-old teacher with mild myopic astigmatism and A 58-year-old without any systemic comorbidities: Correct. Patient 1 has mild myopic astigmatism, which can be managed with laser correction or toric multifocal IOLs. Patient 4 is otherwise healthy. Both are potentially good candidates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multifocal intraocular lenses are contraindicated or discouraged in patients with ocular comorbidities that reduce contrast sensitivity, such as diabetic retinopathy and corneal scars. These conditions can lead to poor visual outcomes and patient dissatisfaction.

questions.text:
Which of the following postmortem findings are typically associated with the poisoning caused by the fruit/seeds shown in the image? 

 

 

  1. Early onset of rigor mortis due to violent convulsions.
  2. Congestion of viscera and petechial hemorrhages in serous membranes.
  3. Fixed and dilated pupils due to muscarinic stimulation.
  4. Extravasation of blood in voluntary muscles.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 4 only

 

  • The image shows Strychnos nux-vomica, a poisonous seed containing strychnine and brucine, potent neurotoxins. Strychnine acts by blocking glycine receptors in the spinal cord, leading to uncontrolled motor neuron stimulation and violent convulsions.

 

The postmortem findings reflect the extreme neuromuscular activity prior to death:

 

  • Statement 1. Early onset of rigor mortis due to violent convulsions: Due to intense muscle contraction before death.
  • Statement 2 and 4. Congestion of viscera and petechial hemorrhages in serous membranes and Extravasation of blood in voluntary muscles: Caused by repeated convulsive episodes.
  • Pupillary constriction (not dilation) is typically cholinergic, but muscarinic stimulation is not a feature of strychnine (this rules out statement 3).

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 3. Fixed and dilated pupils due to muscarinic stimulation: Incorrect. Fixed and dilated pupils are not a consistent finding in strychnine poisoning. The action is central via glycine inhibition, not through muscarinic receptors like in organophosphate or muscarine poisoning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In strychnine poisoning, the postmortem findings include early onset of rigor mortis, extravasated blood in muscles, and congested viscera, reflecting severe pre-mortem convulsions. 
  • Muscarinic features like fixed/dilated pupils are not typically seen.

choices.text: It reverses both depolarizing and non-depolarizing blockade
It forms an inclusion complex with aminosteroid neuromuscular blockers
It increases acetylcholine concentration at the neuromuscular junction
It is contraindicated in patients with renal impairment because it causes hepatotoxicity

questions.text: A 40-year-old male undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy receives rocuronium for neuromuscular blockade. At the end of surgery, the anesthetist decides to reverse the block using sugammadex. Which of the following statements about sugammadex is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It forms an inclusion complex with aminosteroid neuromuscular blockers

 

  • Sugammadex is a modified γ-cyclodextrin that encapsulates aminosteroid non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers such as rocuronium and vecuronium in a 1:1 inclusion complex. 
  • This binding reduces the free plasma concentration of the relaxant, creating a concentration gradient that draws the drug out of the neuromuscular junction back into plasma — leading to rapid reversal of paralysis.
  • It acts independently of acetylcholinesterase and thus avoids muscarinic side effects (e.g., bradycardia) typical of neostigmine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It reverses both depolarizing and non-depolarizing blockade: Incorrect. Sugammadex only works on aminosteroid non-depolarizing agents (rocuronium, vecuronium). It does not reverse depolarizing blockers such as succinylcholine or benzylisoquinoliniums like atracurium.

 

Option C. It increases acetylcholine concentration at the neuromuscular junction: Incorrect. This is the mechanism of neostigmine (AChE inhibitor), not sugammadex. Sugammadex acts by encapsulation and chemical inactivation of the relaxant.

 

Option D. It is contraindicated in patients with renal impairment because it causes hepatotoxicity: Incorrect. Sugammadex is renally excreted unchanged; caution or avoidance is due to renal accumulation, not liver toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sugammadex is a selective relaxant-binding agent that rapidly reverses rocuronium and vecuronium blockade by encapsulation, not by acetylcholinesterase inhibition.
  • It enables faster and more complete recovery with fewer cardiovascular side effects compared to neostigmine.

questions.text: At what gestational age should Group B Streptococcus (GBS) screening be performed in pregnant women according to ACOG guidelines to prevent early-onset neonatal sepsis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 35–37 weeks gestation

 

  • Group B Streptococcus (GBS) is a leading cause of early-onset neonatal sepsis (within the first 7 days of life). 
  • Vertical transmission occurs from a colonized mother during labor or rupture of membranes.
  • To prevent neonatal infection, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) recommends universal screening for maternal GBS colonization using a rectovaginal swab between 35–37 weeks gestation.
  • This time frame provides an accurate reflection of colonization status close to delivery.
  • Women who test positive for GBS should receive intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis (most commonly Penicillin G) during labor to prevent transmission to the neonate.

 

Indications for intrapartum prophylaxis:

 

  • Positive GBS screening at 35–37 weeks
  • Previous delivery of an infant with GBS disease
  • GBS bacteriuria during current pregnancy
  • Unknown GBS status with risk factors: preterm labor (<37 weeks), intrapartum fever (≥38°C), or prolonged rupture of membranes (>18 hours)

 

Educational Objective:

 

GBS screening should be performed at 35–37 weeks gestation using a rectovaginal swab. If the result is positive, intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis should be given to prevent early-onset neonatal GBS sepsis.

questions.text: A term baby is born with birth weight 2 kg and length 50 cm. PI is 1.6. Head circumference is normal. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Asymmetrical IUGR

 

Low weight with preserved length and HC. Ponderal Index < 2.0. Commonly due to placental insufficiency (late insult).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Symmetrical IUGR: Both weight and length are proportionally reduced; PI is normal or high, not low.

 

Option C. Preterm AGA: Preterm babies usually have normal or slightly high PI.

 

Option D. Normal term baby: PI 2.2–2.5 is normal. PI of 1.6 is low → abnormal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ponderal Index helps distinguish asymmetrical (low PI) from symmetrical (normal/high PI) IUGR in term infants.

choices.text: A woman with poorly controlled asthma and chronic urticaria
A woman with a history of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) and oligomenorrhea
A woman who recently recovered from viral hepatitis with mild liver enzyme elevation
A woman with irregular menstrual cycles due to dysfunctional uterine bleeding

questions.text: You are supervising a new community health worker in a government contraceptive distribution program. She shows you the medication in the image and asks which patient groups should avoid this drug. Which of the following patients is safest for this medication?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A woman with irregular menstrual cycles due to dysfunctional uterine bleeding

 

  • Centchroman (also known as Saheli or Chhaya) is a non-steroidal contraceptive with Selective Estrogen Receptor Modulator (SERM) activity.
  • It's approved in India and used in national contraceptive programs. Apart from its contraceptive effect, it is also used in the management of dysfunctional uterine bleeding, making Option D the best choice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A woman with poorly controlled asthma and chronic urticaria: Centchroman is contraindicated in severe allergic conditions, especially if they involve hypersensitivity.

 

Option B. A woman with a history of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) and oligomenorrhea (Stein-Leventhal syndrome): It is specifically contraindicated due to hormonal imbalance and poor cycle control.

 

Option C. A woman who recently recovered from viral hepatitis with mild liver enzyme elevation: Centchroman should be avoided in recent or active hepatic disorders due to its hepatic metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Centchroman is a weekly, non-steroidal contraceptive safe for use in women with dysfunctional uterine bleeding.
  • Contraindicated in:
    • PCOS,
    • Recent jaundice,
    • Severe allergic disorders,
    • Cervical hyperplasia.
  • Mechanism: SERM with anti-implantation and anti-estrogenic effects on the uterus.
  • Distributed free under India’s “Chhaya” program by the Ministry of Health.

questions.text: A 18-year-old boy is found unresponsive at home and is brought to the emergency department. His family reports that he ingested an unknown quantity of medication in a suicide attempt. On examination, he is somnolent, with shallow respiration at a rate of 8 breaths per minute and a blood pressure of 82/46 mmHg. Blisters are noted on his upper arm, as shown in the image. Laboratory results reveal a blood pH of 7.25, PaCO2 of 68 mmHg, and HCO3- of 24 mmol/L. Which of the following medications is most likely responsible for this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Phenobarbital

 

  • This patient presents with shallow respirations, hypotension, and a large pressure blister, which are characteristic of barbiturate poisoning (e.g., phenobarbital). 
  • Barbiturates depress the central nervous system, leading to respiratory depression, hypotension, and coma. 
  • Pressure blisters develop due to prolonged immobility, which causes localized pressure and ischemia.
  • Barbiturates also cause respiratory acidosis, as evidenced by the elevated PaCO2 and low pH in this patient’s arterial blood gas results. 
  • Hypotension occurs due to vasodilation and myocardial depression caused by barbiturates.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heroin: Opioid overdose can cause similar symptoms of respiratory depression and hypotension but is not typically associated with the development of pressure blisters.

 

Option C. Imipramine: Overdose with tricyclic antidepressants like imipramine can lead to anticholinergic toxicity, seizures, and cardiac arrhythmias. Pressure blisters are not a common finding in this condition.

 

Option D. Phenytoin: Phenytoin toxicity may cause neurological symptoms such as ataxia, nystagmus, and altered mental status, but it does not typically result in respiratory depression or pressure blister formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Barbiturate poisoning presents with central nervous system depression, respiratory acidosis, hypotension, and features such as pressure blisters due to prolonged immobility. 
  • Management includes supportive care and, in severe cases, the use of activated charcoal or hemodialysis.

questions.text:
Match the following anticancer drugs with their most characteristic dose-limiting toxicities:

 

 

Which of the following is the correct matching?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-b, 2-c, 3-a, 4-d

 

1. Vincristine → Peripheral neuropathy (b):

 

  • Mechanism: Microtubule inhibitor (vinca alkaloid).
  • Toxicity: Causes sensory and motor neuropathy, areflexia, foot drop, constipation, and cranial nerve palsies.
  • Mnemonic: “Vincristine → Neurotoxicity; Vinblastine → Blood toxicity (bone marrow suppression).”

 

2. Ifosfamide → Hemorrhagic cystitis (c):

 

  • Mechanism: Alkylating agent (nitrogen mustard analogue).
  • Toxicity: Acrolein metabolite causes hemorrhagic cystitis.
  • Prevention: Mesna (2-mercaptoethane sulfonate) binds and neutralizes acrolein in urine.
  • Also causes encephalopathy (due to chloroacetaldehyde).

 

3. Bleomycin → Flagellated dermatitis (a): 

 

  • Mechanism: Generates free radicals → DNA strand breaks.
  • Toxicities: Pulmonary fibrosis (dose-limiting) and flagellated hyperpigmentation (linear streaks on skin).
  • Mnemonic: “Bleo-marks (flagellated lines) on the skin.”

 

4. Capecitabine → Hand-foot syndrome (d):

 

  • Mechanism: Oral prodrug of 5-fluorouracil (5-FU).
  • Toxicity: Palmar–plantar erythrodysesthesia (hand-foot syndrome) – redness, pain, and peeling on palms and soles.
  • Mnemonic: “Capecitabine caps your hands and feet with redness.”

 

Educational Objective:

 

Each chemotherapeutic agent has a characteristic dose-limiting toxicity: vincristine (neuropathy), ifosfamide (hemorrhagic cystitis), bleomycin (flagellated dermatitis and pulmonary fibrosis), and capecitabine (hand-foot syndrome).

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of prostate cancer undergoes a percutaneous nephrostomy for obstructive uropathy. The interventional radiology team places the catheter shown in the image below. Which of the following best identifies the catheter in use?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Malecot catheter

 

  • The Malecot catheter is recognized by its winged, flower-petal–like tip, which provides anchorage in body cavities such as the renal pelvis.
  • It is frequently used in percutaneous nephrostomy to facilitate urinary diversion when retrograde access is not feasible or is contraindicated. 
  • The wings help it remain securely in position and prevent dislodgement.
  • It is particularly useful in:
    • Nephrostomy drainage
    • Suprapubic cystostomy
    • Pelvic abscess drainage
  • The image shows the classic flared, expanded distal tip design, confirming it as a Malecot catheter.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Foley catheter: Incorrect. A Foley catheter has a balloon at the tip and is used for bladder drainage via the urethra. It lacks the winged tip characteristic of a Malecot catheter.

 

Option C. Jackson-Pratt drain: Incorrect. A Jackson-Pratt (JP) drain is a closed-suction surgical drain with a bulb at the end and is typically used postoperatively for serous or blood fluid drainage, not urinary diversion.

 

Option D. Mushroom catheter: Incorrect. The Mushroom catheter, or Pezzer catheter, also has a retention head but is shaped more like a rounded button or mushroom cap. It is not winged and is typically used for bladder drainage in suprapubic catheterization, not renal pelvis drainage.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Malecot catheter features a winged tip for anchorage and is commonly used in procedures like percutaneous nephrostomy for urinary drainage from the renal pelvis.

choices.text: Rigor mortis allows joint movement with moderate resistance unless fully developed
Cold stiffening produces a “crackling” sensation on movement if attempted before thawing
Heat stiffening is pliable and allows easy joint extension
Rigor mortis disappears sequentially; heat and cold stiffening disappear uniformly

questions.text: All of the following are correct regarding joint manipulation during various types of postmortem stiffening, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Heat stiffening is pliable and allows easy joint extension

 

  • Heat stiffening results from coagulation of muscle proteins due to exposure to high temperatures (≥65°C), such as in burns or electrocution. 
  • This causes the body to become extremely rigid, and joint manipulation is difficult, often risking rupture of muscles.
  • Hence, Option C is false — heat stiffening is not pliable; in fact, it is more rigid than rigor mortis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rigor mortis allows joint movement with moderate resistance unless fully developed: True. Early rigor can be overcome with moderate force; fully developed rigor offers more resistance but doesn't lead to rupture.

 

Option B. Cold stiffening produces a “crackling” sensation on movement if attempted before thawing: True. The frozen state of the muscles and joints leads to a crepitus-like sensation if manipulated before thawing.

 

Option D. Rigor mortis disappears sequentially; heat and cold stiffening disappear uniformly: True. Rigor mortis passes in a head-to-toe sequence, whereas heat and cold stiffening disappear suddenly, typically with putrefaction (heat) or on thawing (cold).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Heat stiffening results from thermal coagulation of muscle proteins and leads to extreme, non-pliable rigidity that cannot be reversed by ordinary manipulation — unlike rigor mortis, which develops gradually and can be overcome in early stages.

questions.text: Which type of gland is depicted in the histological image given below?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Holocrine gland

 

  • The image shows sebaceous glands, which are holocrine glands associated with hair follicles.
  • In holocrine secretion, the entire secretory cell ruptures to release its contents — a mixture of lipids, cell debris, and sebum. 
  • This mechanism provides lubrication and waterproofing for the skin and hair.
  • The glandular cells undergo continuous mitosis at the base, replacing the ones lost during secretion. 
  • These glands are most numerous on the face, scalp, and upper trunk, and their activity increases during puberty under androgen stimulation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Merocrine gland: Incorrect. Merocrine glands release their secretions via exocytosis without cell damage (e.g., eccrine sweat glands and pancreatic acini).

 

Option B. Endocrine gland: Incorrect. Endocrine glands are ductless and secrete hormones directly into the bloodstream (e.g., thyroid, adrenal). Sebaceous glands release onto the skin surface, not into blood.

 

Option D. Apocrine gland: Incorrect. Apocrine glands release secretion by pinching off part of the apical cytoplasm (e.g., mammary glands, sweat glands in the axilla).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sebaceous glands are holocrine glands whose secretory cells disintegrate to release sebum. This distinguishes them from merocrine (exocytotic) and apocrine (apical shedding) glands.

questions.text:
A neonatology resident is evaluating a 4-week-old male infant presenting with persistent vomiting. Consider the following statements regarding infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS). Which of the statements is true? 

 

  1. The most common presentation is non-bilious projectile vomiting.
  2. An olive-shaped mass may be palpable in the epigastrium or right upper quadrant, and on test feeding, visible peristalsis moves from left to right across the abdomen.
  3. The condition is most commonly seen between 3 and 6 weeks of age, with females at the highest risk.
  4. The fluid for correction is DNS + KCl (0.15%) after stabilizing dehydration and electrolyte imbalance.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2 and 4 are correct

 

Statement 1. The most common presentation is non-bilious projectile vomiting: Correct. IHPS typically presents with progressive, non-bilious projectile vomiting after 2–8 weeks of life (not at birth).

 

Statement 2. An olive-shaped mass may be palpable in the epigastrium or right upper quadrant, and on test feeding, visible peristalsis moves from left to right across the abdomen: Correct. The classic finding is an olive-shaped mass in the RUQ/epigastrium, with visible left-to-right gastric peristalsis after a test feed.

 

Statement 4. The fluid for correction is DNS + KCl (0.15%) after stabilizing dehydration and electrolyte imbalance: Correct. Initial management is fluid and electrolyte correction — DNS + KCl (0.15%) is appropriate before surgery.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 3. The condition is most commonly seen between 3 and 6 weeks of age, with females at the highest risk: Incorrect. The most common age group is indeed 3–6 weeks, but first-born males (not females) are at highest risk.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis presents at 2–8 weeks with non-bilious projectile vomiting, palpable “olive” mass, and visible peristalsis. First-born males are most at risk. 
  • Treatment includes initial fluid/electrolyte stabilization followed by Ramstedt pyloromyotomy.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man presents with new-onset seizures. MRI brain with contrast reveals a ring-enhancing lesion. Which of the following conditions are most likely to present with such radiologic findings? 

 

  1. Brain abscess
  2. Resolving hematoma
  3. Primary CNS lymphoma
  4. Encephalopathy
  5. Infarction
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2 and 3

 

  • Ring-enhancing lesions on CT/MRI occur when there is a central area of necrosis, liquefaction, or cystic change surrounded by a rim of active inflammation, granulation tissue, or tumor. 
  • These appear as rings of enhancement after contrast administration.

 

1. Brain abscess: Classic cause. Central necrosis of infection is surrounded by granulation tissue and a capsule, producing ring enhancement.

 

2. Resolving hematoma: As blood products break down, granulation tissue with leaky capillaries leads to ring enhancement.

 

3. Primary CNS lymphoma: Can present as ring-enhancing lesions, especially in immunocompromised patients (e.g., HIV, transplant recipients). Enhancement may be homogeneous but can also be ring-like if central necrosis occurs.

 

Incorrect options:

 

4. Encephalopathy: Usually shows diffuse or patchy non-enhancing white matter changes, not a discrete ring.

 

5. Infarction: Acute/subacute infarcts enhance patchily or diffusely; frank ring enhancement is unusual and nonspecific unless there is hemorrhagic transformation or abscess formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ring-enhancing brain lesions are most classically seen in brain abscesses, resolving hematomas, and CNS lymphoma. 
  • Encephalopathy and uncomplicated infarction do not typically present with ring enhancement.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is fasting overnight. His liver begins to produce glucose via gluconeogenesis to maintain blood glucose levels. Some of the enzymes used in this pathway are also shared with glycolysis, while others are unique. Which of the following enzymes is common to both glycolysis and gluconeogenesis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Phosphoglycerate kinase

 

This enzyme catalyzes the reversible reaction: 1,3-bisphosphoglycerate ⇌ 3-phosphoglycerate, and thus functions in both glycolysis and gluconeogenesis.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Pyruvate kinase: False. Catalyzes the final irreversible step in glycolysis (PEP → pyruvate).


In gluconeogenesis, this step is bypassed by pyruvate carboxylase and PEP carboxykinase.

 

Option B. Phosphofructokinase: False. Catalyzes the irreversible step fructose-6-phosphate → fructose-1,6-bisphosphate in glycolysis.
In gluconeogenesis, it is bypassed by fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase.

 

Option C. Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase: False. Functions only in gluconeogenesis (oxaloacetate → PEP).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Phosphoglycerate kinase is one of the reversible enzymes shared by glycolysis and gluconeogenesis. 
  • It catalyzes the interconversion of 1,3-bisphosphoglycerate and 3-phosphoglycerate, utilizing or generating ATP depending on the metabolic direction.

questions.text:
Match each disease in Column I with the corresponding defective DNA repair mechanism in Column II. 

 

Column I (Disease)

 

  1. Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID)
  2. Xeroderma Pigmentosum
  3. Hereditary Nonpolyposis Colorectal Cancer (HNPCC)
  4. MUTYH-associated Polyposis (MAP)

 

Column II (Defective Repair Mechanism)

 

  1. Base Excision Repair
  2. Nucleotide Excision Repair
  3. Mismatch Repair
  4. Non-Homologous End Joining
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-D, 2-B, 3-C, 4-A

 

  • 1-D. Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID) — Defective Non-Homologous End Joining: SCID, particularly the form caused by defects in DNA-dependent protein kinase (DNA-PK) or Artemis, involves failure of V(D)J recombination during B and T cell receptor formation. This recombination process depends on non-homologous end joining (NHEJ) to repair double-stranded DNA breaks. Thus, a defect in NHEJ leads to lymphocyte maturation failure, resulting in combined immunodeficiency.
  • 2-B. Xeroderma Pigmentosum (XP) — Defective Nucleotide Excision Repair: XP is characterized by extreme UV sensitivity and predisposition to skin cancers due to mutations in genes responsible for nucleotide excision repair (NER). NER normally removes bulky thymine dimers and pyrimidine dimers caused by UV light. Defective NER results in the accumulation of UV-induced DNA damage.
  • 3-C. Hereditary Nonpolyposis Colorectal Cancer (HNPCC or Lynch Syndrome) — Defective Mismatch Repair: HNPCC is caused by germline mutations in DNA mismatch repair (MMR) genes such as MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, and PMS2. These genes correct base-pair mismatches and microsatellite instability that occur during DNA replication. Loss of mismatch repair leads to microsatellite instability and promotes colorectal and endometrial cancers.
  • 4-A. MUTYH-Associated Polyposis (MAP) — Defective Base Excision Repair: The MUTYH gene encodes a DNA glycosylase involved in base excision repair (BER), which removes oxidatively damaged bases such as 8-oxoguanine. Mutations in MUTYH impair BER, causing accumulation of base substitution mutations and leading to multiple colorectal adenomas and cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Different DNA repair mechanisms correct specific types of DNA damage:

 

  • Non-Homologous End Joining → SCID
  • Nucleotide Excision Repair → Xeroderma Pigmentosum
  • Mismatch Repair → HNPCC
  • Base Excision Repair → MUTYH-Associated Polyposis

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman para 1, living 1, is currently on warfarin therapy for treatment of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). She seeks a reliable method of contraception. Which of the following contraceptive options should be avoided in her case?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vaginal combined hormonal ring (NuvaRing)

 

  • Women with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or on anticoagulant therapy (such as warfarin) have a high risk of thromboembolic events. 
  • Therefore, contraceptive methods containing estrogen are contraindicated, as estrogen increases the risk of venous thromboembolism (VTE) by promoting hepatic synthesis of clotting factors (II, VII, IX, X) and decreasing antithrombin III activity.
  • The NuvaRing is a combined hormonal contraceptive device that releases ethinyl estradiol (estrogen) and etonogestrel (progestin). Because of its estrogen component, it is contraindicated in:
    • Women with active or prior DVT or PE
    • Women on anticoagulation therapy (e.g., warfarin)
    • Women with known thrombophilia
  • Therefore, in this patient with DVT on warfarin, the NuvaRing must be avoided.
  • Safe alternatives include progestin-only and nonhormonal methods, which have no significant impact on coagulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Levonorgestrel intrauterine device (LNG-IUD): Safe and effective in women with DVT. The LNG-IUD releases local progestin, has minimal systemic absorption, and does not increase thrombosis risk.

 

Option B. Depot medroxyprogesterone acetate (DMPA) injection: A progestin-only contraceptive that does not contain estrogen. It is safe in women with DVT, although prolonged use may decrease bone mineral density.

 

Option C. Etonogestrel implant (Implanon): Also a progestin-only method with minimal thrombotic risk. It is safe for women with a history of DVT or on anticoagulants.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In women with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or on anticoagulant therapy, estrogen-containing contraceptives (such as the vaginal ring, combined oral pills, or transdermal patches) are contraindicated due to the increased risk of venous thromboembolism. Progestin-only or nonhormonal methods are preferred.

choices.text: Immune complex deposition in dermal vessels
Type I IgE-mediated mast cell degranulation

questions.text: A 50-year-old female develops targetoid skin lesions with central necrosis after starting phenytoin therapy. She also develops erosions on lips and buccal mucosa, and conjunctivitis. Pseudonikolsky sign is positive. Which of the following best explains the underlying pathogenesis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cytotoxic T-cell–mediated keratinocyte apoptosis

 

  • The description fits Stevens–Johnson syndrome (SJS), a severe mucocutaneous drug reaction.
  • Mechanism: CD8+ cytotoxic T-cells induce keratinocyte apoptosis via Fas–FasL interaction → epidermal necrosis.
  • Common drugs: Sulfonamides, phenytoin, carbamazepine, allopurinol, NSAIDs.
  • Nikolsky sign positive due to epidermal detachment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immune complex deposition in dermal vessels: Occurs in vasculitis, not in drug-induced epidermal necrosis.

 

Option C. Autoantibody against desmoglein 3: Seen in pemphigus vulgaris, not SJS/TEN.


Option D. Type I IgE-mediated mast cell degranulation: Causes urticaria, not necrotic epidermal detachment.

 

Educational Objective:


SJS/TEN represents a type IV (cytotoxic T-cell–mediated) hypersensitivity reaction with keratinocyte apoptosis leading to epidermal necrolysis and mucosal involvement.

choices.text: Lower BP immediately to <185/110 mm Hg
Reduce by about 15% during the first 24 hours
Lower BP rapidly to <140/90 within 2 hours to prevent hemorrhagic transformation
Initiate oral antihypertensive therapy and observe

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with 6 hours of right-sided weakness and slurred speech. CT brain shows an acute left MCA infarct without hemorrhage. He has no prior hypertension or diabetes. On arrival: BP 230/140 mm Hg, HR 88 bpm, and no pulmonary edema or aortic dissection. What is the most appropriate blood pressure management strategy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reduce by about 15% during the first 24 hours

 

  • In acute ischemic stroke (AIS), permissive hypertension is allowed to maintain cerebral perfusion in the ischemic penumbra.
  • Overly rapid BP reduction may worsen cerebral ischemia by reducing perfusion pressure.

 

Guideline-based approach:

 

 

  • Since this patient is not receiving thrombolysis and has no hypertensive emergency, the correct strategy is gradual reduction (~15%) in 24 hours.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lower BP immediately to <185/110 mm Hg: Applies only to patients eligible for thrombolysis (tPA).

 

Option C. Lower BP rapidly to <140/90 within 2 hours to prevent hemorrhagic transformation: Rapid reduction may reduce cerebral perfusion, worsening infarct.

 

Option D. Initiate oral antihypertensive therapy and observe: Delays controlled reduction; IV titratable agents (e.g., labetalol, nicardipine) preferred for safe, gradual lowering.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In acute ischemic stroke without thrombolysis, avoid aggressive BP lowering unless >220/120 mm Hg.
  • Aim for ~15% reduction in the first 24 hours to balance perfusion and safety.
  • Preferred IV agents: labetalol, nicardipine, or clevidipine (titrated to effect).

questions.text: A 56-year-old man with ADPKD presents with fever, left flank pain, dysuria, and pyuria. Both kidneys are palpable and the left flank is tender. Labs show WBC 14.7 × 10⁹/L, CRP 45 mg/L, and Urinanalysis shows pus cells and blood. Which antibiotics should be started empirically?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ciprofloxacin + co-trimoxazole

 

  • In ADPKD with suspected infected renal cysts/pyelonephritis, the empiric regimen should include agents that penetrate cysts and cover Enterobacterales (e.g., E. coli, Klebsiella, Proteus).
  • Fluoroquinolones (e.g., ciprofloxacin) and co-trimoxazole are lipid-soluble and cross cyst epithelium, achieving therapeutic intra-cyst concentrations and providing broad Gram-negative coverage.
  • Cyst aspiration for culture is the gold standard to direct therapy, but treatment should begin empirically while awaiting results.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amoxicillin + metronidazole: Inadequate Gram-negative aerobic coverage; metronidazole targets anaerobes, which are uncommon in this setting.

 

Option C. Gentamicin + cefixime: Gentamicin has poor cyst penetration and nephrotoxicity risk; cefixime (oral 3rd-gen) alone is suboptimal empirically.

 

Option D. Vancomycin + linezolid: Primarily anti-Gram-positive (including MRSA); insufficient Enterobacterales coverage and not first-line for presumed cyst/urinary Gram-negative infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In ADPKD with suspected infected cysts, choose lipid-soluble antibiotics that penetrate cysts and provide Gram-negative coverage (e.g., fluoroquinolones or co-trimoxazole). 
  • Obtain urine and blood cultures, consider imaging (CT/US) if abscess suspected, and perform cyst aspiration when diagnosis is uncertain or response is poor.

questions.text: The bed net in the image is distributed by government under vector control program. Which of the following insecticides is most likely used to treat this net?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Deltamethrin

 

  • LLINs (Long-Lasting Insecticidal Nets) are pre-treated bed nets with synthetic pyrethroids. 
  • They are a cost-effective, WHO-endorsed strategy for malaria control and prevention.
  • Deltamethrin is the most widely used synthetic pyrethroid in LLINs.
  • It kills mosquitoes upon contact and provides protection even after multiple washes (up to 20+ times).
  • Effectiveness lasts for 3 years or more, depending on use and washing frequency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DDT: An organochlorine insecticide. Though historically used in indoor residual spraying, it is not used for bed net treatment due to safety/environmental concerns.

 

Option B. Malathion: An organophosphate. Used in fogging/spraying for vector control (e.g., dengue, filariasis) but not suitable for treating fabric like bed nets.

 

Option D. DEET: A topical repellent, not an insecticide. Applied to skin, not used for bed net impregnation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • LLINs impregnated with deltamethrin are a cornerstone of malaria control. They reduce mosquito density and interrupt transmission. 
  • The use of safe, effective insecticides like pyrethroids ensures broad coverage and community-level protection in endemic areas.

questions.text: Within a multienzyme mitochondrial complex that converts pyruvate into acetyl-CoA, which specific enzyme catalyzes the reoxidation of reduced lipoamide by transferring electrons first to FAD and then to NAD?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase

 

  • The mitochondrial enzyme complex responsible for oxidative decarboxylation of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA operates through a series of enzymatic steps requiring multiple cofactors (TPP, lipoic acid, CoA, FAD, and NAD⁺).
  • Within this system:
    • Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase (E3) is the enzyme that reoxidizes reduced lipoamide, restoring it to its oxidized form so the catalytic cycle can continue.
    • During this process, electrons are transferred from lipoamide to FAD, forming FADH₂, and then from FADH₂ to NAD⁺, producing NADH + H⁺.
      This regeneration of cofactors is essential to maintain continuous conversion of pyruvate into acetyl-CoA and energy production in the mitochondria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dihydrolipoyl transacetylase: Transfers the acetyl group from lipoamide to coenzyme A to form acetyl-CoA but does not regenerate lipoamide or handle electron transfer.

 

Option C. Citrate synthase: A citric acid cycle enzyme that catalyzes condensation of acetyl-CoA with oxaloacetate to form citrate, unrelated to lipoamide oxidation.

 

Option D. α-Ketoglutarate dehydrogenase: Although mechanistically similar (it also requires lipoamide, FAD, and NAD⁺), it functions in the citric acid cycle, not in the oxidative decarboxylation of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase reoxidizes reduced lipoamide by transferring electrons to FAD and then NAD⁺, producing NADH and regenerating the enzyme complex for continued catalytic activity.

questions.text:
Regarding the Achilles tendon, which of the following statements are correct? 

 

  1. It is formed by the tendinous union of gastrocnemius and soleus muscles.
  2. It is supplied by the superficial peroneal nerve.
  3. It inserts into the posterior surface of the calcaneus.
  4. Its primary action is plantar flexion at the ankle joint.
  5. It is the strongest tendon in the human body.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 3, 4, and 5

 

Statement 1. It is formed by the tendinous union of gastrocnemius and soleus muscles: It is formed by the union of the gastrocnemius and soleus muscles, occasionally receiving fibers from the plantaris muscle.

 

Statement 3. It inserts into the posterior surface of the calcaneus: It inserts into the middle portion of the posterior surface of the calcaneus.

 

Statement 4. Its primary action is plantar flexion at the ankle joint: It produces plantar flexion at the ankle joint and assists in knee flexion.

 

Statement 5. It is the strongest tendon in the human body: The Achilles tendon (tendo calcaneus) is the thickest and strongest tendon in the human body.

 

 

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 2. It is supplied by the superficial peroneal nerve: The Achilles tendon is not supplied by the superficial peroneal nerve; it receives innervation from the tibial nerve (S1, S2).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Achilles tendon, formed by the gastrocnemius and soleus, is the strongest tendon in the body, inserts into the posterior calcaneus, and is responsible for plantar flexion of the foot. 
  • It is supplied by the tibial nerve (S1, S2).

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents with a rapidly enlarging, non-tender testicular mass. Serum studies reveal a markedly elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) level. Histopathologic examination of the tumor is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Yolk sac tumor

 

  • Yolk sac tumor (endodermal sinus tumor) is the most common testicular tumor in children under 3- years and a malignant germ cell tumor derived from yolk sac elements.
  • Histopathology: The presence of Schiller-Duval bodies, which are glomerulus-like structures with a central blood vessel surrounded by tumor cells in a cystic space lined by more tumor cells, is pathognomonic.
  • Immunohistochemistry and markers:
    • AFP (alpha-fetoprotein): Elevated in serum.
    • Cytokeratin: Positive.
    • PLAP (Placental Alkaline Phosphatase): Typically, negative.
  • Gross appearance: Often mucinous, yellow-tan, and hemorrhagic.
  • The tumor mimics primitive yolk sac and endodermal sinus structures, explaining its name.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Embryonal carcinoma: Occurs in young adults, composed of pleomorphic cells with indistinct borders and prominent nucleoli; lacks Schiller-Duval bodies and does not elevate AFP as consistently.

 

Option B. Choriocarcinoma: Highly malignant tumor with cytotrophoblastic and syncytiotrophoblastic cells, associated with elevated β-hCG, not AFP.

 

Option D. Seminoma: Composed of uniform cells with clear cytoplasm and central nuclei, resembling “fried-egg” appearance; PLAP positive, AFP negative, and Schiller-Duval bodies absent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Schiller-Duval bodies—glomerulus-like structures with a central vessel—are pathognomonic for Yolk Sac Tumor, which is the most common testicular neoplasm in children and shows elevated serum AFP levels.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding anti-androgen therapies is/are true? 

 

  1. Flutamide antagonizes the effects of testosterone at the hypothalamus, leading to decreased LH release.
  2. Dutasteride decreases the formation of DHT and is useful in BPH patients. 
  3. Flutamide monotherapy may paradoxically increase serum testosterone levels via loss of negative feedback.
  4. Bicalutamide selectively inhibits 5α-reductase in the prostate.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 and 3 only.

 

  • Statement 2. Dutasteride decreases the formation of DHT and is useful in BPH patients: True. Dutasteride is a 5α-reductase inhibitor that blocks both type I and type II isoenzymes. This leads to decreased conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT), a more potent androgen that plays a significant role in prostate tissue growth. It is commonly used in the management of BPH to reduce prostate size and improve urinary symptoms.
  • Statement 3. Flutamide monotherapy may paradoxically increase serum testosterone levels via loss of negative feedback: True. Flutamide is a nonsteroidal androgen receptor antagonist. When used as monotherapy, it blocks androgen receptors at the hypothalamus and pituitary. This inhibition removes the normal negative feedback exerted by androgens, leading to increased luteinizing hormone (LH) release, and consequently elevated testosterone levels from the testes.

 

False Statements:

 

Statement 1. Flutamide antagonizes the effects of testosterone at the hypothalamus, leading to decreased LH release: False. Flutamide does not decrease LH release; rather, it increases LH due to blockade of androgen receptors at the hypothalamic-pituitary axis. This results in loss of negative feedback, which causes the hypothalamus to increase gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) secretion, stimulating the pituitary to release more LH.

 

Statement 4. Bicalutamide selectively inhibits 5α-reductase in the prostate: False. Bicalutamide is a nonsteroidal androgen receptor antagonist, not a 5α-reductase inhibitor. It blocks the action of androgens at their receptor sites, particularly in the prostate, but it does not affect the enzymatic conversion of testosterone to DHT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dutasteride inhibits 5α-reductase to reduce DHT production in BPH, while flutamide monotherapy increases LH and testosterone by removing androgen negative feedback at the hypothalamus.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male renal transplant recipient presents with dysuria, suprapubic pain, and alkaline urine (pH 8.5) for the past 3 weeks. Cystoscopy reveals white-gray plaques adherent to the bladder mucosa. Which organism is most likely responsible for this patient's encrusted cystitis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Corynebacterium urealyticum

 

  • This patient presents with classic features of alkaline encrusted cystitis, a rare but serious urinary tract infection characterized by alkaline urine and struvite stone formation on the bladder wall. 
  • C. urealyticum is a skin commensal that uniquely causes this condition, particularly in immunocompromised patients such as renal transplant recipients.
  • The key diagnostic features include:
    • Strong urease production leading to urea hydrolysis and ammonia formation
    • Resultant alkaline urine (pH > 7)
    • Formation of struvite (magnesium ammonium phosphate) crystals that encrust the bladder mucosa
    • Slow growth requiring extended incubation (48-72 hours)
    • Occurrence primarily in immunocompromised hosts
  • The organism's potent urease activity is central to its pathogenesis, creating the alkaline environment necessary for struvite precipitation and the characteristic encrusted plaques seen on cystoscopy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Corynebacterium xerosis: This is a common skin commensal that rarely causes infections. It does not produce significant urease activity and is not associated with encrusted cystitis or alkaline urine. It may occasionally cause prosthetic device infections but not the clinical presentation described.

 

Option C. Corynebacterium renale: This organism primarily causes urinary tract infections in cattle and other animals, not humans. While it can produce urease, it is not a human pathogen and would not be isolated from a human transplant recipient with encrusted cystitis.

 

Option D. Corynebacterium pseudotuberculosis: This species causes caseous lymphadenitis in sheep and goats, and rarely causes lymphadenitis in humans with animal contact. It does not cause urinary tract infections or encrusted cystitis, and lacks the strong urease activity characteristic of C. urealyticum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Corynebacterium urealyticum causes alkaline encrusted cystitis through strong urease production, leading to alkaline urine and struvite stone formation on bladder mucosa, particularly in immunocompromised and renal transplant recipients.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with progressive headaches, seizures, and subtle personality changes over several months. MRI of the brain reveals a well-circumscribed, calcified mass in the frontal lobe. Histopathologic examination of the biopsy is shown in the image below. Which of the following genetic abnormalities is most characteristic of this tumor?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1p/19q codeletion

 

  • The described findings are classic for an oligodendroglioma, a diffusely infiltrating glioma that typically arises in the cerebral hemispheres, most commonly the frontal lobe.

 

Histology:

 

  • Round, regular nuclei with clear perinuclear halos (the “fried-egg” appearance).
  • Delicate branching capillaries resembling a chicken-wire pattern.
  • Frequent calcifications.

 

Genetics:

 

  • Combined loss of chromosomal arms 1p and 19q (1p/19q codeletion) is the molecular hallmark.
  • It predicts better prognosis and responsiveness to chemotherapy and radiation.
  • Most cases also harbor an IDH1 mutation, but 1p/19q codeletion is the defining alteration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. EGFR amplification: Typical of glioblastoma multiforme (GBM), not oligodendroglioma.

 

Option B. MGMT promoter methylation: Associated with better response to alkylating chemotherapy in glioblastoma, not diagnostic for oligodendroglioma.

 

Option C. IDH1 mutation: Can be seen in both astrocytomas and oligodendrogliomas, but not specific; the defining lesion for oligodendroglioma is 1p/19q codeletion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Oligodendrogliomas are WHO Grade 2–3 gliomas of oligodendrocyte origin that show 1p/19q codeletion and IDH mutation.
  • The 1p/19q codeletion is a diagnostic and prognostic marker, associated with favorable treatment response and prolonged survival.

choices.text: Start first-line antitubercular therapy and repeat CBNAAT after 2 weeks
Repeat CBNAAT on a fresh specimen now
Send the same residual sample for liquid culture only
Classify as rifampicin-resistant TB and refer to a DR-TB center

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents with painless cervical lymphadenopathy. Fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is performed. CBNAAT (Xpert MTB/RIF) on the aspirate detects Mycobacterium tuberculosis, but the rifampicin resistance result is reported as “indeterminate.” According to the diagnostic algorithm for extra-pulmonary TB (EPTB), what is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Repeat CBNAAT on a fresh specimen now

 

  • In EPTB, a CBNAAT result of “MTB detected; rif indeterminate” most often reflects low bacillary load or a technical issue that prevents reliable detection of rpoB mutations. 
  • Programmatic algorithms direct that the first action is to repeat CBNAAT on a fresh specimen (another aspirate/biopsy from the involved node).
  • If the repeat again reports rif indeterminate, the algorithm advises collecting a fresh sample for liquid culture (and DST) to resolve rif status.
  • Jumping straight to a drug-resistant pathway or starting therapy without clarifying rif status risks overtreatment or undertreatment.
  • Thus, repeating CBNAAT on a newly collected specimen is the appropriate immediate step.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start first-line antitubercular therapy and repeat CBNAAT after 2 weeks: Incorrect. Empirically starting treatment before clarifying rif status can delay recognition of drug resistance. The algorithm prioritizes repeat CBNAAT now on a fresh sample, not delayed retesting after empiric therapy.

 

Option C. Send the same residual sample for liquid culture only: Incorrect. Residual material may be insufficient or degraded, and culture alone delays results. Culture/DST is recommended only if the second, fresh CBNAAT remains indeterminate.

 

Option D. Classify as rifampicin-resistant TB and refer to DR-TB center: Incorrect. An indeterminate rif result is not evidence of resistance. Labeling as DR-TB without confirmation may lead to unnecessary toxic, prolonged regimens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diagnostic Algorithm for Extra-pulmonary TB (EPTB)

choices.text: Artesunate + sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine for 3 days, plus primaquine single dose on day 2
Artemether-lumefantrine for 3 days, plus primaquine single dose (0.75 mg/kg) on day 2
Chloroquine for 3 days, plus primaquine daily for 14 days

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy from Manipur (North-Eastern India) presents with 2 days of fever, chills, and headache. There is no jaundice, altered sensorium, severe anemia, or respiratory distress. A rapid diagnostic test and peripheral smear are positive for Plasmodium falciparum. He is able to take oral medications and has no history of G6PD deficiency. According to the national treatment recommendations used in India, which of the following is the most appropriate regimen?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Artemether-lumefantrine for 3 days, plus primaquine single dose (0.75 mg/kg) on day 2

 

  • Under the NVBDCP recommendations you provided:
    • Uncomplicated P. falciparum malaria in the North-Eastern states (e.g., Manipur, Assam, Meghalaya, Mizoram, Nagaland, Tripura, Arunachal Pradesh) is treated with ACT-AL (artemether-lumefantrine) for 3 days.
    • In addition, give primaquine 0.75 mg/kg as a single dose on day 2 to clear gametocytes and reduce transmission.
    • Age-wise blister packs are used for dosing; children 5–8 years receive the green pack (useful for practical dispensing, though not needed to choose the regimen).
  • Thus, artemether-lumefantrine for 3 days plus a single 0.75 mg/kg primaquine dose on day 2 is the correct programmatic regimen for this child with uncomplicated falciparum malaria in a North-Eastern state.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Artesunate + sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine for 3 days, plus primaquine single dose on day 2: Incorrect in the North-Eastern states, where SP resistance is a concern. ACT-SP is used in other Indian states (non-NE).

 

Option C. Chloroquine for 3 days, plus primaquine daily for 14 days: This is the regimen for P. vivax (chloroquine for 3 days + primaquine 0.25 mg/kg daily for 14 days) per the sheet; it is not appropriate for falciparum malaria.

 

Option D. Oral quinine for 7 days: Quinine is reserved for 1st-trimester pregnancy with uncomplicated falciparum malaria (and for some severe malaria settings). This patient is a non-pregnant child with uncomplicated disease in NE India, so ACT-AL is preferred.

 

Educational Objective:
