Uncomplicated P. falciparum malaria in India:

 

  • North-Eastern states: ACT-AL (artemether-lumefantrine for 3 days) + primaquine 0.75 mg/kg single dose on day 2.
  • Other states: ACT-SP (artesunate + sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine) + primaquine single dose on day 2.

questions.text: A patient underwent an appendectomy for acute appendicitis. However, on the 5th day following surgery, the patient experienced spiking fever, abdominal pain and diarrhoea. Which post operative complication is likely to have occurred?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intra-abdominal abscess

 

  • Approximately 8% of patients following appendicectomy will develop a postoperative intra-abdominal abscess. 
  • Characteristically presents 5–7 days postoperatively with spiking fevers, abdominal pain, and generalized malaise, suggestive of an intraperitoneal collection, matching the clinical picture described.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Wound infection: Commonly presents with localized symptoms such as erythema, tenderness, and purulent discharge at the incision site, often occurring on the 4th or 5th day postoperatively, not typically associated with spiking fever or abdominal pain.

 

Option C. Portal pyemia: A rare complication involving infection of the portal venous system, typically presenting with multiple liver abscesses, jaundice, and systemic illness.

 

Option D. Ileocolic bleed: Bleeding would present with syncope and tachycardia, usually within 24 hours of surgery.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

The clinical presentation of a postoperative intra-abdominal abscess following appendectomy, includes delayed onset of spiking fever, abdominal pain, and malaise.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman with diabetes, nephropathy, neuropathy, hypertension, HIV, and COPD presents for follow-up in your OPD. Labs show the following - Na 134, K 5.2, Cl 110, HCO₃⁻ 17, BUN 30, Cr 1.1, Glucose 233 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows the following - pH 5.3, 2+ protein, no blood/ketones. What is the most likely cause of these abnormalities?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Renal tubular acidosis type 4

 

  • This patient has non–anion gap metabolic acidosis (NAGMA) with mild hyperkalemia and acidic urine (pH <5.5).
  • The combination of diabetic nephropathy and HIV strongly suggests Type 4 RTA (hyporeninemic hypoaldosteronism).

 

Key features of Type 4 RTA:

 

  • Mechanism: Aldosterone deficiency or resistance → impaired distal tubular K⁺ and H⁺ secretion.
  • Electrolytes: Mild hyperkalemia, mild to moderate metabolic acidosis.
  • Anion gap: Normal (Na - [Cl + HCO₃] = 134 - 127 = 7 → normal).
  • Urine pH: <5.5 (acidic; distal H⁺ secretion intact but reduced due to low aldosterone).
  • Common causes:
    • Diabetic nephropathy
    • ACE inhibitors, ARBs, heparin, TMP-SMX, NSAIDs
    • HIV infection
    • Chronic tubulointerstitial disease

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Renal tubular acidosis type 1 (Distal RTA): Defect in distal H⁺ secretion → alkaline urine (pH >5.5) and hypokalemia.

 

Option B. Renal tubular acidosis type 2 (Proximal RTA): Impaired HCO₃⁻ reabsorption → hypokalemia, urine pH <5.5 after acidosis develops, often part of Fanconi syndrome (with glycosuria, phosphaturia, aminoaciduria).

 

Option D. Diabetic ketoacidosis: Causes high anion gap metabolic acidosis, ketonuria, and much higher glucose (>250 mg/dL); not seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Type 4 renal tubular acidosis (RTA), or hyporeninemic hypoaldosteronism, is characterized by NAGMA and hyperkalemia. Common causes include diabetes, HIV, ACE inhibitors, ARBs, heparin
  • In a diabetic or HIV patient with mild hyperkalemia, NAGMA, and acidic urine, Type 4 RTA is the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text:
Regarding commonly used surgical sutures, which of the following statements are correct?

 

  1. Polypropylene (Prolene) is a non-absorbable monofilament suture
  2. Polyglactin (Vicryl) is a delayed absorbable suture that completely absorbs within 180–210 days by hydrolysis.
  3. Polydioxanone (PDS) is an absorbable suture that provides prolonged wound support and is completely absorbed within 180–210 days.
  4. Delayed absorbable sutures such as Vicryl and PDS are preferred for biliary and urological anastomoses to reduce risk of foreign body stone formation.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 3 and 4 are correct

 

Statement 1. Polypropylene (Prolene) is a non-absorbable monofilament suture: Correct. Polypropylene (Prolene) is a monofilament non-absorbable suture, composed of isotactic crystalline stereoisomer of polypropylene. Its blue color enhances visibility, and it is highly favored for vascular anastomosis due to inertness and minimal tissue reaction.

 

Statement 3. Polydioxanone (PDS) is an absorbable suture that provides prolonged wound support and is completely absorbed within 180–210 days: Correct. Polydioxanone (PDS) is a delayed absorbable suture, ideal for cases needing extended wound support. It retains tensile strength for up to 6 weeks and is completely absorbed by 180–210 days.

 

Statement 4. Delayed absorbable sutures such as Vicryl and PDS are preferred for biliary and urological anastomoses to reduce risk of foreign body stone formation: Correct. Delayed absorbable sutures (Vicryl and PDS) are recommended for biliary and urological anastomoses, since permanent sutures can act as a nidus for stone formation in these regions.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 2. Polyglactin (Vicryl) is a delayed absorbable suture that completely absorbs within 180–210 days by hydrolysis: Incorrect.
Polyglactin (Vicryl) is not a delayed absorbable suture; it is a synthetic absorbable suture that is fully absorbed within 56–70 days, not 180–210 days. It retains ~70% tensile strength at 14 days.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Polypropylene is a permanent vascular suture; Vicryl is absorbed within 2 months, while PDS provides delayed absorption over 6 months — delayed absorbables are preferred in biliary and urological anastomoses to prevent stone formation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a recent history of broad-spectrum antibiotic use presents with profuse watery diarrhea, abdominal cramping, and leukocytosis. Stool assay is positive for Clostridioides difficile toxin. He is started on oral vancomycin but develops severe nausea, making oral administration intolerable. Which of the following is the most appropriate alternative that can be administered orally with minimal systemic absorption?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fidaxomicin

 

  • Fidaxomicin is a narrow-spectrum oral macrocyclic antibiotic that is bactericidal against Clostridioides difficile. 
  • It inhibits the sigma subunit of RNA polymerase, thereby blocking transcription. 
  • Importantly, it has minimal systemic absorption and acts locally in the gut, making it a suitable alternative to oral vancomycin in patients who cannot tolerate it.
  • It is equally effective as vancomycin and is associated with lower recurrence rates of C. difficile infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fosfomycin: This antibiotic is primarily used for uncomplicated urinary tract infections. It is absorbed systemically and excreted in urine, making it ineffective against C. difficile, which resides in the colon.

 

Option C. Teicoplanin: Though related to vancomycin and sometimes used in C. difficile treatment in Europe, it requires parenteral administration in most formulations. It does not have FDA approval for C. difficile in the U.S., and it is less accessible and studied than fidaxomicin.

 

Option D. Dalbavancin: This is a long-acting IV glycopeptide antibiotic used primarily for MRSA skin infections. It has no role in the management of C. difficile infections because it lacks gut lumen activity due to systemic absorption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fidaxomicin is an effective oral alternative to vancomycin for Clostridioides difficile infection, especially in patient’s intolerant to vancomycin. 
  • It is minimally absorbed and acts locally in the gut, with a low recurrence rate and favorable safety profile.

questions.text: A woman presents for a routine health checkup. She reports having a regular 28-day menstrual cycle. On days 21–25 of the cycle, what are the typical patterns of reproductive hormone levels?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Estrogen ↑, Progesterone ↑; FSH,↓, LH ↓

 

  • During a normal 28-day menstrual cycle, hormone levels fluctuate in a predictable pattern.
  • The luteal phase (days 15–28) follows ovulation and is dominated by progesterone, secreted from the corpus luteum, with moderate levels of estrogen.
  • Days 21–25 correspond to the mid-luteal phase, which is the peak functional period of the corpus luteum:
    • Progesterone: High — prepares the endometrium for implantation.
    • Estrogen: Moderately high — supports endometrial growth and vascularization.
    • FSH and LH: Suppressed due to negative feedback from high estrogen and progesterone levels.
  • If fertilization does not occur, the corpus luteum regresses near day 26–28, leading to a decline in progesterone and estrogen and the onset of menstruation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Estrogen ↓, Progesterone ↓; FSH ↓, LH ↑: Occurs after luteal regression (late luteal/menstrual phase) — not during days 21–25.

 

Option B. Estrogen ↓, Progesterone ↑; FSH ↑, LH ↑: FSH and LH are not elevated in the luteal phase — they are suppressed by negative feedback.

 

Option D. Estrogen↓, Progesterone ↓; FSH ↓, LH ↓: This pattern corresponds to the early follicular phase (days 1–5) when hormone levels are low after corpus luteum breakdown.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During the mid-luteal phase (days 21–25) of a 28-day menstrual cycle, both estrogen and progesterone levels are high, while FSH and LH levels are suppressed due to negative feedback from ovarian hormones.

questions.text: A 4-month-old female infant is brought to the pediatrician with concerns about head shape. Physical examination reveals an elongated and narrow head with prominence in the anterior-posterior direction. The sagittal suture feels ridge-like on palpation. The infant has achieved age-appropriate milestones and neurological examination is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dolichocephaly

 

  • The clinical presentation in this case is classic for dolichocephaly, which results from premature fusion (craniosynostosis) of the sagittal suture. 
  • This is the most common type of craniosynostosis, accounting for approximately 40-60% of cases.
  • The key findings supporting this diagnosis are:
    • Elongated, narrow head with increased anterior-posterior diameter (scaphocephaly)
    • Ridge-like sagittal suture on palpation, indicating premature fusion
    • Normal developmental milestones, suggesting isolated craniosynostosis without associated syndromic features
  • When the sagittal suture fuses prematurely, the skull cannot grow in width but compensates by growing in length, resulting in the characteristic boat-shaped (scaphocephalic) deformity. 
  • The sagittal suture runs from the anterior fontanelle to the posterior fontanelle along the top midline of the skull.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Plagiocephaly:

 

  • Results from unilateral coronal suture fusion, causing asymmetric flattening of one side of the forehead
  • Produces facial asymmetry with displacement of the orbit and ear on the affected side
  • The head appears flattened on one side with compensatory prominence on the contralateral side
  • Can also be positional (without suture fusion) due to preferential head positioning in infants

 

Option C. Oxycephaly:

 

  • Results from fusion of coronal and sphenofrontal sutures
  • Causes a tower-like skull appearance (turricephaly or "tower head")
  • Often associated with shallow orbits, exophthalmos, and midface hypoplasia
  • May be seen in syndromic craniosynostosis (Apert, Crouzon syndromes)

 

Option D. Trigonocephaly:

 

  • Results from metopic suture fusion
  • Causes a triangular-shaped forehead with narrowing at the front
  • Often associated with hypotelorism (abnormally close-set eyes)
  • The metopic suture runs from the anterior fontanelle to the nasal bridge

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Craniosynostosis types are defined by which cranial suture(s) fuse prematurely:

choices.text: 50,000 IU single dose on day 1
100,000 IU single dose on day 1
200,000 IU single dose on day 1
400,000 IU split into two doses over 2 days

questions.text: A 14-month-old boy weighing 6.2 kg is brought to the malnutrition clinic with visible severe wasting, bilateral pitting edema, and skin changes. His mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) is 10.5 cm. After initial stabilization, the healthcare team begins planning micronutrient supplementation. Which of the following vitamin A dosing regimens is correct for this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 100,000 IU single dose on day 1

 

  • For children with Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM), vitamin A supplementation is an essential component of treatment. 
  • The dosing of vitamin A is age-dependent, with children older than 12 months receiving 200,000 IU as a single dose on day 1 of treatment. 
  • This child is 14 months old, so option C is correct.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. 50,000 IU single dose on day 1: 50,000 IU is the appropriate dose for infants under 6 months of age with SAM. This dose would be insufficient for a 14-month-old and would not provide adequate supplementation to address vitamin A deficiency.

 

Option C. 200,000 IU single dose on day 1: If the child is more than 1 year and less than 8 kg then instead of giving 2 lakh IU, we give one lakh IU of vitamin A

 

Option D. 400,000 IU split into two doses over 2 days: 400,000 IU is excessive and potentially toxic. There is no recommendation to split vitamin A doses in SAM treatment protocols, and this total dose exceeds the recommended amount for any pediatric age group.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Comprehensive Micronutrient Supplementation in SAM:

questions.text: A 20-year-old female college basketball player presents to the OPD immediately after injuring her knee during a game. She reports landing awkwardly after a jump shot and feeling a sharp pop followed by immediate, excruciating pain. Within minutes, her knee began to swell rapidly. Testing the ligamentous stability reveals a soft or absent endpoint during the Lachman test. An initial X-ray shows no fracture. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anterior Cruciate Ligament (ACL) Tear

 

  • Rationale: The patient's presentation is highly specific for an acute, high-grade ACL tear:
    • Mechanism: Non-contact deceleration, pivoting, or awkward landing.
    • Symptoms: Audible "pop," followed by the cardinal sign of immediate, massive swelling (acute hemarthrosis), and the subjective feeling of instability ("giving way").
    • Physical Exam: The Lachman test is the most sensitive physical exam test for an acute ACL tear. A soft or absent endpoint indicates significant anterior translation of the tibia, confirming the tear.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Patellar Tendon Rupture:

 

  • A patellar tendon rupture would cause an inability to actively extend the knee against gravity, leading to a visible gap above or below the kneecap (patella alta or infera). 
  • While it involves pain and a pop, the primary deficit is a loss of the extensor mechanism, which is not the main finding described here.

 

Option B. Medial Collateral Ligament (MCL) Sprain:

 

  • MCL sprains are typically caused by a valgus stress (a blow to the outside of the knee).
  • While they cause swelling, they usually do not result in the rapid, massive hemarthrosis or profound instability associated with an ACL tear. 
  • Instability is tested by stressing the knee into valgus at 30∘ of flexion.

 

Option D. Meniscus Injury:

 

  • A meniscus tear also involves a pop and swelling, but the swelling is often delayed (not immediate hemarthrosis). 
  • The most characteristic symptom is mechanical catching or locking of the joint. 
  • While meniscus tears often coexist with ACL tears, the rapid swelling and profound instability are the dominant features pointing to the ligamentous injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The classic clinical triad of an acute Anterior Cruciate Ligament (ACL) tear: non-contact pivoting/landing mechanism, a pop sensation followed by immediate, massive swelling (hemarthrosis), and knee instability.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with cough and shortness of breath. He has been working in a shipyard factory for 30 years. A chest X-ray shows a pleural-based mass in the right lung apex. A biopsy from the lesion on electron microscopy is shown below. Which of the following tumor markers is most likely to be positive in this tumor?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Calretinin

 

  • The description of long, slender microvilli seen on electron microscopy is pathognomonic for malignant mesothelioma, a tumor of the pleural mesothelial cells strongly linked to asbestos exposure.

 

Key Diagnostic Features of Mesothelioma:

  • Histology: Epithelioid or sarcomatoid pattern.
  • Electron Microscopy:
    • Profuse, long, slender, and sometimes branching microvilli on apical and lateral surfaces.
    • Numerous desmosomes and tonofilaments may be present.
    • Helps distinguish mesothelioma from adenocarcinoma, which has short, stubby microvilli.
  • Immunohistochemistry (IHC):
    • Positive: Calretinin, CK5/6, WT-1, D2-40 (podoplanin).
    • Negative: TTF-1, CEA, Napsin A (seen in adenocarcinoma).
  • Mechanism: Asbestos fibers deposit in pleural tissue → chronic inflammation → DNA damage and tumor formation → malignant mesothelioma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CD117 (c-KIT): Marker expressed in gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs) and seminomas, unrelated to pleural neoplasms.

 

Option B. Napsin A: Marker of lung adenocarcinoma, not mesothelioma.

 

Option C. Chromogranin A: Marker of neuroendocrine tumors (e.g., carcinoid tumor, small cell carcinoma), not mesothelial origin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Malignant mesothelioma, caused by asbestos exposure, typically expresses Calretinin, CK5/6, and WT-1 positivity, with long, slender microvilli on electron microscopy.
  • These features distinguish it from adenocarcinoma of the lung, which expresses TTF-1 and Napsin A.

choices.text: Cervical punch biopsy from the abnormal acetowhite areas
Cold knife conization from the abnormal acetowhite areas
Loop electrosurgical excision procedure (LEEP) from the abnormal acetowhite areas

questions.text: A 46-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with postcoital bleeding for the past month. On pelvic examination, the cervix appears grossly normal. A Pap smear reveals high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL). Colposcopy demonstrates dense acetowhite areas with abnormal vascular patterns. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cervical punch biopsy from the abnormal acetowhite areas

 

  • A Pap smear showing high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL) indicates a strong suspicion for cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN 2/3) or even microinvasive carcinoma. 
  • The next diagnostic step depends on the colposcopic findings.
  • When colposcopy reveals dense acetowhite lesions with abnormal vascularity, the most appropriate next step is a targeted cervical punch biopsy from these abnormal acetowhite areas to obtain tissue for histopathological examination.
  • This confirms the diagnosis and helps guide further management (e.g., excisional procedures if CIN 2/3 is confirmed).

 

Key principle:

 

  • Pap smear = Screening test
  • Biopsy = Diagnostic confirmation
    Only after biopsy confirms a high-grade lesion should excisional therapy (LEEP or conization) be considered.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endocervical curettage: Used when the transformation zone is not fully visualized or to evaluate the endocervical canal for hidden lesions. It is not the first-line step when abnormal acetowhite areas are clearly seen and accessible for biopsy.

 

Option C. Cold knife conization for the abnormal acetowhite areas: Indicated when colposcopy is unsatisfactory, or invasive carcinoma is suspected. In this case, colposcopy is satisfactory, so a biopsy (not conization) is the correct next step.

 

Option D. Loop electrosurgical excision procedure (LEEP) from the abnormal acetowhite areas: LEEP is a diagnostic and therapeutic excision method but is performed only after biopsy confirms CIN 2/3. Performing LEEP without histologic confirmation may result in unnecessary excision or missed invasive disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a woman with HSIL on Pap smear and visible abnormal acetowhite areas on colposcopy, the next best step is a targeted cervical punch biopsy from those acetowhite areas to obtain histologic confirmation before proceeding to excisional therapy.

choices.text: Cyclin A → Cyclin E → Cyclin D → Cyclin B
Cyclin B → Cyclin A → Cyclin D → Cyclin E
Cyclin D → Cyclin E → Cyclin A → Cyclin B
Cyclin E → Cyclin D → Cyclin B → Cyclin A

questions.text: During cell cycle progression, specific cyclins activate corresponding cyclin-dependent kinases (CDKs) in a defined order to ensure proper phase transitions. Which of the following represents the correct sequential activation of cyclins during the normal cell cycle?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cyclin D → Cyclin E → Cyclin A → Cyclin B

 

  • Cyclins act intermittently in coordination with cyclin-dependent kinases (CDKs) to regulate different phases of the cell cycle. 
  • Each cyclin activates a specific CDK that controls a checkpoint or transition.
  • Normal sequence of cyclin activation: Cyclin D → Cyclin E → Cyclin A → Cyclin B

 

 

Clinical relevance:

 

  • Cyclin D1 overexpression due to t(11;14) translocation causes Mantle Cell Lymphoma.
  • CDK4/6 inhibitors (e.g., Palbociclib) are used in ER⁺ breast cancer to halt tumor cell cycle progression at G₁.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cyclin activation occurs in a specific order — D → E → A → B — ensuring orderly progression through G₁ → S → G₂ → M phases.
  • Overexpression or mutation in these cyclins, particularly Cyclin D1, can lead to uncontrolled cell proliferation and malignancy (e.g., Mantle Cell Lymphoma).

choices.text: Idiopathic hypercalciuria with recurrent renal stones

questions.text: A 54-year-old man with newly diagnosed hypertension is being considered for thiazide diuretic therapy. Which of the following associated conditions is least likely to benefit from this class of drugs?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypercalcemia

 

  • Thiazide diuretics, such as hydrochlorothiazide and chlorthalidone, are commonly used to treat hypertension and congestive heart failure and to reduce urinary calcium excretion.
  • They lower blood pressure by reducing plasma volume initially and decreasing peripheral vascular resistance with chronic use.
  • In CHF, they are effective adjuncts to loop diuretics in managing volume overload.
  • Thiazides also increase calcium reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule, which reduces urinary calcium and thereby prevents calcium-based kidney stones, especially in cases of idiopathic hypercalciuria.
  • However, this same mechanism can lead to or worsen hypercalcemia, especially in predisposed individuals such as those with primary hyperparathyroidism or other causes of elevated serum calcium. 
  • Since thiazides decrease urinary calcium excretion, they are contraindicated or used with caution in patients with hypercalcemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Idiopathic hypercalciuria with recurrent renal stones: Correct indication. Thiazides reduce urinary calcium excretion, making them helpful in preventing calcium stone formation.

 

Option C. Congestive heart failure (CHF): Thiazides are effective diuretics for mild fluid overload and serve as adjuncts to loop diuretics in volume management in CHF.

 

Option D. Hypertension: Thiazides are first-line agents for managing uncomplicated hypertension and are particularly effective in older adults and African American patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Thiazide diuretics reduce urinary calcium excretion, which benefits conditions like idiopathic hypercalciuria but may worsen hypercalcemia.
  • Therefore, they are contraindicated or used cautiously in patients with elevated serum calcium.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman with a history of primary infertility undergoes a hysterosalpingography (HSG) which reveals bilateral tubal blockage. She has regular menstrual cycles and no history of pelvic surgery or infections. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Laparoscopic chromopertubation

 

  • In a woman with primary infertility and bilateral tubal block on HSG, the next step is to confirm the diagnosis with laparoscopy and chromopertubation, rather than proceeding directly to assisted reproductive techniques (ART).

 

Rationale:

 

  • Hysterosalpingography (HSG) is a screening test that may show false-positive tubal blockage, especially due to tubal spasm or mucus plugs.
  • Therefore, before labeling the tubes as permanently blocked, laparoscopic chromopertubation is performed to directly visualize the tubes and assess tubal patency.
  • Methylene blue dye is injected through the cervix, and its passage through the fimbrial ends confirms patency.
  • Laparoscopy also allows the surgeon to identify and treat pelvic adhesions, endometriosis, or tubal pathology in the same sitting, which are common causes of infertility.

 

Thus, laparoscopy with chromopertubation is the next best diagnostic and therapeutic step following an abnormal HSG report.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Letrozole ovulation induction: Used for anovulatory infertility, especially in polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). Since this patient’s problem lies with tubal blockage, ovulation induction will not help in conception.

 

Option C. Intrauterine insemination (IUI): Requires at least one patent fallopian tube for sperm transport and fertilization. In bilateral tubal blockage, IUI is ineffective.

 

Option D. In vitro fertilization (IVF): IVF bypasses the fallopian tubes and is indicated in confirmed bilateral tubal occlusion. However, since HSG may be falsely positive, laparoscopic confirmation is necessary before starting IVF.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In women with bilateral tubal blockage on HSG, the next best step is laparoscopic chromopertubation to confirm true tubal occlusion and evaluate for pelvic pathology before proceeding to advanced fertility treatments such as IVF.

questions.text: An elderly man undergoes vestibular evoked myogenic potential (VEMP) testing as part of a balance disorder evaluation. Which of the following findings is most commonly observed on VEMP in older adults?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Decreased amplitude

 

  • VEMP is a neurophysiological test that assesses the integrity of the saccule and inferior vestibular nerve pathway (via sound-evoked muscle potentials recorded from the sternocleidomastoid).
  • With aging, there is degeneration of otolith organs (saccule/utricle) and reduced vestibular hair cell sensitivity, leading to:
    • Reduced amplitude of VEMP responses
    • Increased thresholds (need louder stimulus)
    • Prolonged latency (delayed conduction)
  • Among these, the most consistent and common finding is a decrease in amplitude.
  • This reflects diminished vestibular receptor function in the elderly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased threshold: Thresholds are elevated, not reduced.

 

Option C. Decreased latency: Opposite occurs; latency is often prolonged.

 

Option D. Increased amplitude: Not seen; amplitude reduces with age.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The most common VEMP finding in the elderly is decreased response amplitude, due to age-related vestibular receptor degeneration.

questions.text: In the given image, muscles A and B are labelled. Which of the following nerves supply muscles A and B, respectively?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Facial nerve & Nerve to mylohyoid

 

  • The cadaveric image shows the digastric muscle, which is a unique "hybrid muscle" of the neck with dual innervation:
    • Muscle A (Anterior belly of digastric): This muscle is derived from the first pharyngeal arch and is supplied by the mandibular nerve (V3), specifically through the nerve to mylohyoid branch. The nerve to mylohyoid runs along the mylohyoid muscle and sends a branch to innervate the anterior belly of the digastric.
    • Muscle B (Posterior belly of digastric): This muscle is derived from the second pharyngeal arch and is supplied by the facial nerve (CN VII), specifically through the digastric branch of the facial nerve that arises near the stylomastoid foramen.
  • The digastric muscle is classified as a hybrid muscle because its two bellies have different embryological origins and nerve supplies:
    • First arch → Mandibular nerve (V3) → Nerve to mylohyoid → Anterior belly
    • Second arch → Facial nerve (CN VII) → Posterior belly

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Facial nerve & Glossopharyngeal nerve: Incorrect. While the facial nerve correctly supplies the posterior belly, the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) does not supply the digastric muscle. The glossopharyngeal nerve supplies the stylopharyngeus muscle (third pharyngeal arch derivative) and provides sensory innervation to the posterior third of the tongue and pharynx.

 

Option C. Facial nerve & Hypoglossus nerve: Incorrect. The hypoglossal nerve (CN XII) supplies all intrinsic and most extrinsic muscles of the tongue (except palatoglossus), not the digastric muscle. While the hypoglossal nerve does run in close proximity to the digastric muscle in the submandibular region, it does not innervate it.

 

Option D. Facial nerve & Vagus nerve:  Incorrect. The vagus nerve (CN X) does not supply the digastric muscle. The vagus nerve supplies muscles of the palate (except tensor veli palatini), pharynx (except stylopharyngeus), and larynx (all intrinsic muscles except cricothyroid via recurrent laryngeal nerve). The vagus is the nerve of the fourth pharyngeal arch.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The digastric muscle is a hybrid muscle with dual innervation: the anterior belly is supplied by the nerve to mylohyoid (branch of mandibular nerve, V3) as it is a first pharyngeal arch derivative, while the posterior belly is supplied by the facial nerve (CN VII) as it is a second pharyngeal arch derivative.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) is in active labor. After the fetal head delivers, the shoulders fail to deliver and become impacted behind the maternal symphysis pubis. Which of the following represents the correct sequence of maneuvers to manage this complication?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) McRobert’s → Rubin → Gaskin → Zavanelli

 

  • The described scenario is a classic case of shoulder dystocia, a true obstetric emergency that occurs when the anterior fetal shoulder becomes impacted behind the maternal pubic symphysis after delivery of the fetal head.

 

Risk factors:

 

  • Maternal diabetes (GDM) → large fetal shoulders (macrosomia)
  • Prolonged labor or instrumental delivery
  • Obesity or excessive maternal weight gain

 

Management involves a stepwise approach, starting from least to most invasive maneuvers:

 

1. McRobert’s Maneuver (First step)

 

  • Action: Flex maternal thighs sharply onto the abdomen.
  • Mechanism: Rotates the symphysis pubis cephalad and flattens the lumbar lordosis, increasing the anteroposterior diameter of the pelvis.
  • Effectiveness: Resolves >40% of shoulder dystocia cases.

 

2. Rubin Maneuver (Second step)

 

  • Action: Insert a hand into the vagina and apply pressure on the posterior aspect of the anterior shoulder to adduct it toward the fetal chest.
  • Mechanism: Reduces the bisacromial diameter (shoulder width) to help the shoulder slip under the pubic symphysis.

 

3. Gaskin Maneuver (Third step)

 

  • Action: Have the mother move to an all-fours (hands-and-knees) position.
  • Mechanism: Changes pelvic dimensions and allows the posterior shoulder to dislodge more easily.
  • Often used when McRobert’s and Rubin maneuvers fail.

 

4. Zavanelli Maneuver (Last resort)

 

  • Action: Cephalic replacement of the fetal head into the vagina, followed by cesarean section.
  • Mechanism: Used only when all other maneuvers fail; it carries high maternal and fetal risk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In shoulder dystocia, management should proceed stepwise as follows:
McRobert’s maneuver → Rubin maneuver → Gaskin maneuver → Zavanelli maneuver. This sequence progresses from the least invasive to the most invasive interventions, aiming to relieve shoulder impaction and prevent fetal hypoxia or brachial plexus injury.

questions.text:
What are the indications to treat hypertension as per the current recommendations? 

 

  1. ABPM ≥130/80 mmHg over 24 hours
  2. Daytime ABPM ≥135/85 mmHg
  3. Night-time ABPM ≥120/70 mmHg
  4. Office BP ≥140/90 mmHg
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

  • The diagnostic thresholds for hypertension differ based on the method of measurement:

 

 

  • These thresholds align with ESC/ESH guidelines, which emphasize the importance of out-of-office BP monitoring to identify white coat hypertension and masked hypertension.
  • Treatment initiation thresholds (based on office BP):
    • BP ≥ 140/90 mmHg
    • BP ≥ 130/80 mmHg + CVD, CKD, DM, or high CV risk (based on risk models)
  • Equivalent Office BP thresholds:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypertension diagnosis depends on measurement setting:

 

  • Office ≥140/90 mmHg
  • 24-hour ABPM ≥130/80 mmHg
  • Daytime ≥135/85 mmHg
  • Night-time ≥120/70 mmHg
    Out-of-office monitoring improves diagnostic accuracy and risk stratification.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-tubercular drugs exerts its therapeutic action by interfering with Mycobacterium tuberculosis folate metabolism, unlike the others that act via unrelated mechanisms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) PAS 

 

  • PAS is a structural analogue of para-aminobenzoic acid (PABA) and acts as a competitive inhibitor of folate synthesis in Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • It targets the same pathway as sulfonamides but is specifically active against mycobacteria.
  • This disruption inhibits the formation of dihydrofolic acid, leading to impaired nucleic acid synthesis and cell replication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pyrazinamide: Targets mycobacterial cell membrane function and energy metabolism, especially in acidic environments. It does not affect folate pathways.

 

Option C. Bedaquiline: A diarylquinoline drug that selectively inhibits mycobacterial ATP synthase, leading to energy depletion. It is independent of folate metabolism.

 

Option D. Capreomycin: An aminoglycoside-like agent that inhibits protein synthesis by binding to ribosomal subunits. It has no effect on folate metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • PAS is the only anti-TB drug that inhibits folate metabolism, mimicking PABA. 
  • Understanding drug mechanisms is crucial for rational use in multi-drug-resistant TB regimens.

 

Note: Mechanism of action of anti-tubercular drugs

choices.text: Detection of Negri bodies on H&E stain
RT-PCR on nape of neck biopsy

questions.text: A 36-year-old man presents with low-grade fever, malaise, and tingling around a recent dog bite wound sustained two weeks ago. He has not received post-exposure prophylaxis. Neurological examination is normal. The physician suspects early rabies infection and wants to confirm the diagnosis using the most sensitive test available at this stage. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic test for confirming rabies in this patient during the early phase of infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) RT-PCR on nape of neck biopsy

 

  • In living patients, especially during the early stages of rabies infection, RT-PCR (Reverse Transcription-Polymerase Chain Reaction) is the most sensitive and specific method for detecting rabies viral RNA.
  • The nape of the neck biopsy contains hair follicles with rich innervation, making it an ideal site for detecting rabies RNA before CNS symptoms fully develop.
  • RT-PCR can detect even low levels of viral RNA, offering early and reliable diagnosis before antibodies develop or inclusion bodies (e.g., Negri) appear.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Detection of Negri bodies on H&E stain:

 

  • Negri bodies are eosinophilic intracytoplasmic inclusions found in neurons (especially hippocampus and Purkinje cells).
  • They are pathognomonic but only visible post-mortem or late in the disease.
  • Additionally, up to 20% of rabies cases may lack Negri bodies.
  • Incorrect: Not useful early and not reliable in living patients.

 

Option B. DFA test on corneal impressions:

 

  • Direct Fluorescent Antibody (DFA) is a rapid test that detects rabies nucleoprotein antigen, typically in corneal impression smears or nape biopsies.
  • While it is useful, corneal smears have lower sensitivity (~30%), especially early in infection.
  • DFA on nape biopsy is preferred over corneal smear but still inferior to RT-PCR.
  •  Incorrect: DFA is less sensitive than RT-PCR and corneal site is suboptimal.

 

Option D. Serum antibody testing using IFA:

 

  • Antibodies in serum appear late and are often detectable after vaccination or in the late stage of infection.
  • CSF antibody is more specific, but even then, it’s not a preferred early diagnostic method.
  • Incorrect: Antibody-based tests are not sensitive early and may give false reassurance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • RT-PCR on a nape of the neck biopsy is the most sensitive and specific diagnostic method for early rabies detection in living patients. 
  • It detects viral RNA before antibody response or histopathological changes (e.g., Negri bodies) occur.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with breast cancer is starting anthracycline chemotherapy. Which imaging modality is most accurate and reproducible for serial monitoring of her left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF)?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Echocardiography

 

  • Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) is the first-line and most commonly used imaging modality for serial monitoring of LVEF in patients undergoing cardiotoxic chemotherapy (e.g., anthracyclines). 
  • It is non-invasive, radiation-free, widely available, and provides not only information about LVEF but also about diastolic function, wall motion abnormalities, and valvular structure.
  • Modern advancements like 3D echocardiography and global longitudinal strain (GLS) analysis have significantly improved the reproducibility and sensitivity of echocardiography for detecting early subclinical myocardial dysfunction, making it preferable over MUGA scans in current practice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cardiac MRI: While highly accurate for LVEF and myocardial characterization, CMR is expensive, less accessible, and time-consuming. It is typically reserved for inconclusive echocardiograms or more complex cardiomyopathies—not for routine monitoring.

 

Option C. MUGA scan: Previously favored for high reproducibility of LVEF, especially in oncology, but it involves radiation exposure and limited structural detail. Its use has declined in favor of echocardiography enhanced with strain imaging.

 

Option D. CT angiography: Primarily used for coronary artery assessment, not routinely for LVEF monitoring. It involves radiation and contrast, making it unsuitable for serial follow-up.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Echocardiography, especially with 3D imaging and global longitudinal strain (GLS), is the preferred modality for serial LVEF monitoring during anthracycline chemotherapy due to its non-invasive nature, accessibility, and comprehensive cardiac assessment capabilities.

questions.text: Which of the following malignancies is most strongly associated with radiation exposure during infancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thyroid carcinoma

 

  • Radiation exposure during childhood/infancy, especially involving the head and neck, is strongly associated with the development of thyroid carcinoma, particularly papillary thyroid carcinoma.
  • The thyroid is highly sensitive to ionizing radiation during early life because of its high mitotic activity and concentration of iodine uptake.
  • Historical cases (irradiation for thymic enlargement, acne, tonsillar hypertrophy, or lymphomas in infants) showed markedly increased incidence of thyroid cancers decades later.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Breast carcinoma: Radiation is indeed a risk factor for breast cancer, but primarily in adolescents and young women exposed to chest radiation (e.g., mantle radiation for Hodgkin lymphoma). It is not the primary cancer linked to infant radiation.

 

Option B. Melanoma: Ultraviolet radiation, not therapeutic ionizing radiation in infancy, is the major risk factor.

 

Option D. Lung carcinoma: Risk is mostly associated with smoking, environmental toxins (radon, asbestos), and high-dose radiation exposures in adults (e.g., atomic bomb survivors), not infancy radiation to the neck.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ionizing radiation exposure in infancy, particularly to the head and neck, is most strongly associated with an increased risk of thyroid carcinoma (especially papillary type).

choices.text: Direct isoniazid toxicity causing niacin depletion
Vitamin B6 deficiency leading to impaired tryptophan-to-niacin conversion
Malabsorption of niacin due to isoniazid-induced enteropathy
Competitive inhibition of niacin by isoniazid metabolites

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman being treated for tuberculosis with isoniazid presents with a 6-week history of photosensitive dermatitis on her face and hands, diarrhea, and confusion. She also complains of peripheral numbness and tingling. Physical examination reveals a symmetrical rash on sun-exposed areas and decreased sensation in her distal extremities. Which of the following best explains her pellagra-like symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin B6 deficiency leading to impaired tryptophan-to-niacin conversion

 

  • This patient has pellagra-like symptoms (dermatitis, diarrhea, dementia) caused by secondary niacin (B3) deficiency due to vitamin B6 deficiency from isoniazid therapy.

 

Key Mechanism:

 

  • Vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) is a cofactor for enzymes involved in converting tryptophan to niacin (B3)
  • Isoniazid depletes vitamin B6 stores and interferes with B6 metabolism
  • Without adequate B6, the body cannot synthesize niacin from dietary tryptophan
  • This leads to functional niacin deficiency → pellagra symptoms
  • The peripheral neuropathy is a direct effect of B6 deficiency itself

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct isoniazid toxicity causing niacin depletion: Incorrect. Isoniazid toxicity does not directly deplete niacin. The drug’s adverse effects stem primarily from interference with vitamin B6 metabolism and hepatic injury, not from direct niacin depletion.

 

Option C. Malabsorption of niacin due to isoniazid-induced enteropathy: Incorrect. Isoniazid does not cause intestinal mucosal damage or malabsorption. Niacin levels fall due to impaired synthesis, not poor absorption.

 

Option D. Competitive inhibition of niacin by isoniazid metabolites: Incorrect. Isoniazid does not compete with niacin for receptor or enzyme sites. Its effect is through enzyme cofactor (pyridoxal phosphate) depletion, not substrate competition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Isoniazid therapy can cause vitamin B6 deficiency by forming a complex with pyridoxal phosphate. 
  • This impairs the conversion of tryptophan to niacin, leading to secondary pellagra (dermatitis, diarrhea, dementia) and peripheral neuropathy.
  • Co-administration of pyridoxine (vitamin B6) prevents these adverse effects.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old woman with ESRD on haemodialysis develops painful leg ulcers over 1 month as shown below. She is currently taking amlodipine, calcium supplements, alfacalcidol, erythropoietin. Labs show Ca 10.8 mg/dL, Phosphate 9.3 mg/dL and iPTH ~1150 pg/mL. Which of the following would be inappropriate for her condition?

 

 

1. Sodium thiosulfate

2. Paracalcitol

3. Warfarin

4. Cinacalcet

5. Hyperbaric oxygen therapy
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2, 3

 

  • The presentation is consistent with calcific uraemic arteriolopathy (calciphylaxis) in a haemodialysis patient with hypercalcaemia, severe hyperphosphataemia, and very high PTH.
  • 2. Paricalcitol: Is an active vitamin D analogue that can raise calcium–phosphate burden and worsen calcification; avoid in calciphylaxis.
  • 3. Warfarin: Inhibits matrix Gla protein, a natural inhibitor of vascular calcification, and is a recognized risk factor for calciphylaxis; avoid/stop if possible.

 

Correct Options:

 

Appropriate therapies include:

 

1. Sodium thiosulfate: IV post-dialysis to aid dissolution of calcium deposits and relieve pain.

 

4. Cinacalcet: To lower PTH and Ca×P product; medical alternative to parathyroidectomy.

 

5. Hyperbaric oxygen therapy: As an adjunct to promote wound healing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Management of calciphylaxis: remove drivers (stop calcium salts/active vitamin D, avoid warfarin, use low-calcium dialysate, control phosphate), treat lesions (meticulous wound care; consider hyperbaric oxygen), and use sodium thiosulfate plus PTH-lowering therapy (e.g., cinacalcet or parathyroidectomy if refractory). 
  • Avoid paricalcitol and warfarin.

choices.text: Ampullary portion – because it is the widest and most tortuous segment
Isthmic portion – because it is narrow and has thick muscular walls
Fimbrial portion – because it lies closest to the ovary and is easily accessible
Infundibular portion – because it contains the largest number of fimbriae for easy identification

questions.text: Which of the following represents the most common site chosen for tubal ligation and the reason for selecting it?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Isthmic portion – because it is narrow and has thick muscular walls

 

  • The isthmic portion of the fallopian tube is the most common site for performing tubal ligation (female sterilization).

 

Anatomical rationale:

 

  • The isthmus is the narrowest part of the fallopian tube and has thick circular muscle fibers, which make it ideal for safe and effective ligation.
  • Ligation at this point ensures permanent tubal occlusion with minimal chance of recanalization.
  • It is located close to the uterine cornu, allowing easy surgical access during minilaparotomy or laparoscopy.

 

Common methods used:

 

  • Pomeroy’s method: Loop of isthmic tube is tied and segment excised.
  • Modified Pomeroy’s or Parkland’s method: Used for higher efficacy and lower failure rates.

 

Clinical relevance:

 

  • Ligation at the isthmic portion provides the best balance between surgical accessibility, low failure rate, and preservation of blood supply to adjacent segments.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ampullary portion – because it is the widest and most tortuous segment: The ampulla is the usual site of fertilization, but ligation here increases the risk of failure and ectopic pregnancy due to its wider lumen and delicate wall.

 

Option C. Fimbrial portion – because it lies closest to the ovary and is easily accessible: Used in fimbriectomy (Madlener method) but less preferred due to higher recanalization rates and difficulty in identifying the exact segment intraoperatively.

 

Option D. Infundibular portion – because it contains the largest number of fimbriae for easy identification: The infundibulum is fragile and close to the ovary, making it unsuitable for ligation because of the risk of damage to ovarian blood supply.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The isthmic portion of the fallopian tube is the preferred site for tubal ligation because it is narrow, muscular, and easily accessible, ensuring a low failure rate and effective permanent sterilization.

questions.text:
Which of the following situations qualify as medico-legally acceptable privileged communication? 

 

  1. A bus driver with epilepsy refusing to inform his employer.
  2. A syphilitic patient about to get married.
  3. A case of suspected child sexual abuse.
  4. An impotent man preparing to marry, without any health risk to others.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 3 only

 

  • Privileged communication is an exception to medical confidentiality. 
  • It allows a physician to disclose patient information without consent when necessary to protect the health or safety of the individual or the public, or as required by law.
  • Statement 1. A bus driver with epilepsy refusing to inform his employer: Is correct. A bus driver with epilepsy poses a risk to public safety, and the doctor has a duty to report such a condition if the patient refuses to do so.
  • Statement 2. A syphilitic patient about to get married: Is correct. A syphilitic patient marrying can transmit a sexually transmitted infection, justifying privileged communication.
  • Statement 3. A case of suspected child sexual abuse: Is correct. Child sexual abuse must be mandatorily reported as per the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act, 2012.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 4. An impotent man preparing to marry, without any health risk to others: Incorrect. Impotence is not a public health threat, and hence, does not justify privileged communication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Privileged communication permits physicians to disclose patient information without consent in situations involving public health threats, legal obligations, or when required to protect vulnerable individuals (e.g., children, elderly, disabled). 
  • Impotence, however, is not considered a reportable or dangerous condition and does not qualify under privileged communication.

questions.text: A 22-year-old college student reports excessive daytime sleepiness, episodes of sudden muscle weakness triggered by laughter, and occasional hallucinations while falling asleep. His nocturnal polysomnography is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic test to confirm narcolepsy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Multiple Sleep Latency Test (MSLT)

 

  • This 22-year-old student presents with classic symptoms of narcolepsy, including:
    • Excessive daytime sleepiness
    • Cataplexy (sudden loss of muscle tone triggered by laughter)
    • Hypnagogic hallucinations (hallucinations while falling asleep)
  • While nocturnal polysomnography (PSG) may appear unremarkable, the Multiple Sleep Latency Test (MSLT) is the diagnostic test for narcolepsy. MSLT measures the speed at which a person falls asleep in a quiet environment during the day and checks for sleep-onset REM periods (SOREMPs).
  • Narcolepsy is diagnosed when the mean sleep latency is <8 minutes and ≥2 SOREMPs are observed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epworth Sleepiness Scale: This is a screening tool, not a diagnostic test. It measures the subjective severity of daytime sleepiness, but cannot confirm narcolepsy.

 

Option C. EEG with photic stimulation: This is used primarily in the diagnosis of epilepsy, particularly photosensitive seizures, and has no role in narcolepsy diagnosis.

 

Option D. Overnight pulse oximetry: This is used to screen for sleep-related breathing disorders such as obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), not for narcolepsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Multiple Sleep Latency Test (MSLT) is the diagnostic test for narcolepsy, especially after an unremarkable overnight PSG.
  • It evaluates daytime sleep latency and the presence of REM-onset sleep episodes, helping to confirm the diagnosis in patients with daytime sleepiness, cataplexy, and sleep-related hallucinations.

choices.text: Check anti-sp100 and anti-gp210 antibody titers
Trial of prednisone to see whether alkaline phosphatase improves

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with 8 months of fatigue and pruritus. Labs show ALP 409 U/L (normal 40-120), bilirubin 1.8 mg/dL, AMA negative, ANA 1:80 (positive), ASMA negative, IgG 900 mg/dL (normal). MRCP is normal. What is the next best step before considering liver biopsy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Check anti-sp100 and anti-gp210 antibody titers 

 

  • Primary biliary cholangitis (PBC) can be diagnosed when 2 of 3 are present:
  1. Chronic cholestasis (elevated ALP),
  2. PBC-specific autoantibodies (typically AMA; in AMA-negative cases, anti-sp100 and anti-gp210),
  3. Compatible histology (nonsuppurative destructive cholangitis).
  • This patient has cholestatic labs (markedly elevated ALP) with AMA-negative serology and normal MRCP. 
  • Testing for anti-sp100 and anti-gp210 (highly specific for PBC) can establish AMA-negative PBC without biopsy; if positive, the scheduled biopsy can be canceled.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Refer for ERCP: Not indicated with a normal MRCP and no obstructive features.

 

Option C. Trial of prednisone to see whether alkaline phosphatase improves: Empiric steroids are not appropriate for suspected isolated PBC (normal AST/ALT and IgG argue against AIH).

 

Option D. Check serum bile acids: Not useful for diagnosis of PBC; they are more relevant for cholestasis severity/symptom assessment (e.g., pruritus, pregnancy-related cholestasis).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In suspected AMA-negative PBC with cholestatic liver tests and normal cholangiography, check PBC-specific antibodies (anti-sp100, anti-gp210).
  • A diagnosis of PBC can be made without biopsy when cholestasis and PBC-specific autoantibodies are present.

choices.text: Convalescent rash or itching on extremities

questions.text: A 28-year-old man hospitalized with dengue with warning signs and is not recovering. Which of the following is not a sign of recovery of dengue patients?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Platelet count > 50,000/mm³

 

According to the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP, 2023):

 

  • Signs of Recovery
    • Stable pulse, blood pressure, and respiratory rate
    • Normal temperature
    • No external or internal bleeding
    • Return of appetite
    • No vomiting or abdominal pain
    • Good urinary output
    • Stable hematocrit at baseline level
    • Convalescent confluent petechial rash or itching, especially on extremities
  • Criteria for Discharge
    • Afebrile ≥ 24 hours without antipyretics
    • Presence of above signs of recovery
    • ≥ 2–3 days after recovery from shock (if present)
    • No respiratory distress from effusion/ascites
    • Platelet count > 50,000/mm³
  • Hence, platelet count > 50,000/mm³ is not a sign of recovery but a criterion for discharge.
  • Platelet rise usually lags behind clinical recovery and stabilization of hematocrit.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Normal temperature: Defervescence is an early and reliable sign of recovery.

 

Option B. Stable hematocrit at baseline level: Indicates resolution of plasma leakage and clinical stability.

 

Option D. Convalescent rash/itching on extremities: Typical of the recovery phase due to immune reactivation and skin re-perfusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In dengue, clinical recovery precedes hematologic normalization.
According to NVBDCP 2023, stable vitals, appetite return, good urine output, stable hematocrit, and convalescent rash define recovery, whereas platelet > 50,000/mm³ marks readiness for discharge, not recovery.

questions.text: A 56-year-old patient is diagnosed with advanced pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor (PNET). The oncologist chooses a targeted therapy that inhibits the mTOR pathway to reduce tumor proliferation and angiogenesis. Which of the following agents fits this profile?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Everolimus

 

  • Everolimus is a small molecule inhibitor of mTOR (mechanistic target of rapamycin) and is approved for use in advanced pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (PNETs).
  • By inhibiting mTOR, it interferes with cell growth, proliferation, and angiogenesis in tumor cells. 
  • It is also approved for renal cell carcinoma and other indications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Erlotinib: An EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitor used mainly in non-small cell lung cancer and pancreatic adenocarcinoma (with gemcitabine), not neuroendocrine tumors. It does not target mTOR.

 

Option C. Idelalisib: A PI3Kδ inhibitor approved for chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) and follicular lymphoma, not indicated in PNETs or as an mTOR inhibitor.

 

Option D. Olaparib: A PARP inhibitor used in BRCA-mutated ovarian and breast cancers. It targets DNA repair mechanisms and is not related to mTOR inhibition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Everolimus is a key mTOR inhibitor used in the management of advanced pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors. 
  • Its mechanism targets a pathway central to cell growth and angiogenesis, making it an effective agent in selected cancers with dysregulated mTOR signaling.

choices.text: Statement 1 is true; statement 2 is true
Statement 1 is true; statement 2 is false
Statement 1 is false; statement 2 is true
Statement 1 is false; statement 2 is false

questions.text:
Trimetazidine exerts its anti‑ischemic effect primarily via metabolic modulation in cardiomyocytes. Which of the following statements about its mechanism is true, and which is incorrect? 

 

  1. It inhibits mitochondrial long‑chain 3‑ketoacyl‑CoA thiolase, thereby reducing fatty acid β-oxidation and shifting energy utilization toward glucose.
  2. It causes significant coronary vasodilation and reduces myocardial oxygen demand via hemodynamic effects.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Statement 1 is true; statement 2 is false

 

Statement 1. It inhibits mitochondrial long‑chain 3‑ketoacyl‑CoA thiolase, thereby reducing fatty acid β-oxidation and shifting energy utilization toward glucose: True. Trimetazidine inhibits the mitochondrial enzyme 3‑ketoacyl‑CoA thiolase (LC-3-KAT), an essential component of β-oxidation of fatty acids. By inhibiting this pathway, the myocardium switches to glucose oxidation, which requires less oxygen per ATP molecule — a major advantage in ischemic tissue.

 

Statement 2. It causes significant coronary vasodilation and reduces myocardial oxygen demand via hemodynamic effects: False. Unlike nitrates or beta-blockers, trimetazidine does not exert any significant hemodynamic effect. It does not alter heart rate, blood pressure, or coronary vasomotor tone. Its benefit is purely metabolic, making it suitable in patients intolerant to hemodynamic agents.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Trimetazidine is a metabolic modulator, not a vasodilator.
  • It improves myocardial ischemia by enhancing glucose oxidation and reducing fatty acid metabolism, without affecting blood pressure or heart rate — making it ideal for stable angina patients who cannot tolerate standard antianginal drugs.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man has been fasting for the past 24 hours as part of a religious ritual. He reports feeling slightly weak but alert. His blood glucose is 65 mg/dL, and serum ketone levels are mildly elevated. Hormonal studies reveal a low insulin-to-glucagon ratio. Which of the following metabolic processes is least likely to occur under these hormonal conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Glycogen storage

 

  • This 25-year-old man has been fasting for 24 hours, which means his body is in a post-absorptive (fasting) state.
  • During fasting, insulin levels fall, and glucagon levels rise, resulting in a low insulin-to-glucagon ratio. 
  • This hormonal pattern promotes catabolic processes that generate glucose and energy substrates to maintain blood glucose levels and support essential organ function (especially the brain).
  • The man’s blood glucose level of 65 mg/dL (slightly low but not dangerously hypoglycemic) and mildly elevated serum ketones confirm a normal adaptive response to fasting. 
  • The low insulin-to-glucagon ratio activates enzymes involved in glycogenolysis (glycogen breakdown), gluconeogenesis (glucose synthesis from non-carbohydrate sources), and ketogenesis (production of ketone bodies from fatty acids) to provide energy.
  • In contrast, glycogen storage is an anabolic process that occurs in the fed state, when insulin levels are high and glucose is abundant. Under the current fasting, low-insulin, high-glucagon conditions, glycogen synthesis (storage) is suppressed, as the body prioritizes energy release, not storage.
  • Therefore, the metabolic process least likely to occur under these hormonal conditions is glycogen storage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glycogen breakdown: True (Likely to occur). In fasting, glycogenolysis is stimulated by the low insulin-to-glucagon ratio. Glucagon activates glycogen phosphorylase, which breaks down glycogen into glucose-1-phosphate, eventually yielding glucose for release into the bloodstream to maintain normal blood sugar levels.

 

Option B. Ketogenesis: True (Likely to occur). As fasting continues and hepatic glycogen stores become depleted, fatty acid oxidation increases, producing acetyl-CoA, which is converted into ketone bodies (acetoacetate, β-hydroxybutyrate) in the liver. The elevated serum ketones in this patient confirm that ketogenesis is active.

 

Option D. Gluconeogenesis: True (Likely to occur). When fasting exceeds several hours and glycogen stores begin to decline, the liver activates gluconeogenesis, producing glucose from substrates such as lactate, glycerol, and alanine. This ensures that blood glucose remains stable, especially for glucose-dependent tissues such as the brain and red blood cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During fasting, a low insulin-to-glucagon ratio stimulates glycogenolysis, gluconeogenesis, and ketogenesis, while glycogen storage is inhibited — making glycogen storage the least likely process to occur.

questions.text: Which of the following pairs of antibody and manifestation in SLE is correctly matched?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3

 

  • Based on the standard SLE autoantibody associations (as in Harrison’s 22e / ACR-EULAR), the correct pairings are:

 

 

Thus, the correctly matched antibodies are 1, 2, and 3.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Anti-Ro (SSA) → Subacute cutaneous lupus, neonatal lupus, heart block
  • Anti-dsDNA → Nephritis and disease activity marker
  • Antiphospholipid antibodies → Thrombotic CNS events and pregnancy loss
  • Anti-RNP → High interferon signature and MCTD overlap

questions.text:
Which pair of syndromic or metabolic cardiomyopathy and its management is correct? 

 

Statements:

 

  1. Sarcoidosis – Selective transthyretin stabilizer and polyneuropathy treatment
  2. Danon disease – Enzyme replacement therapy
  3. ATTR cardiac amyloidosis – Steroids and immunosuppressants
  4. Anderson–Fabry disease – Enzyme replacement therapy
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 4 only

 

Statement 4. Anderson–Fabry disease – Enzyme replacement therapy:

 

  • Anderson–Fabry disease is an X-linked lysosomal storage disorder caused by deficiency of α-galactosidase A.
  • Leads to accumulation of globotriaosylceramide (Gb3) in lysosomes, causing cardiac, renal, and neurological manifestations.
  • Treated with enzyme replacement therapy (ERT) using agalsidase-α or agalsidase-β, which replaces the deficient enzyme and slows disease progression.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 1. Sarcoidosis –– Selective transthyretin stabilizer and polyneuropathy treatment: Incorrect.

 

  • Cardiac sarcoidosis is treated with corticosteroids and, if needed, steroid-sparing immunosuppressants (e.g., methotrexate, azathioprine).
  • Selective transthyretin stabilizers (e.g., tafamidis) are used for ATTR amyloidosis, not sarcoidosis.

 

Statement 2. Danon disease – Enzyme replacement therapy: Incorrect.

 

  • Danon disease is an X-linked lysosomal storage disorder caused by LAMP2 deficiency.
  • No specific enzyme replacement therapy currently exists.
  • Management is supportive—heart failure therapy, ICD, or heart transplantation.
  • Enzyme replacement therapy applies to Anderson–Fabry or Pompe disease, not Danon.

 

Statement 3. ATTR cardiac amyloidosis – Steroids and immunosuppressants: Incorrect.

 

  • ATTR (transthyretin) amyloidosis is treated with selective transthyretin stabilizers (e.g., tafamidis, diflunisal) and neuropathy-directed therapy (e.g., patisiran, inotersen).
  • Steroids and immunosuppressants are not effective in ATTR amyloidosis; they are used in sarcoidosis.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following examination findings best helps differentiate episcleritis from scleritis in an outpatient setting?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Response of vessels to 2.5% phenylephrine

 

  • In episcleritis, the inflamed episcleral vessels blanch with topical 2.5% phenylephrine.
  • In scleritis, the inflamed deep scleral vessels do not blanch, because the inflammation is deeper and less accessible to the vasoconstrictive effect of phenylephrine.
  • This test is a commonly used clinical maneuver to distinguish between the two in real-life outpatient ophthalmologic practice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Loss of pupillary light reflex: This would suggest more severe intraocular pathology like optic nerve involvement, retinal detachment, or acute glaucoma, not typically seen in either episcleritis or scleritis.

 

Option C. Fluorescein staining of cornea:

 

  • Useful for corneal abrasions, ulcers, keratitis, etc.
  • Not relevant for differentiating episcleral vs. scleral inflammation (which is deeper).

 

Option D. Tonometry revealing increased intraocular pressure: Elevated IOP is associated with glaucoma or uveitis with angle involvement, not diagnostic for episcleritis or scleritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Episcleritis: Mild, self-limiting inflammation, vessels blanch with 2.5% phenylephrine.
  • Scleritis: Deep, severe pain, no blanching with phenylephrine, may impair vision.
  • Phenylephrine response is the most reliable outpatient clinical test to differentiate between the two.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with a persistent cough, weight loss, and night sweats for the past month. Chest radiograph reveals cavitary lesions in the upper lobe of the right lung. The schematic image below represents the cell envelope structure of the causative organism. Which of the following components depicted in the image is the primary urinary antigen detected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lipoarabinomannan (LAM)

 

  • Lipoarabinomannan (LAM) is a lipopolysaccharide specific to the Mycobacterium tuberculosis cell wall. 
  • It is released into body fluids during active infection and can be detected in urine, especially in immunocompromised patients (e.g., HIV). 
  • The image shows LAM as an extended branched structure (pink) linked to the mycobacterial cell wall. 
  • Detection of urinary LAM is a non-invasive diagnostic marker for active tuberculosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mycolic acid: These are long-chain fatty acids responsible for the acid-fast nature of the organism, but not excreted in urine or used for antigen detection.

 

Option B. Arabinogalactan: This polysaccharide links peptidoglycan to mycolic acids but remains bound within the bacterial cell wall; not excreted or antigenically detected in clinical tests.

 

Option D. Peptidoglycan: Present in almost all bacteria; not specific, and its fragments are not typically used in TB diagnostics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Urinary detection of Lipoarabinomannan (LAM), a unique mycobacterial lipoglycan, is used for rapid diagnosis of Mycobacterium tuberculosis, especially in immunocompromised patients.

questions.text: Match the following choose the correct match:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1–c, 2–b, 3–d, 4–a

 

  • 1–c. Cerebral circulation: Controlled mainly by local CO₂ and H⁺ levels → vasodilation when ↑CO₂ or ↓pH.
  • 2–b. Coronary circulation: Metabolic control (adenosine) dominates, increasing blood flow with cardiac work.
  • 3–d. Skeletal muscle: Resting tone under sympathetic vasoconstriction (α₁). During exercise, local metabolites override this.
  • 4–a. Renal circulation: Controlled by myogenic and tubuloglomerular feedback mechanisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Each vascular bed has a dominant autoregulatory mechanism:

 

  • Brain: CO₂ and H⁺ levels
  • Heart: Adenosine-mediated metabolic control
  • Muscle: Metabolic vasodilation
  • Kidney: Myogenic response

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman with a 15-year history of rheumatoid arthritis presents with chronic stiffness and deformity in her hands. She reports that she is unable to completely straighten the middle joint of her fingers. She often has trouble performing activities requiring fine motor control, like buttoning a shirt. An X-ray confirms chronic erosive changes consistent with RA. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this specific finger deformity?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Boutonnière Deformity

 

  • The definition of Boutonnière (French for "buttonhole") deformity is the specific posturing described: Flexion of the PIP joint combined with hyperextension of the DIP joint.
  • This deformity results from disruption (rupture or severe stretching) of the central slip of the extensor tendon at the PIP joint. 
  • Without the central slip, the lateral bands of the extensor mechanism slide downward (palmarward) and become flexors of the PIP joint, causing the PIP flexion. 
  • The tension then increases on the terminal tendon, causing compensatory DIP hyperextension.
  • The patient's history of chronic RA (a common cause), inability to straighten the middle joint (PIP flexion), and the specific posture fit the Boutonnière deformity perfectly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Swan-Neck Deformity:

 

  • Swan-neck deformity is the exact opposite posturing: Hyperextension of the PIP joint and flexion of the DIP joint. 
  • It is also common in RA but is defined by this contrasting position.

 

 

 

Option B. Mallet Finger:

 

  • Mallet finger involves an isolated injury or rupture of the terminal extensor tendon at the DIP joint. 
  • This leads to an isolated, uncontrolled flexion of the DIP joint only, with the PIP joint remaining straight or neutral. 
  • It does not involve the PIP joint flexion characteristic of the Boutonnière deformity.

 

 

Option D. Ulnar Drift:

 

  • Ulnar drift is a common overall hand deformity in RA characterized by the fingers deviating toward the ulnar (little finger) side at the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints. 
  • While present in the patient, it describes the hand-level deviation, not the specific PIP/DIP joint posturing of a single finger.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Boutonnière (or Buttonhole) Deformity is a characteristic finger deformity resulting from damage to the central slip of the extensor tendon at the Proximal Interphalangeal (PIP) joint.

choices.text: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis followed by staging laparotomy

questions.text: A 61-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with progressive abdominal distension and early satiety. Pelvic ultrasound shows a 10 cm complex adnexal mass with thick septations and ascites. Her CA-125 level is 580 U/mL. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis followed by staging laparotomy

 

  • In a postmenopausal woman presenting with a large complex adnexal mass, ascites, and markedly elevated CA-125, the primary concern is epithelial ovarian carcinoma.
  • The appropriate next step is to obtain a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis to assess the extent of disease, possible metastases, and operability, followed by a staging laparotomy (not laparoscopy) for both diagnosis and definitive surgical management.
  • Staging laparotomy includes:
    • Total abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy (TAH-BSO)
    • Omentectomy
    • Peritoneal washings and multiple peritoneal biopsies
    • Lymph node sampling
  • This approach allows for accurate staging and optimal cytoreduction, which are critical for prognosis and guiding postoperative chemotherapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serial ultrasound monitoring: Appropriate for premenopausal women with simple cysts <5 cm and normal CA-125 levels. In a postmenopausal woman with a large complex mass and elevated CA-125, this would delay diagnosis and treatment.

 

Option B. Immediate chemotherapy: Chemotherapy should never precede histologic confirmation unless the patient is medically unfit for surgery or has inoperable disease confirmed by imaging and biopsy. First-line management is surgical staging and cytoreduction.

 

Option D. Repeat CA-125 level in 2 weeks: Repeating CA-125 is useful for monitoring known disease, not for initial diagnosis. The markedly elevated CA-125 with imaging findings already warrants immediate further evaluation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a postmenopausal woman with a complex adnexal mass, ascites, and elevated CA-125, the most appropriate next step is a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis to evaluate disease extent, followed by staging laparotomy for diagnosis, staging, and surgical management of suspected ovarian carcinoma.

questions.text:
All of the following statements about vaccination in HIV or immunosuppressed individuals are incorrect, except?

 

  1. In asymptomatic HIV, there are no vaccine contraindications listed.
  2. In symptomatic HIV, all live vaccines are absolutely contraindicated.
  3. In symptomatic HIV, MMR and varicella (and zoster) may be given if required.
  4. In corticosteroid-induced immunosuppression, all live vaccines are contraindicated.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 3 and 4 only

 

Statement 1. In asymptomatic HIV, there are no vaccine contraindications listed: Correct. In the provided program list, asymptomatic HIV has no specific vaccine contraindications noted; routine immunization generally proceeds as indicated.

 

Statement 3. In symptomatic HIV, MMR and varicella (and zoster) may be given if required: Correct. Although live vaccines are usually avoided in symptomatic HIV, the list explicitly allows MMR, varicella, and zoster when required.

 

Statement 4. In corticosteroid-induced immunosuppression, all live vaccines are contraindicated: Correct. All live vaccines are contraindicated during significant immunosuppression (e.g., high-dose systemic corticosteroids).

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 2. In symptomatic HIV, MMR and varicella (and zoster) may be given if required: Incorrect. “All live vaccines are absolutely contraindicated in symptomatic HIV” is too strict because MMR, varicella, and zoster are permitted exceptions in the provided guidance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Asymptomatic HIV: no listed vaccine contraindications.
  • Symptomatic HIV: live vaccines generally avoided except MMR, varicella, and zoster may be given if required.
  • Any significant immunosuppression (e.g., high-dose steroids): avoid all live vaccines.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman has 4 days of high fever (40°C), arthralgia, and a diffuse pink macular rash on the trunk. Exam shows synovitis of proximal small joints in both hands and tenderness over both MTPs. Vitals are stable (HR 95, BP 108/80, SpO₂ 97%). CBC is normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chikungunya fever

 

  • This patient’s presentation of acute high-grade fever, maculopapular rash, and severe polyarthralgia with synovitis strongly suggests Chikungunya fever, an RNA virus (Togaviridae, Alphavirus) transmitted by the Aedes mosquito.

 

Key diagnostic clues:

 

  • High fever and polyarthritis/polyarthralgia (especially small joints of hands and feet)
  • Maculopapular or pinkish rash on trunk and limbs
  • Normal platelet and WBC counts (distinguishes from dengue)
  • Usually self-limited but joint pain can persist for months in some cases

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dengue fever: Often presents with thrombocytopenia, leukopenia, severe myalgia (“breakbone fever”), and sometimes hemorrhagic manifestations — not seen here.

 

Option C. Zika virus infection: Typically causes mild fever, conjunctivitis, and maculopapular rash with less severe arthralgia.

 

Option D. Falciparum malaria: Characterized by high fever with chills, anemia, and splenomegaly, none of which are seen in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chikungunya fever is a mosquito-borne viral infection characterized by:

 

 

Key distinction:

 

  • Severe arthralgia with normal platelet count → Chikungunya
  • Thrombocytopenia and hemorrhagic signs → Dengue

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a known history of severe lumbar disc herniation presents to the OPD with a 24-hour history of severe low back pain radiating down both legs, bilateral leg weakness, and numbness in his inner thighs and buttocks. He reports difficulty initiating urination and an inability to feel the sensation of a full bladder. Physical examination reveals decreased anal sphincter tone and absent ankle jerks bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cauda Equina Syndrome

 

  • CES represents a massive compression of the cauda equina nerve roots (L2-S5) below the termination of the spinal cord. The classic presentation—which is fully met by the patient—involves:
    • Saddle Anesthesia: Numbness and paresthesia affecting the perineum, buttocks, and inner thighs, corresponding to the S2-S5 nerve roots.
    • Bowel and Bladder Dysfunction: Urinary retention (difficulty initiating urination and inability to sense a full bladder) is the most sensitive sign, often accompanied by decreased anal sphincter tone. This is critical for S2-S4 function.
    • Bilateral Lower Extremity Deficits: Multi-level weakness and sensory changes, evidenced here by bilateral leg weakness and absent ankle jerks (S1 root).
  • The patient's history of a severe lumbar disc herniation is the most common cause of acute CES. This condition requires emergency surgical decompression to prevent permanent neurological damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lumbar Radiculopathy:

 

  • Lumbar radiculopathy is compression of a single nerve root (e.g., L5 or S1), typically caused by a smaller, unilateral disc herniation. 
  • The symptoms are characterized by pain, numbness, and weakness in the distribution of that single root, and are nearly always unilateral. 
  • Radiculopathy does not cause bilateral neurological deficits or bladder/bowel dysfunction, making it an incorrect diagnosis for this severe, bilateral presentation.

 

Option B. Spinal Stenosis:

 

  • Spinal stenosis is a chronic narrowing of the spinal canal, most common in older adults, leading to neurogenic claudication (leg pain/weakness brought on by standing or walking and relieved by sitting or bending forward). 
  • While severe stenosis can occasionally precipitate CES, the typical presentation is chronic and positional, not the acute, severe onset of catastrophic deficits involving bladder function seen here.

 

Option C. Transverse Myelitis:

 

  • Transverse myelitis is an inflammatory disorder of the spinal cord itself.
