  • Pathology involving the spinal cord (above L1/L2) causes upper motor neuron (UMN) signs below the level of the lesion, which include spasticity, hyperreflexia, and a positive Babinski sign. 
  • Since CES affects the nerve roots (lower motor neurons) below the cord, it causes flaccidity and absent reflexes (lower motor neuron signs), as evidenced by the absent ankle jerks. 
  • Therefore, the pattern of deficits is inconsistent with a spinal cord lesion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize Cauda Equina Syndrome (CES) as an acute neurosurgical emergency by identifying its characteristic clinical triad—saddle anesthesia, bowel/bladder dysfunction, and bilateral, multi-level lower extremity motor/sensory deficits—and differentiating it from more common, less urgent spinal pathologies.

questions.text: Match the following diagnostic/public health tests with their purpose:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-c, 2-a, 3-b, 4-d

 

  • 1-c. Shake Test → Freeze damage to aluminium-adjuvanted vaccines: Used to check if vaccines like DPT, TT, Hep B, PCV13 have been damaged by freezing.
  • 2-a. Schick Test → Susceptibility to diphtheria: An intradermal skin test to detect immunity against diphtheria toxin.
  • 3-b. Habel Test → Potency of rabies vaccine: An in vivo test historically used to assess rabies vaccine potency.
  • 4-d. Tine Test → Screening for tuberculosis: An outdated, multipuncture skin test for TB exposure, less reliable than Mantoux.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Shake test: Cold chain quality check for freeze-sensitive vaccines.
  • Schick test: Diphtheria susceptibility.
  • Habel test: Rabies vaccine potency.
  • Tine test, Heaf test, Mantoux test: TB screening.

questions.text: A patient with oral carcinoma requires free tissue transfer for reconstruction after resection. This type of flap is best classified as which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fasciocutaneous flap

 

  • The radial forearm free flap (FRAFF) is a fasciocutaneous flap. 
  • It is based on fasciocutaneous perforators arising from the radial artery, with the greatest density of perforators between 12–20 cm from its origin. 
  • This flap provides a thin, pliable, and reliable tissue for reconstruction, making it especially useful in oral cavity and head-neck reconstruction where contour and mobility are important.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Myocutaneous flap: Incorrect. These include flaps like latissimus dorsi or transverse rectus abdominis (TRAM), where both muscle and overlying skin are transferred together. FRAFF does not include muscle.

 

Option B. Osseomyocutaneous flap: Incorrect. These involve bone along with muscle and skin, such as fibula osteocutaneous flap or iliac crest flaps. The radial forearm flap can sometimes include a small segment of radius bone, but the standard FRAFF is fasciocutaneous only.

 

Option C. Subcutaneous flap: Incorrect. Pure subcutaneous flaps are rare and consist only of fat and overlying skin. FRAFF has a fascial component and is classified under fasciocutaneous flaps.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The free radial artery forearm flap is a fasciocutaneous flap based on radial artery perforators, widely used in head and neck reconstructive surgery for its thin, pliable, and reliable tissue.

choices.text: A lesion at point C results in paralytic agitans, while a lesion at point F leads to disturbance in the Papez circuit.
Point B is considered the fifth lobe of the brain, and point F is part of the sixth (limbic) lobe.
Point A is not part of the basal nuclei, while point F is not part of the limbic system.
Point D represents the largest commissural fiber, and point E acts as an afferent to the mammillary body.

questions.text: All of the following statements regarding the labelled brain sections are correct, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Point A is not part of the basal nuclei, while point F is not part of the limbic system.

 

  • Point A (Claustrum) is not part of the basal nuclei, but F (Hippocampus) is part of the limbic system, making the statement incorrect.
  • Point C (Substantia Nigra) → Lesion here causes parkinsonism (paralytic agitans) due to dopaminergic neuron loss.
  • Point F (Hippocampus) → Involved in the Papez circuit, crucial for memory and emotion, part of the limbic lobe.
  • Point B (Insula) → Considered the fifth lobe of the brain.
  • Point D (Corpus Callosum) → The largest commissural fiber, connecting both cerebral hemispheres.
  • Point E (Fornix) → Carries afferent fibers from the hippocampus to the mammillary bodies.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hippocampus forms an essential component of the limbic system and the Papez circuit, while the corpus callosum is the largest commissural fiber connecting the cerebral hemispheres.

questions.text: A patient was treated with steroids for psoriasis. On stopping the treatment, he developed fever, malaise, and pustular lesions as shown in the image below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pustular psoriasis

 

  • Pustular psoriasis is an acute, severe, and potentially life-threatening variant of psoriasis characterized by widespread sterile pustules on an erythematous base.
  • It is often precipitated by sudden withdrawal of systemic corticosteroids or coal tar therapy in a patient with chronic plaque psoriasis.

 

Clinical features include:

 

  • Fever, malaise, leukocytosis (systemic toxicity)
  • Sterile pustules that may coalesce to form “lakes of pus”
  • Histology shows spongiform pustules of Kogoj (collections of neutrophils in epidermis)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Staphylococcal infection: Causes pustules filled with infected pus (positive culture) and systemic sepsis; not seen following steroid withdrawal.

 

Option C. Acute generalized exanthematous pustulosis (AGEP): A drug reaction (commonly to beta-lactams or macrolides) with pinpoint pustules and rapid desquamation, resolving within days after drug withdrawal; not related to psoriasis.

 

Option D. Subcorneal pustulosis (Sneddon–Wilkinson disease): A chronic relapsing sterile pustular dermatosis seen in middle-aged women, limited to flexural areas, and not associated with systemic toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Withdrawal of systemic corticosteroids in a psoriatic patient can precipitate generalized pustular psoriasis (von Zumbusch type) — a dermatologic emergency characterized by fever, malaise, and widespread sterile pustules on erythematous skin.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of low back stiffness and pain that is worst in the morning and improves significantly with exercise. She also reports alternating buttock pain. Her physical exam is notable for restricted range of motion in the lumbar spine. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ankylosing Spondylitis

 

  • The patient's presentation perfectly aligns with the diagnostic profile of AS:
    • Patient Profile: Young man (30-year-old).
    • Pain Pattern (Inflammatory): Back pain that is worst in the morning and improves significantly with exercise. This is the hallmark of inflammatory back pain.
    • Clinical Signs: Restricted range of motion and alternating buttock pain (referred pain from the sacroiliac joints).
    • Radiographic Signs: Bilateral sacroiliitis (erosions and fusion in the SI joints) is the earliest and most essential radiographic feature. Thin, vertical syndesmophytes represent the classic spine ossification pattern.
  • The presence of sacroiliitis combined with inflammatory back pain in a young man makes AS the definitive diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diffuse Idiopathic Skeletal Hyperostosis:

 

  • Rationale: DISH is a major differential for spinal ossification but is easily distinguished by key factors:
    • Patient Profile: Typically affects older individuals (≥50 years), often associated with obesity and diabetes.
    • Pain Pattern (Mechanical/Non-inflammatory): Back pain is usually mild stiffness, often not significantly improved by exercise.
    • Radiographic Contrast: DISH is characterized by thick, "flowing" ossification (like melted candle wax) that bridges vertebrae, but crucially, the sacroiliac joints are preserved (no erosions or fusion), and the disc spaces are generally maintained.
  • The patient's age and, most importantly, the presence of sacroiliitis strongly rule out classic DISH.

 

Option C. Osteoarthritis:

 

  • Rationale: Osteoarthritis (OA) is a degenerative joint disease:
    • Patient Profile: Usually affects older individuals.
    • Pain Pattern (Mechanical): Pain is typically worse with activity and relieved by rest (the opposite of this patient's symptoms).
    • Radiographic Contrast: While OA causes osteophytes (bony spurs), it does not cause the severe, bilateral erosive and fusing changes seen in the sacroiliac joints (sacroiliitis) or the specific thin, vertical syndesmophytes of AS.
  • The inflammatory nature of the pain and the specific radiographic signs of sacroiliitis excludes OA.

 

Option D. Osteomyelitis:

 

  • Rationale: Osteomyelitis is a bone infection:
    • Pain Pattern: Causes severe, localized, acute pain that is often unremitting and may be accompanied by systemic signs like fever and malaise.
    • Radiographic Contrast: X-rays would show signs of acute bony destruction and disc space narrowing at the site of infection, typically involving only one or two segments, not the bilateral, chronic inflammatory changes seen across the entire sacroiliac joint and spine.
  • The chronic, 6-month history and the specific widespread, bilateral inflammatory pattern rule out acute bacterial bone infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The classic inflammatory features (clinical and radiographic) that differentiate Ankylosing Spondylitis (AS) from other chronic spine conditions, particularly the distinction between inflammatory and mechanical back pain patterns, and the specific radiographic signs of sacroiliitis and syndesmophytes.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions best describes Kallmann syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism with anosmia

 

  • Kallmann syndrome is a congenital form of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism caused by defective migration of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) neurons and olfactory neurons from the olfactory placode to the hypothalamus during embryonic development.
  • As a result:
    • GnRH secretion is decreased, leading to low LH and FSH levels.
    • Testosterone (or estrogen) levels are also reduced.
    • The olfactory bulbs fail to develop, resulting in anosmia (loss of smell).

 

Clinical features include:

 

  • Delayed or absent puberty
  • Micropenis, cryptorchidism in males
  • Amenorrhea in females
  • Loss of smell (anosmia or hyposmia)
  • Occasionally midline defects (e.g., cleft lip/palate)

 

Genetics: Most commonly X-linked recessive (KAL1 gene), though autosomal variants exist.

 

Treatment: Pulsatile GnRH therapy or exogenous gonadotropins to induce puberty and restore fertility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism with gynecomastia: Seen in Klinefelter syndrome (47,XXY) due to primary testicular failure, resulting in high LH and FSH, not seen in Kallmann syndrome.

 

Option C. Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism with short stature: Occurs in Turner syndrome (45, X), affecting females with streak ovaries and elevated gonadotropins, not males.

 

Option D. Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism with normal olfaction: Can result from hypothalamic or pituitary disorders but without olfactory deficits, distinguishing it from Kallmann syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kallmann syndrome is characterized by hypogonadotropic hypogonadism with anosmia due to failed migration of GnRH and olfactory neurons, resulting in delayed puberty and infertility.

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient presents with chronic knee pain. An X-ray shows a lytic lesion, and a non-contrast CT (NCCT) was performed for better evaluation. The scan demonstrates a well-circumscribed, nonaggressive lesion without cortical breach or periosteal reaction. Which of the following features would not be expected in this type of lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Associated exophytic soft-tissue component

 

  • Nonaggressive bone lesions (e.g., unicameral bone cyst, enchondroma) typically demonstrate:
    • Well-defined lytic appearance → margins are smooth.
    • Narrow zone of transition → indicates slow-growing/benign process.
    • Sclerotic rim may or may not be present → but absence of sclerosis does not imply aggressiveness if other benign features are present.
  • Aggressive lesions (osteosarcoma, Ewing sarcoma, metastasis) usually demonstrate:
    • Wide zone of transition.
    • Cortical destruction.
    • Exophytic soft-tissue component due to breach of periosteum and extraosseous extension.
  • Hence, exophytic soft-tissue component is not compatible with a nonaggressive lesion, making it the correct “except” choice.
  • Indicates aggressiveness → not seen in nonaggressive lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Well-defined lytic lesion: Classic for benign/nonaggressive pathology.

 

Option B. Narrow zone of transition: Hallmark of benign lesions.

 

Option C. No surrounding sclerotic rim: Benign lesions may lack sclerosis (not all have a rim).

 

Educational Objective:

 

In bone imaging, zone of transition is the most reliable indicator of aggressiveness:

 

  • Narrow zone → benign.
  • Wide zone/poorly defined → malignant/aggressive. Presence of a soft-tissue component strongly suggests an aggressive lesion.

questions.text: Match the following genes with their associated conditions:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1–B, 2–C, 3–A, 4–D

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • SMAD 2/4 → TGF-β regulation → Juvenile polyposis
  • VHL gene → chromosome 3p25 deletion → Renal cell carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, hemangioblastoma
  • SDHB gene → mitochondrial dysfunction → Paraganglioma, pheochromocytoma
  • STK11 gene → kinase tumor suppressor → Peutz–Jeghers syndrome

questions.text: A 28-year-old nurse frequently presents to the emergency department with unexplained hypoglycemic episodes. Lab results show low blood glucose with high insulin levels but suppressed C-peptide. She refuses psychiatric referral and changes hospitals often. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Factitious disorder

 

  • The clinical picture shows intentional production of symptoms (hypoglycemia via insulin injection) in the absence of external rewards (e.g., financial gain, avoiding responsibilities), suggesting Factitious Disorder. 
  • Key lab finding is high insulin with low C-peptide, pointing to exogenous insulin administration. 
  • Her behavior of hospital hopping and refusal of psychiatric referral further supports a diagnosis rooted in a desire to assume the sick role, which is typical of factitious disorder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Somatic symptom disorder: This involves unintentional symptoms that are medically unexplained, often accompanied by anxiety about health. Here, the hypoglycemia is intentionally induced, which rules this out.

 

Option C. Malingering: Also involves intentional symptom production, but with clear external rewards (e.g., avoiding work, gaining drugs, financial compensation). In this case, there’s no external incentive, making malingering unlikely.

 

Option D. Illness anxiety disorder: Characterized by preoccupation with having or acquiring a serious illness despite normal medical evaluation. There’s no fabrication or induction of symptoms in illness anxiety disorder, unlike in factitious disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Factitious disorder (Munchausen syndrome) is characterized by the willful production of false symptoms (physical or psychological) or exaggeration of actual symptoms to get medical attention. 
  • Pseudologia fantastica is the term used for the ‘false stories’ that these patients make to get medical attention. 
  • Often, signs of previous interventions, such as scars from previous surgeries, are present. 
  • The patient may have a gridiron abdomen (mass of scars on the abdomen).
  • The term ‘professional patients’ has been used for these patients, and the illness has been called ‘hospital addiction’ or ‘poly surgical addiction’. Patients try to assume a sick role (i.e., they want to be treated as if they are very sick and want extra attention from doctors and medical staff).

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with gradual, progressive hearing loss, especially for high-pitched sounds and conversations in noisy environments. Audiometry shows bilateral, symmetric, down-sloping sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) involving higher frequencies. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Presbycusis

 

  • Presbycusis is age-related bilateral symmetric high-frequency SNHL, caused by degenerative changes in the cochlea — particularly loss of hair cells at the basal turn (which encodes high frequencies).
  • The audiogram typically shows a bilateral down-sloping curve — the hallmark of presbycusis.
  • It begins insidiously, leading to difficulty in hearing high-pitched sounds, understanding speech in noisy places, and impaired speech discrimination.
  • No associated vertigo or tinnitus (unlike Ménière’s disease).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endolymphatic hydrops (Ménière’s disease): Causes fluctuating low-frequency SNHL, not high-frequency; usually unilateral and associated with vertigo + tinnitus.

 

Option B. Noise-induced trauma: Produces a notch-type audiogram at 4000 Hz (Boilermaker’s notch), typically asymmetrical and occupationally related.

 

Educational Objective:


A bilateral, symmetric, down-sloping high-frequency SNHL is characteristic of presbycusis, the most common cause of hearing loss in the elderly due to cochlear hair cell degeneration at the basal turn.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding adrenaline dosing is correct? 

 

  1. 1:10,000 is preferred IV during cardiac arrest 
  2. 1:200,000 adrenaline with local anesthetic reduces systemic adverse effects and prolongs duration of action of local anaesthetics
  3. 1:1,000 can be safely used IV in adult anaphylactic shock
  4. 1:100 adrenaline is used for inhalational therapy in severe asthma attacks
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 4 only

 

Statement 1. 1:10,000 is preferred IV during cardiac arrest: 1:10,000 (0.1 mg/mL) is the correct IV formulation for cardiac arrest, allowing controlled systemic administration.

 

Statement 2. 1:200,000 adrenaline with local anesthetic reduces systemic adverse effects and prolongs duration of action of local anaesthetics: 1:200,000 adrenaline is commonly mixed with lidocaine or other anesthetics to reduce bleeding and prolong effect, especially in dental and minor procedures.

 

Statement 4. 1:100 adrenaline is used for inhalational therapy in severe asthma attacks: 1:100 adrenaline (10 mg/mL) may be diluted for nebulization in life-threatening asthma or croup, especially in pediatrics.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 3. 1:1,000 can be safely used IV in adult anaphylactic shock: Incorrect. 1:1,000 adrenaline (1 mg/mL) is NOT given IV — it is used intramuscularly or subcutaneously for anaphylaxis. IV use of this concentration can lead to fatal arrhythmias and hypertensive crises.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Adrenaline formulations must be matched precisely with the route and indication:
    • 1:1,000 → IM/SC (Anaphylaxis)
    • 1:10,000 → IV (Cardiac arrest)
    • 1:200,000 → With LA (minor surgery)
    • 1:100 → Nebulized (rare/emergency bronchospasm cases)
  • Improper dosing can lead to severe cardiovascular complications.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man with advanced HIV (CD4 count <50 cells/µL) presents with multiple red, vascular, nodular skin lesions on his trunk and face. The lesions are friable and bleed on touch. A biopsy reveals vascular proliferation with neutrophilic infiltrate and bacilli that are silver-stain positive. He also reports close contact with cats. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bartonella henselae

 

  • Bacillary angiomatosis is a vascular proliferative disease caused by Bartonella spp., typically affecting immunocompromised patients, especially those with AIDS.
  • Bartonella henselae is the most common cause, and is transmitted by cat scratches, bites, or flea exposure.
  • Bartonella quintana can also cause bacillary angiomatosis but is less common, and associated with trench fever and lice exposure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bartonella quintana: Less common cause of bacillary angiomatosis; transmitted via body lice.

 

Option B. Bartonella bacilliformis: Causes Carrion’s disease (Oroya fever and verruga peruana); seen in South America.

 

Option D. Bartonella elizabethae:  Rare; associated with culture-negative endocarditis, not bacillary angiomatosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bartonella henselae is the most frequent cause of bacillary angiomatosis in AIDS patients, presenting with angiomatous skin lesions. 
  • Diagnosis is confirmed with Warthin-Starry staining or PCR. 
  • Macrolides are the treatment of choice.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with recurrent bacterial skin infections and poor wound healing with history of delayed separation of the umbilical cord. Despite infection, no pus is seen, and a wound swab shows absence of neutrophils at the site. Laboratory findings reveal marked neutrophilia. Which of the following molecular defects best explains this child’s condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Integrins (CD18)

 

  • This child’s presentation is characteristic of Leukocyte Adhesion Deficiency type 1 (LAD-1), a rare congenital immunodeficiency caused by defective β2 integrins (CD18 subunit) on leukocytes.
  • Normal process of leukocyte adhesion and migration:
    1. Margination and rolling: Mediated by selectins (E-selectin, P-selectin).
    2. Adhesion (firm attachment): Mediated by integrins on leukocytes binding to ICAM (CD54, CD102) and VCAM (CD106) on endothelial cells.
    3. Transmigration (diapedesis): Mediated by PECAM-1 (CD31).

 

In LAD-1:

 

  • Mutation in CD18 → defective integrin function → failure of firm adhesion.
  • Neutrophils cannot migrate out of circulation to infection sites, leading to:
    • Recurrent bacterial infections without pus formation
    • Delayed umbilical cord separation (>30 days)
    • Leukocytosis and neutrophilia

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Selectins: Mediate rolling phase of leukocyte extravasation, not firm adhesion. Defect in selectins would impair initial rolling, not adhesion.

 

Option C. ICAM-1 (CD54): Endothelial adhesion molecule that interacts with integrins. The defect in LAD is on leukocytes (CD18 integrins), not on the endothelial ICAM.

 

Option D. PECAM-1 (CD31): Involved in transmigration (movement through endothelium). Defect would impair diapedesis, not adhesion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Firm adhesion of leukocytes to endothelium during inflammation is mediated by integrins (CD18) binding to ICAM and VCAM.
  • Deficiency of CD18 causes Leukocyte Adhesion Deficiency type 1 (LAD-1), presenting with delayed umbilical cord separation, recurrent bacterial infections, and absence of pus formation.

questions.text:
Based on the Rotterdam criteria for diagnosing polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), evaluate the following statements:

  1. Hyperandrogenism can be clinical (hirsutism, acne) or biochemical (elevated testosterone).
  2. Oligo- or anovulation is defined as fewer than 9 cycles per year or cycles lasting more than 35 days.
  3. The diagnosis requires all three criteria to be present simultaneously.
  4. Polycystic ovaries are defined as ≥12 antral follicles in one ovary or ovarian volume >10 cm³.

Which of the following options is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2 and 4 are correct

 

  • The Rotterdam criteria (2003) state that PCOS is diagnosed when any two of the following three features are present (after excluding other endocrine causes):
    1. Hyperandrogenism – may be clinical (hirsutism, acne, androgenic alopecia) or biochemical (elevated serum testosterone or DHEAS).
    2. Oligo- or anovulation – characterized by <9 menstrual cycles per year or cycles lasting >35 days.
    3. Polycystic ovaries on ultrasound – ≥12 antral follicles in one ovary and/or ovarian volume >10 cm³.

Only two out of three criteria are required for diagnosis. Therefore, statement 3 (“all three criteria required”) is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) is diagnosed when any two of the following three are present:
    • Hyperandrogenism (clinical or biochemical)
    • Oligo-/anovulation (<9 cycles/year or >35-day cycles)
    • Polycystic ovaries (≥12 follicles or ovarian volume >10 cm³)

questions.text: During examination of a 6-year-old child with a history of poor weight gain and recurrent respiratory infections, you note a harsh systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border associated with a palpable thrill. The child's height and weight are below the 5th percentile for age. Chest X-ray findings are shown below. Echocardiography is pending. What grade of murmur is this most likely to be?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Grade 4/6 

 

  • This murmur has characteristics of Grade 4/6, which is defined as a loud murmur with an associated palpable thrill. 
  • The presence of a palpable thrill is the key diagnostic feature that distinguishes a Grade 4 murmur from lower grades. 
  • In this case, the VSD (Ventricular Septal Defect) produces a harsh systolic murmur at the left sternal border, which is typical of this condition. 
  • The poor weight gain indicates a hemodynamically significant VSD with increased pulmonary blood flow, which is consistent with a Grade 4 murmur.
  • TIPTOE" - From softest to loudest:
    • Tiny whisper (Grade 1) - Barely audible, need perfect conditions
    • Identifiable easily (Grade 2) - Quiet but clearly audible
    • Prominent sound (Grade 3) - Moderately loud, no thrill
    • Thrill appears (Grade 4) - Loud with palpable thrill
    • Off chest partially (Grade 5) - Very loud, stethoscope partially lifted
    • Even without stethoscope (Grade 6) - Can be heard without stethoscope

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Grade 2/6: This describes a soft but easily audible murmur without thrill. Grade 2 murmurs are not associated with a palpable thrill, and they are typically not harsh in quality. A Grade 2 murmur would be unlikely to correlate with the significant clinical findings (poor weight gain) described in this patient.

 

Option B. Grade 3/6: While this is a moderately loud murmur, Grade 3 murmurs do not have an associated thrill. They are defined as loud murmurs that are easily heard but without a palpable thrill. Since this patient has a palpable thrill, the murmur must be at least Grade 4.

 

Option D. Grade 5/6: A Grade 5 murmur is very loud and can be heard with the stethoscope partly off the chest wall. While Grade 5 murmurs also have a thrill, they represent a more severe finding than described in this clinical scenario. Grade 5 murmurs are often associated with more severe symptoms and clinical deterioration.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The Levine grading system for cardiac murmurs is based on intensity, with Grades 1-6. 
  • The presence of a palpable thrill is the defining characteristic of a Grade 4/6 murmur or higher. 
  • In pediatric patients with VSD, the grade of the murmur often correlates with the size of the defect and its hemodynamic significance.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with a BP of 230/125 mmHg and rising creatinine is started on IV antihypertensive therapy. Within hours, his urine output improves, and BP begins to normalize. The drug acts via peripheral arterial dilation and increases renal perfusion. Which of the following drugs can produce these effects?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fenoldopam

 

  • This patient presents with a hypertensive emergency (severely elevated BP with evidence of target-organ damage, in this case rising creatinine). 
  • The improvement in urine output after antihypertensive treatment suggests enhanced renal perfusion, which helps distinguish the mechanism of action.
  • Fenoldopam is a selective dopamine-1 receptor agonist that causes arteriolar vasodilation, especially in renal, mesenteric, coronary, and peripheral arteries. 
  • It:
    • Increases renal blood flow and glomerular filtration rate (GFR)
    • Promotes natriuresis and diuresis
    • Is particularly useful in hypertensive emergencies with renal impairment
    • Is given intravenously with a short half-life, allowing tight BP control
  • These properties match the clinical improvement observed in this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nicardipine: IV calcium channel blocker (DHP type) → arterial vasodilator. Used in hypertensive emergencies, but does not improve renal perfusion specifically.

 

Option B. Sodium nitroprusside: Releases NO → arterial + venous vasodilator. Rapidly lowers BP but can decrease renal perfusion and causes cyanide toxicity.

 

Option D. Labetalol: α₁ and β-blocker. Effective IV drug for hypertensive emergencies, but no renal vasodilatory effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fenoldopam is a selective dopamine-1 receptor agonist used in hypertensive emergencies. 
  • It lowers blood pressure while increasing renal perfusion and is particularly beneficial in patients with acute kidney injury.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with a sensation of vaginal heaviness and difficulty walking. On pelvic examination, Valsalva maneuver demonstrates descent of the vaginal wall and uterus, confirming pelvic organ prolapse and finding is shown below. Based on this finding, which stage of prolapse best describes her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Stage II

 

  • Pelvic organ prolapse (POP) occurs when the pelvic floor muscles and connective tissues weaken, allowing the uterus or vaginal walls to descend. 
  • The diagnosis is confirmed on physical examination, often by performing a Valsalva maneuver or asking the patient to bear down, which accentuates the descent.
  • In the image the leading edge of the bulge is observed to be approximately even with the plane of the hymen or within 1 cm distal to it.
  • The Pelvic Organ Prolapse Quantification (POP-Q) system classifies prolapse based on the relationship between the leading edge of the prolapsed organ and the hymenal plane:

 

 

  • Since the leading edge of the prolapse is at or within 1 cm of the hymen, the correct diagnosis is Stage II prolapse.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stage IV: Represents complete eversion of the vagina or total uterine procidentia, where the entire vaginal wall and uterus lie outside the introitus—more severe than the described finding.

 

Option B. Stage I: Occurs when the prolapse remains more than 1 cm above the hymen and is often not visible externally.

 

Option C. Stage III: Defined as descent of the leading edge >1 cm below the hymen but not complete eversion—more advanced than this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pelvic organ prolapse is assessed during a pelvic examination with a Valsalva maneuver. When the leading edge of the prolapse is at or within 1 cm of the hymen, it is classified as Stage II prolapse according to the POP-Q system.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding the diagnostic criteria for multiple myeloma are correct? 

 

  1. The presence of ≥10% clonal plasma cells in bone marrow or a biopsy-proven plasmacytoma is essential for diagnosis.
  2. Hypercalcemia, defined as serum calcium >11.5 mg/dL, is a myeloma-defining event.
  3. Renal impairment is considered when serum creatinine exceeds 1 mg/dL or GFR falls below 60 mL/min.
  4. Anemia with hemoglobin <10 g/dL or ≥2 g/dL below normal is a criterion for end-organ damage.
  5. One or more osteolytic bone lesions detected on radiographic imaging confirms bone involvement.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Only 1, 2, 4 and 5 are correct

 

  • Diagnosis of Multiple Myeloma (MM) requires ≥10% clonal plasma cells in the bone marrow or a biopsy-proven plasmacytoma, AND
  • Evidence of myeloma-defining events, summarized by the mnemonic CRAB:

 

 

Incorrect statement:

 

Statement 3. Renal impairment is considered when serum creatinine exceeds 1 mg/dL or GFR falls below 60 mL/min: Incorrect because renal impairment in MM requires creatinine >2 mg/dL, not 1 mg/dL, and GFR <40 mL/min, not 60 mL/min.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnosis of multiple myeloma requires evidence of clonal plasma cell proliferation (≥10%) along with one or more myeloma-defining events (CRAB — hyperCalcemia, Renal dysfunction, Anemia, Bone lesions) indicating end-organ damage.

questions.text:
Regarding the importance and limitations of the Dependency Ratio, which statements are correct? 

 

  1. A higher DR indicates increased strain on the working population.
  2. DR includes economic status (employed/unemployed) of the population in its calculation.
  3. DR is considered a crude index because it does not differentiate between earners and non-earners.
  4. An increasing old age DR implies greater pressure on pension systems and health services.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 3 and 4 only

 

Statement 1. A higher DR indicates increased strain on the working population: Correct. A high dependency ratio means fewer people in the working-age group (15–64 years) are supporting more dependents (children and elderly), increasing economic pressure.

 

Statement 3. DR is considered a crude index because it does not differentiate between earners and non-earners: Correct. As it does not consider whether a person is economically active, it's considered crude. For example, a 30-year-old unemployed person is not counted as dependent by DR.

 

Statement 4. An increasing old age DR implies greater pressure on pension systems and health services: Correct. An increase in old-age DR reflects more elderly people requiring pension, health care, and long-term support, which burdens public health and social welfare systems.

 

Incorrect Statement

 

Statement 2. DR includes economic status (employed/unemployed) of the population in its calculation: Incorrect. DR is a crude measure. It does not account for actual employment or income status — it’s based purely on age structure, not on whether individuals are working or not.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understand that the Dependency Ratio is a demographic tool measuring the age-based economic burden on the productive population. 
  • While useful for macro-planning, it doesn’t reflect actual employment, making it a crude but critical measure in population studies.

choices.text: It should be treated with surgical removal of mucin and polyps
Fungal stains and cultures are not necessary
Postoperative oral corticosteroids are not as important
Topical antifungal medications reduce postoperative recurrence

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding allergic fungal rhinosinusitis (AFRS) is most accurate?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It should be treated with surgical removal of mucin and polyps

 

  • Allergic Fungal Rhinosinusitis (AFRS) is a non-invasive fungal sinusitis seen in atopic individuals with nasal polyposis.
  • The key management step is endoscopic surgical clearance of thick allergic mucin and polyps, restoring sinus ventilation.
  • Systemic corticosteroids postoperatively are essential to reduce inflammation and recurrence.
  • Fungal cultures/stains confirm the diagnosis (they are necessary for diagnosis, not optional).
  • Topical or systemic antifungals have no proven benefit in AFRS, as the fungi are not tissue-invasive.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fungal stains and cultures not necessary: Incorrect — histologic confirmation with fungal elements (Aspergillus, Alternaria, etc.) is required.

 

Option C. Postoperative oral corticosteroids are not as important: False — they are the mainstay to reduce recurrence and mucosal inflammation.

 

Option D. Topical antifungal medications reduce postoperative recurrence: Ineffective; AFRS is an immunologic rather than infective process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • AFRS is treated primarily by functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS) with meticulous removal of mucin and polyps, followed by systemic corticosteroids to prevent recurrence. 
  • Antifungal drugs have no established role.

choices.text: For intubation in an anticipated difficult airway
Guide placement of double lumen tube
Suction of blood from the airways

questions.text: Identify the use of the equipment shown below in the picture?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the Above

 

Since the bronchoscope can be used for all the above-mentioned purposes: 

 

Option A. For Intubation in an Anticipated Difficult Airway: A flexible fiberoptic bronchoscope is often used to navigate and visualize the airway in cases where difficult intubation is anticipated, such as with abnormal airway anatomy.

 

Option B. Guide Placement of Double Lumen Tube: In thoracic surgery requiring lung isolation, a double-lumen endotracheal tube is used, and a fiberoptic bronchoscope is often employed to confirm proper placement and position of the tube.

 

Option C. Suction of Blood from the Airways: While primarily used for visualization, a bronchoscope can also assist in the suctioning of blood or secretions from the airway when necessary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A flexible fiberoptic bronchoscope and understand its multifunctional use in airway management, including aiding difficult intubations, guiding the placement of double-lumen tubes, and clearing the airways of obstructions such as blood or secretions.

questions.text: A male baby, born to a non-consanguineous couple, develops blisters over areas of friction soon after birth. There is a history of a previous child having similar complaints and dying at 2 weeks of age. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Epidermolysis bullosa

 

  • Epidermolysis bullosa (EB) is an inherited mechanobullous disorder characterized by blister formation after minor trauma due to structural protein defects in the skin.
  • The onset in the neonatal period, blisters at friction sites, and history of sibling death indicate a severe autosomal recessive variant, most likely Junctional EB (Herlitz type).
  • It presents with widespread erosions, mucosal involvement, and carries a poor prognosis, often fatal within weeks to months of birth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chronic bullous disorder of childhood: Occurs after 6 months of age; due to IgA deposition along the basement membrane (“string of pearls” appearance). Not congenital and not lethal.

 

Option C. Congenital syphilis: Presents with snuffles, rhagades, hepatosplenomegaly, and mucocutaneous fissures. No friction-induced blistering.

 

Option D. Neonatal pemphigus: Due to transplacental passage of maternal antibodies (anti-desmoglein 3) from a mother with pemphigus vulgaris. It is self-limiting and resolves as maternal IgG levels fall.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Epidermolysis bullosa is an inherited blistering disorder presenting at birth with friction-induced bullae.
  • A history of similar neonatal deaths points to junctional EB (Herlitz type) — the severe, often fatal autosomal recessive form caused by laminin-332 mutation.

questions.text: The device shown in the image is used for postoperative wound drainage. Identify the type of drain:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Closed suction

 

  • Closed suction drain (example: Jackson-Pratt drain, Romovac) consists of a drainage tube connected to a compressible reservoir bulb. 
  • When the bulb is compressed, it creates negative pressure, allowing continuous suction of fluid/blood into a closed system. 
  • This reduces infection risk compared to open drains and is commonly used after surgeries like mastectomy, thyroidectomy, and abdominal procedures.

 

Other Options:  

 

Option A. Open suction: These are open systems like Penrose drains, which drain fluid directly onto a gauze pad or stoma bag. They do not use suction, and infection risk is higher.

 

Option C. Closed continuous: This is not a standard classification; "closed suction" already refers to continuous suction in a sealed system.

 

Option D. Semi-closed: This is not a recognized drain type. It is often a distractor.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Closed suction drains (e.g., Jackson-Pratt, Romovac) use negative pressure to drain fluid into a sealed system, minimizing infection risk compared to open drains.

choices.text: Begin cognitive behavioral therapy and sex therapy

questions.text: A thirty-five-year-old man presents with recent-onset erectile difficulties. He reports good early morning erections but experiences failure during intercourse, especially with performance anxiety. Physical examination and hormone profile are normal. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Begin cognitive behavioral therapy and sex therapy

 

  • The presence of normal early morning erections and normal hormone levels with erectile difficulties in performance settings indicates a psychogenic cause, particularly performance anxiety. 
  • In such cases, the most appropriate management is psychotherapy, especially Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) and sex therapy, which target maladaptive thoughts and performance-related anxiety.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start testosterone replacement therapy: Testosterone therapy is indicated only in hypogonadism with low serum testosterone. Since the patient’s hormone profile is normal, this is unnecessary and may cause harm.

 

Option C. Prescribe long-term benzodiazepines: Benzodiazepines may temporarily reduce anxiety but are not first-line treatments for performance anxiety due to risk of dependence, sedation, and sexual side effects. They are not recommended for erectile dysfunction.

 

Option D. Schedule penile prosthesis implantation: This is a last-resort intervention for severe, treatment-resistant organic erectile dysfunction. It is invasive and not indicated in a young patient with psychogenic ED.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Psychogenic erectile dysfunction is suggested by normal morning erections, normal hormone profile, and performance-related failures. In such cases, cognitive behavioral therapy and sex therapy are first-line treatments. 
  • Identifying the psychological basis helps avoid unnecessary hormonal or invasive treatments.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements correctly describe the characteristics of oxidizing agents used in medical sterilization?

 

  1. Peracetic acid is non-corrosive and safe for all metals.
  2. Vaporized hydrogen peroxide can be used in presence of organic matter.
  3. Plasma sterilization is ideal for heat-sensitive instruments due to its low temperature.
  4. H₂O₂ functions by releasing peroxynitrite radicals which directly lyse bacterial membranes.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2 and 3 only

 

Statement 2. Vaporized hydrogen peroxide can be used in the presence of organic matter: Correct. One of the advantages of H₂O₂ as a sterilizing agent is its effectiveness even in the presence of organic material, unlike some other disinfectants that get inactivated.

 

Statement 3. Plasma sterilization is ideal for heat-sensitive instruments due to its low temperature: Correct. Plasma sterilization uses low temperatures (37–44°C), making it highly suitable for heat-labile instruments, such as ophthalmic, endoscopic, and plastic tools.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 1. Peracetic acid is non-corrosive and safe for all metals: Incorrect. Peracetic acid is effective as a sterilant but is known to corrode metals like steel, iron, copper, brass, and bronze. It must be used cautiously with metal instruments.

 

Statement 4. H₂O₂ functions by releasing peroxynitrite radicals which directly lyse bacterial membranes: Incorrect. The active moiety of hydrogen peroxide in sterilization is the hydroxyl radical (•OH), not peroxynitrite (ONOO⁻). These radicals cause damage to DNA, proteins, and membrane lipids, leading to microbial death.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Vaporized hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂) and plasma sterilization are preferred methods for sterilizing heat-sensitive equipment.
  • H₂O₂ acts by releasing hydroxyl radicals, not peroxynitrite.
  • Peracetic acid, although effective, can be corrosive to certain metals and is not universally safe.

questions.text:
All of the following provisions are true under the Mental Healthcare Act (MHCA), 2017, except: 

 

  1. Psychiatrists are legally liable if adverse outcomes occur while following an advance directive.
  2. Attempt to suicide is presumed to be due to severe stress and is not punishable under IPC.
  3. Supported admission can last a maximum of 30 days.
  4. Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) is banned for minors.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 only

 

Statement 1. Psychiatrists are legally liable if adverse outcomes occur while following an advance directive: False. Psychiatrists are not legally liable if adverse outcomes occur while following an advance directive in good faith.

 

Correct Statements: 

 

  • Statement 2. Attempt to suicide is presumed to be due to severe stress and is not punishable under IPC: True.  MHCA 2017 decriminalizes suicide; anyone attempting suicide is presumed under severe stress, hence not punishable.
  • Statement 3. Supported admission can last a maximum of 30 days: True. Supported admission is permitted for up to 30 days initially.
  • Statement 4. Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) is banned for minors: True. ECT is banned for minors and direct ECT without anesthesia is prohibited.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MENTAL HEALTHCARE ACT, 2017 (MHCA 2017):

 

  • Deals with rights of patients with mental illness and treatment delivery. Important clauses-

 

A. Capacity to make mental healthcare and treatment decision- Every person, including patients with mental illness, are assumed to have it if they can-

 

  • Can understand the information provided to them
  • Understand the consequences of their decisions
  • Can communicate their decision

 

B. Advance directive- Every person (not a minor) can make an advance directive in which he can mention-

 

  • How they wish to be treated/not treated for a mental illness
  • Applicable only if a person loses the capacity to take mental healthcare or treatment decisions
  • Duty of psychiatrist (or medical officer) to give treatment according to the advance directive
  • Doctor is not liable in case of unforeseen consequences while following the advance directive

 

C. Nominated representative (NR)-

 

  • Every person can appoint a nominated representative
  • In case of loss of capacity to make mental healthcare and treatment decision, NR would help in taking decisions about treatment

 

D. Admission- MHCA 2017 allows two types of admissions

 

  • Independent admissions- When the patient himself wants to get admitted
  • Supported admission (for a maximum of 30 days)- A person who has lost the capacity to make mental healthcare or treatment decisions and requires significant support from a nominated representative can be admitted under a “supported admission”

 

E. Ban on direct ECT

 

F. Ban on ECT for minors

 

G. Ban on psychosurgery

 

H. Decriminalisation of suicide attempt - Any person who attempts suicide shall be presumed to be under severe stress and should not be tried or punished

 

I. Restraints and seclusions - A patient can be physically restrained only-

 

  • If it is the only way to prevent harm to self or others
  • If authorised by a psychiatrist in charge

choices.text: There is correlation between the two variables and the Pearson coefficient equals +1
There is correlation between the two variables and the Pearson coefficient equals –1
There is no linear correlation between the two variables
There is no association between the two variables

questions.text: A quality-improvement team examines the relationship between number of units processed per batch (X) and total quantity produced (Y). Which interpretation is most appropriate with respect to Pearson correlation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) There is no linear correlation between the two variables

 

  • Pearson’s r quantifies the strength of a linear relationship (−1 to +1).
    The plotted data demonstrate a non-linear association (Y increases with X, then decreases—an inverted U). 
  • In such settings, the overall slope averaged across the range is near zero, so Pearson’s r will be close to 0, even though the variables are clearly related.
  • Therefore, the correct interpretation is “no linear correlation.” 
  • A better analysis would use a quadratic term, spline/LOESS smoother, or piecewise model to capture curvature.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. There is correlation between the two variables and the Pearson coefficient equals +1: Would require all points to lie on a single upward straight line with no scatter, which is not what the plot shows.

 

Option B. There is correlation between the two variables and the Pearson coefficient equals –1: Would require a straight downward line; also not present.

 

Option D. There is no association between the two variables: Incorrect. The plot shows a clear association, just not linear. Saying “no association” confuses no linear correlation (r ≈ 0) with independence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pearson correlation measures linear association only.
  • A correlation near zero does not exclude a strong non-linear relationship.
  • Always inspect the scatterplot and, when curvature is present, use non-linear modeling (e.g., polynomial or spline).

questions.text:
Which of the following regarding CADASIL is incorrect? 

 

  1. MRI is frequently normal
  2. It is caused by a mutation in the NOTCH2 gene
  3. Definitive diagnosis can be made via nerve biopsy
  4. It is inherited in an autosomal recessive fashion
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

  • CADASIL (Cerebral Autosomal Dominant Arteriopathy with Subcortical Infarcts and Leukoencephalopathy) is a hereditary small-vessel disease of the brain caused by a NOTCH3 gene mutation on chromosome 19.
  • Correct facts about CADASIL:

 

 

Statement 1. MRI is frequently normal: Incorrect. MRI almost always shows abnormalities, even in asymptomatic carriers.

 

Statement 2. Mutation in NOTCH2 gene: Incorrect. Mutation occurs in NOTCH3, not NOTCH2.

 

Statement 3. Definitive diagnosis via nerve biopsy: Incorrect. Diagnosis is made by skin biopsy, not nerve biopsy.

 

Statement 4. Autosomal recessive inheritance: Incorrect. CADASIL is autosomal dominant.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • CADASIL is an autosomal dominant small-vessel arteriopathy caused by NOTCH3 mutations.
  • MRI shows leukoencephalopathy (especially in anterior temporal lobes and external capsule).
  • Skin biopsy confirms diagnosis (GOM deposits, NOTCH3 positivity).
  • Nerve biopsy is not used, and MRI is not normal.

questions.text: Match the following observance days with their correct dates:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-c, 2-b, 3-a, 4-d

 

  • 1-c. World Sight Day → 9th October:
    • World Sight Day is observed on the second Thursday of October; in 2025 that falls on 9 Oct. 
    • 2025 theme/campaign: #LoveYourEyes, with a focus on “putting people at the heart of eye health.”
  • 2-b. UN Day → 24th October: UN Day marks the anniversary of the UN Charter entering into force (24 Oct 1945).
  • 3-a. Universal Immunization Day → 10th November: In India, Universal/World Immunization Day is observed annually on 10 November to spotlight vaccination and the UIP/Mission Indradhanush.
  • 4-d. World Mental Health Day → 10th October: 2025 theme (WFMH): “Access to Services – Mental Health in Catastrophes and Emergencies.” (Announced by the World Federation for Mental Health; also reflected by global mental-health partners.)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Important Days of Public Health Importance in Oct and Nov: 

 

  • 1st October - International Day for Older Persons
  • 1st October - National Voluntary Blood Donation Day
  • 2nd Wednesday of October (Now 13 October) - World Disaster Reduction Day
  • 9th October - World Sight Day
  • 10th October - World Mental Health Day
  • 16th October - World Anesthesia Day
  • 24th October - UN Day
  • 10th November - Universal Immunization Day
  • 14th November - World Diabetes Day
  • 17th November - National Epilepsy Day
  • 25th November - International Day for Elimination of Violence against Women

choices.text: Complete pelvic organ prolapse with mucosal erosion
Advanced uterine descent with vaginal wall ulcer

questions.text: A 60-year-old postmenopausal woman reports a vaginal bulge that she has noticed for several months. She was initially able to push it back inside, but over the past few days, it has become painful and irreducible. On examination, a large mass is seen as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Uterovaginal prolapse with decubitus ulcer

 

  • Uterovaginal prolapse with decubitus ulcer is a common complication of long-standing pelvic organ prolapse, particularly in postmenopausal women.
  • Due to loss of estrogen, pelvic floor muscles and ligaments weaken, leading to uterine descent through the vagina.
  • The exposed vaginal mucosa is prone to chronic pressure, friction, and infection, resulting in ulceration—called a decubitus ulcer.

 

Key features in this patient:

 

  • Postmenopausal age
  • Irreducible uterovaginal prolapse
  • Reddish, ulcerated area (pressure necrosis) on the protruding surface

 

These findings confirm the diagnosis of uterovaginal prolapse with decubitus ulcer.

 

 

Management:

 

  • Initial treatment: Local care with antiseptics or estrogen cream to promote healing of the ulcer.
  • Definitive treatment: Once healed, surgical repair such as vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair or Le Fort colpocleisis (if the patient no longer desires sexual function).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uterine procidentia with pressure ulceration: Although similar in presentation, "uterine procidentia" refers to complete uterine prolapse, where the uterus lies entirely outside the vaginal introitus. It is often used interchangeably but “uterovaginal prolapse with decubitus ulcer” is the more accurate clinical diagnosis here.

 

Option C. Complete pelvic organ prolapse with mucosal erosion: This term describes generalized pelvic organ descent (including bladder or rectum) with mucosal changes, but the specific ulceration due to pressure defines it as a decubitus ulcer rather than simple mucosal erosion.

 

Option D. Advanced uterine descent with vaginal wall ulcer: While advanced uterine descent can cause ulceration, this is a nonspecific term. The precise diagnosis, per gynecologic terminology, is uterovaginal prolapse with decubitus ulcer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Uterovaginal prolapse with decubitus ulcer occurs when prolonged prolapse causes pressure necrosis and ulceration of the exposed vaginal mucosa. 
  • It is a hallmark complication of long-standing, irreducible uterine prolapse in postmenopausal women.

questions.text: A mutation in the AIRE gene results in defective negative selection of autoreactive T cells in the thymus. This defect leads to failure of central tolerance and development of which of the following disorders?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Autoimmune Polyendocrinopathy - Candidiasis-Ectodermal Dystrophy (APECED)

 

  • The AIRE (Autoimmune Regulator) gene is essential for central tolerance during T-cell development in the thymus.

 

Normal function:

 

  • AIRE promotes the expression of self-antigens in thymic medullary epithelial cells.
  • This allows developing T cells to be exposed to a wide variety of self-antigens.
  • Autoreactive T cells that bind too strongly to self-antigens undergo negative selection (apoptosis) — preventing autoimmunity.

 

Defect:

 

  • Mutation in the AIRE gene → failure to eliminate self-reactive T cells → multiple autoimmune disorders.

 

Clinical features of APECED:

 

  1. Autoimmune adrenal insufficiency
  2. Hypoparathyroidism
  3. Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis (Also called Autoimmune Polyendocrinopathy Syndrome Type I)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hashimoto’s Thyroiditis: An organ-specific autoimmune disease due to autoantibodies against thyroid antigens (TPO, thyroglobulin), not caused by AIRE gene mutation.

 

Option B. Autoimmune Lymphoproliferative Syndrome (ALPS): Caused by a defect in FAS gene (CD95), leading to failure of apoptosis of self-reactive lymphocytes in the periphery, not a defect in AIRE.

 

Option C. Goodpasture’s Syndrome: Due to autoantibodies against type IV collagen in basement membranes of lungs and kidneys — not related to T-cell negative selection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The AIRE gene regulates the expression of self-antigens in thymic medullary epithelial cells, promoting negative selection of autoreactive T cells. Defects in AIRE lead to Autoimmune Polyendocrinopathy-Candidiasis-Ectodermal Dystrophy (APECED).

choices.text: Arachidonic acid, Linoleic acid, Gamma-linolenic acid
Palmitic acid, Stearic acid, Oleic acid
Cervonic acid, Alpha-linolenic acid, Timnodonic acid
Linoleic acid, Arachidonic acid, Palmitic acid

questions.text: Which of the following groups consists of omega 3 fatty acids that play essential roles in neural, retinal, and cardiovascular health?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cervonic acid, Alpha-linolenic acid, Timnodonic acid 

 

  • Omega-3 fatty acids are a class of polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs) characterized by the position of their first double bond at the third carbon from the methyl (ω) end. 
  • They are essential for maintaining cell membrane integrity, neuronal development, visual function, and anti-inflammatory responses.
  • The key omega-3 fatty acids include:
    • Alpha-linolenic acid (ALA) – 18:3 (ω-3), a plant-derived essential fatty acid.
    • Timnodonic acid (Eicosapentaenoic acid, EPA) – 20:5 (ω-3), abundant in fish oil.
    • Cervonic acid (Docosahexaenoic acid, DHA) – 22:6 (ω-3), vital for brain and retinal tissue.
  • These fatty acids contribute to the synthesis of anti-inflammatory eicosanoids and protective membrane phospholipids in neural and cardiac cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arachidonic acid, Linoleic acid, Gamma-linolenic acid: These are omega-6 fatty acids, precursors to pro-inflammatory prostaglandins and leukotrienes.

 

Option B. Palmitic acid, Stearic acid, Oleic acid: Palmitic and stearic acids are saturated, while oleic acid is monounsaturated (ω-9)—none are ω-3 PUFAs.

 

Option D. Linoleic acid, Arachidonic acid, Palmitic acid: Linoleic and arachidonic acids are omega-6, and palmitic acid is saturated, not omega-3.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cervonic acid (DHA), Timnodonic acid (EPA), and Alpha-linolenic acid (ALA) are the principal omega-3 fatty acids, with the first double bond located at the third carbon from the methyl end, providing anti-inflammatory, neuroprotective, and cardioprotective effects.
